PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BJELKE-PETERSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 23 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During the adjournment debate on Thursday, 2 April, Senator Tate sought assurances from me that Parliament House was safe for those who work in it, following allegations made that day in the media of the detection of legionella in the air conditioning water towers of Parliament House. At the first opportunity I had on Friday morning I advised Senator Tate's office in the terms of the statement made in the House of Representatives by Mr Speaker on Thursday night.

INTERJECT.PARA: I now inform honourable senators that testing of air conditioning units in this House has been regularly carried out since July 1980 and has included checks on the filters of the fresh air intakes, the quality of conditioned air in certain areas and the water heating and cooling systems. Reports received from the Department of Health, which has consulted with the National Biological Standards Laboratory and the Fairfield Infectious Diseases Hospital, raised no problems with the air conditioning system until the report received by the Joint House Department on 28 February 1981. That report revealed that a water sample from the stand-by water cooling tower within the Prime Minister's suite had disclosed organisms of legionella pneumophilia. Those organisms were contained in that water cooling tower which is confined to and operates only as a stand-by system in the Prime Minister's suite. The water contained in that stand-by system is not connected with the chilled water provided from the main water cooling tower which services most of the Parliament House building.

Consultations between the Joint House Department and the Department of Health resulted in immediate remedial action being taken by the addition of chemicals with a capacity to destroy the bacteria discovered. Tests were also carried out on the main water cooling tower from 16 December 1980 to 19 February this year, and these proved negative. However, a water sample taken from that tower on 28 February 1981 disclosed a strain of legionella pneumophilia. That information was reported by the Department of Health to the Joint House Department on Friday, 3 April 1981-last Friday. Remedial action based on the advice of the Department of Health was taken immediately and consisted of the addition of chemicals to the main water cooling tower similar to those applied to the Prime Minister's stand-by water cooling tower. The Department of Health has advised that the monthly chemical treatment of water in all cooling towers should be increased to fortnightly frequencies, and that action has now been implemented.

I further inform this House that the Department of Health, in conjunction with the Joint House Department, issued a public statement on Friday last. That release is available for honourable senators but I will quote the substantive part relating to the safety of Parliament House:
There is no evidence to suggest that conditions in the air-conditioning system at Parliament House made the House unsafe for members, senators, staff or visitors, from the standpoint of infection.

Air samples tested in Parliament House had not shown serious pathogenic organisms. Legionella pneumophilia had been found only in two isolated specimens from two air-conditioning cooling towers. The organisms were not being circulated by the air-conditioners in Parliament House and so no more danger existed there than in any other building, or to the community at large.

I believe that the interest and safety of honourable senators, members of the House of Representatives, parliamentary staff and visitors to Parliament House have been the prime concern of those responsible for the tests that have taken place. I can assure honourable senators that the testing schedule on the air conditioning system will be maintained and I will make a further report to this chamber if there is any significant change in circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday night, 2 April 1981, I made a statement about accommodation for the Parliamentary Library in response to a question which Senator McAuliffe had asked me earlier in the day. I have thought since that, although Senator McAuliffe did not explicitly ask for it, he may have been seeking clarification about some transfers to the Kurrajong annex during the last summer recess. As reported to the Library Committee on 5 March this year, extenuating circumstances arose as a result of extreme heat earlier this year which prompted Mr Speaker and me to agree that conditions would be better in the Kurrajong than the Canberra Hotel annex for the statistics group of the Legislative Research Service and its special equipment, some elements of the systems and co-ordination unit and the administration section of the Library. In addition to those 20 officers from the Canberra Hotel annex, five persons in the systems and co-ordination unit, who had only makeshift accommodation in Parliament House, were moved to join the rest of their unit in the Kurrajong annex. These transfers were prompted primarily by considerations of staff welfare and have been appreciated by the officers concerned. They certainly could not be described as 'major determinations on locations' and did not constitute a breach of an assurance given by me to the Senate.

—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether he said on 8 October last year that if Australia was to meet its energy balance within the decade we would need to have functioning by 1980 three or four enterprises of the size of the Rundle shale oil project. Did he say that output from Rundle could reach 240,000 barrels a day by 1988? What timetable does he now envisage for oil production from shale over the next 10 years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without being pedantic, I presume that Senator Button meant 1990 and not 1980 as he said. I do not say that in any sense of correction, but just to set the timetable. I think Senator Button has quoted faithfully from what I have said. Indeed, if Senator Button were to look at the progress of the various coal liquefaction undertakings which are emerging in the Latrobe Valley, the Rheinbraun project, the Mitsui-CSR project and the Cominic project, he would find that a series of hydrocarbon synthetic crude undertakings is starting to get into place and will aim to be in position by the 1990s and to supplement any decline that there may be in oil.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, I mentioned Rundle, along with other such projects. The fact is that one hopes strongly that oil shale will play a significant part, along with coal liquefaction and other methods, in supplying the hydrocarbon needs of Australia. I hope that all honourable senators will be wishing that Rundle and similar projects will succeed. It is immensely in the interests of all Australians that the synthetic crude projects should succeed in Australia.

I cannot say what the timetable for Rundle will be. Yesterday's Press statement indicated that the joint venturers were now thinking of by-passing the pilot plant stage and going directly to a commercial plant. That may or may not do one of two things; it could, I understand, even expedite the coming on stream or it could delay it.
Opposition senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is to wait until the technical people say. Since there is a note of derision let me say that in the world at the moment some seven major oil shale projects are under way. Three of them have reached the construction stage. The technology to turn shale into oil is well known. The technology of the Exxon Corporation, the major technical partner in Rundle, is world acknowledged. I would hope that we would all encourage the success of all such projects.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister answer that part of the question relating to his statement of 8 October last year in which he said that if Australia was to meet its energy balance within the next decade we would need to have functioning three or four enterprises of the size of the Rundle shale project?
—Come on!
—Come on yourself. Will the Minister comment on the timetable in the light of that statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button could not have noted that I indicated that since then there have been announcements regarding the Rheinbraun project in the Latrobe Valley, the Cominic project, the Mitsui-CSR project and the Gelliondale undertaking. But perhaps because good news, at least to this side of the House, is attractive, let say that yesterday I was at the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association conference-the largest by 50 per cent in attendance and in calibre ever held in Australia, with some 950 registered delegates. The note was one of sustained optimism that Australia--
—Did they talk about Rundle?
—Tell us about Rundle.

—The Jeremiahs have always been wrong. Their spokesman-a gentleman named Paul Keating in another place-has a reputation for always being wrong. Mr President, you will remember that it was said that it would be 40c for a litre of petrol by January. Let me tell the Senate what APEA said. APEA yesterday said that the prospects for finding moderate supplies of oil and significant supplies of gas in Australia were never better. I was advised that indeed it is likely that, instead of there being a decline in Bass Strait production, extra finds of oil are likely there as indeed they are in central Australia and elsewhere. These finds will in fact help to iron out the indigenous oil supplies so that the pressure on us will not be so great in this decade as it was before. In fact the good news yesterday overwhelmingly outweighed the news of Rundle.
—Tell the Rundle shareholders that. You have talked them up. You have talked them up worse than Patrick Partners did.

—Senator Grimes interjects-the interjection ought to be recorded-that I talked up the Rundle shares. Well, Mr President, here is how I talked up the Rundle shares: The Australian Financial Review, which picks statement after statement of mine in this Senate urging caution about the technological development of Rundle, wrote:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for National Development, Senator Carrick, in Federal Parliament yesterday, cast doubts on the viability of the Rundle shale oil project.

Talking it up! Indeed, let me read a couple of statements to the Senate. In no way do I resile from the fact that Rundle has every good chance of success. Let me read from the Senate Hansard. It reads:
The fact of the matter is that shale may well be there in those kinds of quantities--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I suggest that, as the Minister is reading from volumes of newspaper cuttings, if he sought the leave of the Senate he might be allowed to incorporate them.
—No, I cannot take your point of order. There is no point of order.
—Mr President, contrary to what Senator Keeffe has said, I am reading from Hansard and that, of course, is permitted.
—A Press statement.
—No. I held up a Press statement. I am now reading from Hansard. It reads:

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that shale may well be there in those kinds of quantities, but it becomes a valuable resource only when it is known that, within the capacity of our technology and within the cost structure that is available to us, it can be a useable resource. At this moment oil shale in Australia has yet to be proved to be a significant useable resource. This is why Rundle is such an imaginative and courageous undertaking-setting out, on a scale never undertaken before, to conduct this enterprise and hoping to do so in competition with the price of petrol. One cannot say that the existence of oil shale in the ground in Australia, with unknown difficulties in relation to its extraction, can be a guarantee that the world will be less oil hungry.
May I read even further on--

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that only when you knew it was crook.
—This happened to be on 15 May 1980. I turn to the Senate record again. It reads:

ANSWER.PARA: So the assumption which underlay the Prime Minister's statement is that the companies are going into this project to prove the commercial viability. Of course, any venture encounters risks along the journey.
So time and time again I have pointed out that in any--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one time.

—No. Twice in one instance and three times in another, and there are the headlines in the Australian Financial Review. Time and time again I have pointed out that in any engineering venture at all there are difficulties, there are needs of reappraisals. What I say here is that every decent and thinking Australian should be urging the success of all liquefaction and oil shale projects in Australia.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Social Security. In view of the enormous drain on family finances, both as initially outlaid in purchasing clothing and equipment and later for needed assistance in the home, can some review be made of the family allowance in the case of multiple births, particularly as triplets, for instance, seem to qualify for no special aid?

—Senator Archer correctly advises the Senate in his question that there is no special aid provided for triplets. In fact, there is no additional assistance for twins. But it is normally the practice for act of grace payments to be made for quadruplets. Those payments are made not by the Department of Social Security but, I think, by the Department of Finance through the recent Minister for Social Security. I do take the point which is made by the honourable senator. Obviously there is a substantial additional cost in providing for multiple births. I will therefore ensure that this is among the many matters which are to be considered prior to the Budget.

—My question is directed to Senator Carrick as Minister for National Development and Energy and as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: Does he know that $57m of the market value added to the shares of Central Pacific Minerals NL over the last two years was wiped out yesterday? Given his strenuous efforts to beat up the shares in the first place, one example of which was quoted by Senator Button, what responsibility does he accept for the $57m lost yesterday by small investors? Can he tell the Senate what the Prime Minister dodged telling Senator Wriedt on 23 May 1980, that is, which Ministers or their families have shares in Southern Pacific Petroleum NL or Central Pacific Minerals NL?

—I am not aware of the amount lost yesterday on the shares of that particular company. Certainly, I believe that it was of great importance that the statement of reappraisal of the enterprise should be made. If that is reflected, however temporarily, in a decline in shares, that is what the share market should take. The fact is, as one will see from the records of my statements, that I have expressed over the months and the years a proper caution and, indeed, a cautious optimism about the development of shale and shale oil in Australia. I have never denied the fact that the project has its engineering and cost difficulties but I have wanted it to succeed, as I hope all decent Australians will want it to succeed. The technical partner in Rundle, the Exxon corporation, is world-renowned for its expertise and its integrity, both scientific and commercial. I believe that if anybody can make the project succeed, Exxon will do so. I believe that yesterday the people of Australia were given a very proper statement of reappraisal after certain mining and other appraisals had been made.

—I ask a supplementary question. Senator Carrick did not deal with the second half of my question. Can he tell the Senate what the Prime Minister dodged telling Senator Wriedt almost a year ago; that is, which Ministers or their families hold shares in the Rundle partners? I refer the Minister to page 2936 of the Senate Hansard.

—Mr President, I did not intentionally ignore that part of the question. The fact is that this is a matter for the Prime Minister. I will refer it him and seek his reply. I remind the Senate that it was this Government that instituted the Bowen inquiry, that has already accepted voluntarily for its Ministers the Bowen standards of conduct and will proceed--
—After rejecting the unanimous report of a parliamentary inquiry.
—What about Garland's dividend stripping?

—Mr President, the acoustics are not aided nor is the intellectual content added to by those kinds of interjections. The Government will be extending the provisions of the Bowen report to all honourable senators and honourable members. Then they can look to their own integrity.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce: What action has been taken regarding the pilot study of Tasmanian tourist accommodation which was undertaken last year with a view to assessing tourist facilities for disabled travellers available in my State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pilot study referred to by the honourable senator was undertaken in Tasmania by the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of the Disabled on behalf of the Department of Industry and Commerce and was conducted last year. The main purpose of the study was to develop a methodology appropriate to an Australia-wide study on the same subject and to prepare a national directory of travel accommodation facilities suitable for disabled travellers. All this is part of the contribution of the Department of Industry and Commerce to the International Year of Disabled Persons. The pilot study is regarded as having been successful and it is now being followed up nationally. Tenders have been called for a national study. The Minister for Industry and Commerce expects to announce the successful tenderer shortly. It is expected that the study will be commenced in May of this year. The directory, which will include details for the whole of Australia, including Tasmania, will be published by the end of this year.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not intended to publish separately the results of the preliminary survey which was conducted in Tasmania, but I understand that the information has been made available to the Tasmanian Tourist Board, which will incorporate indicative information relating to accessibility for the disabled in its publication Travelways. Full details of accommodation facilities suitable for disabled travellers are available on request from officers of the Tasmanian Department of Tourism.

This looks to be a very useful additional service for the disabled in this country. I hope that it will be but one of the literally hundreds of successful projects undertaken for the International Year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy both in his own ministerial capacity and as Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is he aware that when the Prime Minister announced the go-ahead for the Rundle project on 28 February last year he rationalised the huge profits Esso had been making in the Bass Strait oil fields on the grounds that they would be reinvested in Rundle? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Rundle project will provide an opportunity for Esso to reinvest in Australia the profits it has derived from the Bass Strait oil fields.
How does the Minister rationalise the huge profits Esso is making in Bass Strait, now that it has bailed out of Rundle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very, very happy to do so. Senator Grimes will know that I was able to announce early last year that Esso-BHP will invest in development in Bass Strait $1,200m over the next few years. That adds up to the extra profit made from oil prices by those two companies in Bass Strait. Quite apart from any other investment these companies make in Australia, they are in their development reinvesting in Bass Strait. If Senator Grimes wishes I will give him details of that investment.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot understand why the Australian Labor Party has such an innate hatred of profit. It is only by company profits that we get capital for investment that enables Australia to have new industries which will create new jobs. Labor's dog in the manger attitude denies the right of Australia to expand and give people more employment. I thought it would be a healthy Australia which would recognise profit as healthy, have it ploughed back into Australia and create jobs and skills for our young.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. If it is a fact that Esso has reinvested all its excess profits-or whatever the Minister wants to call them-in Bass Strait, why did the Prime Minister say last year that it was investing its excess profits in Rundle when, according to the Minister, it was not?

—Senator Grimes has difficulty with the past, present and future tense. I said that the $1,200m was roughly the amount of profit that Esso and BHP had made from higher oil prices. In future years they may make more profits and, of course, they will invest them as they are doing-as BHP is doing-in many new ventures in Australia. Let us keep in mind that BHP is supported--
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Walsh laughs. The shareholdings in BHP, through superannuation, provident funds and fixed trusts, influence the lives of some millions of Australians. Every extra dollar of profit that BHP makes means that Australians can retire in more comfort than before. So let the honourable senator deride the profits. After all, many millions of Australians are the shareholders.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DRAFT CONVENTION AGAINST TORTURE: OPTIONAL PROTOCOL

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the March 1981 edition of Justice, the newsletter of the International Commission of Jurists, Australian section, relating to the optional protocol to the draft convention against torture. The optional protocol will provide for nations to permit visits to places of detention within their jurisdiction by members of an international expert committee. Is it correct, as alleged in this article, that the Australian Government is opposed to the notion of an optional protocol being debated at this stage of the proceedings? If that is so, will the Attorney-General inform the Senate why the Australian Government has adopted that attitude? Does the Attorney-General agree with the claims of the International Commission of Jurists that the optional protocol provides some practical solutions to the problem of torture? If so, will consideration be given by the Government both to supporting debate on the optional protocol at the same time as the draft convention is considered and to supporting the merits of this course of action in discussion with other nations?

—The declaration against torture to which Senator Missen referred will be discussed at the ministerial meeting on human rights to take place on Friday. I am not in a position to answer specifically the question Senator Missen raised in relation to the optional protocol. I will take note of it and give the matter further consideration.

—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy a question. It is not about Rundle. I refer him to the inquiry currently being undertaken by a working party of the Australian Institution of Engineers into the feasibility of constructing a four-State power grid to service Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia and Tasmania. Has the Minister noted the recent statement by the Premier of Victoria, Mr Hamer, that the grid proposal had the full support of the Victorian Government? Is the Minister aware that the Institution of Engineers working party has recommended the deferring of any plans for future hydro-electric power schemes in Tasmania, particularly the Franklin River, until a final decision on the grid has been made? Does the Minister recall the policy commitments made by the Liberal and National Country parties in 1975 to the preservation of the south-west Tasmanian wilderness area and the Prime Minister's statement last June that the Federal Government would be willing to help finance an enlarged south-west national park to include wilderness areas? In view of these promises, will the Government give its full moral and financial support to the grid proposal and treat it as a matter of the most urgent priority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Senator Chipp would know that the Government through me, as Minister, set up an inquiry under Sir David Zeidler, a very distinguished Australian, to find out the facts about a grid for south-east Australia, taking in South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales and, it is hoped-who knows-proceeding further north. In Europe and elsewhere there is plenty of information on the success of power grids. It is against that background that the inquiry is proceeding. It is an inquiry which, of course, links haves and have-nots. It links two States which have the accidental presence, which they are very happy about, of the Snowy Mountains scheme to provide, in a way, their own grid.
—It is not accidental. It was planned by a Labor Government.

—South Australia and Tasmania lack that. As Senator McLaren will know, South Australia until this moment has lacked the natural resource to produce power. One hopes that the coal being found there will resolve that situation. One hopes that the supply of power in South Australia will be helped a lot. I have attended meetings of the inquiry and have urged it to strive for a successful result. I believe that this grid is a very sensible means of progress for Australia. Whether, in the first step, a cable under Bass Strait is feasible is something to be investigated; nevertheless, it is contemplated. I am aware of the submission by the Australian Institution of Engineers and its claims that the working of the grid would save in the capital and operating costs of power stations some hundreds of millions of dollars, even billions of dollars. I am aware it has given evidence as to base loads and peak loads. I have asked the Zeidler inquiry to study the submission in detail. I believe it is doing so. In my judgment the Zeidler inquiry is very significant.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the statement made in 1975 by the Prime Minister on the south-west wilderness of Tasmania. I think that all Australians who know the place have a tremendous interest in it. I am utterly sure that the Prime Minister and the Government hold the same support. As to the general concept, it is absolutely imperative that we in Australia save electric power. The lead time to build a power station is something between seven years and 10 years and the cost today runs into something like $1 billion. If we can save the cost of building a couple of power stations we can build another couple of very large undertakings that can employ more people in Australia. So every time we can save we can advance. I commend the spirit of Senator Chipp's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister sincerely for his full answer. Arising from that answer, I will now be presumptuous enough to ask the Minister whether he will use his good offices with members of the Liberal Party in Tasmania who masquerade as independents in the Legislative Council to stop them harassing the Lowe Government in its desire to save the Franklin River from being dammed.

—I am congenitally a federalist. I do not keep a dog and bark myself. I recognise two sovereignties. I operate within the federal sphere of power. I note what others do in other places. It is a wise man who understands that in other chambers, even in upper Houses, people may possess wisdom and we should not deny that. I make that comment to Senator Chipp.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer to question 16 of the latest census form. The question asks:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the person of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander origin?
The question goes on:
For persons of mixed origin, indicate the one to which they consider themselves to belong.

I ask the Minister: Why are Aborigines singled out in this degrading, dehumanising way? If the Minister cares to look at question 13 of the census form she will see that persons of other nationalities are not asked the same question. Am I to read into this some sinister meaning, as the Minister will no doubt be aware that there are many people who continue to categorise in this dehumanising fashion the indigenous people of this country? As an Aborigine, and being recognised as one of the leaders of my race, I demand that this portion of question 16 be removed from the census form.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am interested to hear Senator Bonner's remarks in regard to the matter he has raised. Perhaps I should explain that the reason for adding to question 16 on the census form the explanatory text to which Senator Bonner has taken exception is the same as the reason for adding it to other questions; that is, that tests show that some explanation is needed for the question to be answered in a reasonably consistent fashion by those people who fill in the census form. Question 16 asks, in effect, whether individuals identify themselves as being of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander origin. Rather than being degrading-that is the way in which I think Senator Bonner referred to it-the explanatory text indicates that those people in any doubt should choose the category to which they regard themselves as belonging. I think in the case of those who identify themselves as Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders in this country, it is a matter of their own perception whether they belong to that category.

ANSWER.PARA: When the Australian Bureau of Statistics consulted interested bodies on the inclusion of this question in the census all agreed that it ought to be included and also that it should be on the basis of self-identification or self-perception. The bodies consulted on this matter included the National Aboriginal Conference. Perhaps I should also point out to honourable senators that substantially the same wording as now appears on the form was included in the document entitled 'Topic Evaluation and Proposed Questions' which was tabled in the Senate on 20 November 1979.

Senator Bonner also referred to question 13. I should explain that this question relates to a matter quite different from Aboriginal origin. Question 13 relates to citizenship which is a matter of legal status and not self-perception or self-identification. Honourable senators might note that question 13 also requires some explanatory text so that it can be filled in in a consistent manner by those who are completing the census form. I have noted what Senator Bonner said about this question. I will see that the question is referred to the Treasurer for consideration of the matters that he has raised. The explanation is that the reason for the explanatory text is to achieve consistency of information. In the case of question 16, it refers to self-identification or self-perception.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer that the question involved in the matter I raised has no bad connotations, will the Minister now consider asking all people who are not of British stock the same type of question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether the same type of question would be appropriate. However, where it is considered that any further information may be required, this could be dealt with on the census form. As I said, the other matter which was referred to is related to citizenship, which is a matter of legal status and not of self-identification. As I have said, the points raised by Senator Bonner can be given some consideration in dealing with these matters in future. I do wish to explain that the form was drafted in this way for consistency and explanation. A number of the questions on the form do give an explanation to assist people to give consistent information for statistical purposes.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, and it is about Rundle. Did the Minister say on 5 October last year that to reject import parity pricing would repel and deter the establishment of synthetic oil projects upon which our oil future depended? Did he also say that gimmicks were poor substitutes for policies? Will he now admit that his policies emphasising synthetic oil production were wrong-headed? Will the Government now abandon these ill-fated policies and adopt the Australian Labor Party policy of giving priority to conventional oil exploration while encouraging further research into synthetic fuels?

—I did say in October that if oil parity pricing were rejected it would be very bad indeed. I did say that gimmicks were bad. Yesterday at the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association conference it was unanimously agreed that the import parity pricing policy is highly successful. It is the basis of success. But perhaps Senator Keeffe is the only one in step in the regiment. Let me say simply that the 21 nations that meet in the International Energy Agency to discuss the world policy all agree that the primary policy to overcome energy shortage is import parity pricing. Let Senator Keeffe be the only one out of step. I am now asked to endorse the Australian Labor Party's policy. Let us see what the Labor Party's policy did. In 1975-that was the last year of the Whitlam Government-25 exploration wells were drilled in Australia. We increased that to 80 last year and to 137 this year. It was 25 under Labor, 137 under us. Let us go a little better. Senator Keeffe wants to know whether I will endorse his policy. Exploration and development expenditure increased from $145m in 1975 to $780m last year and to $1,400m this year. I am being asked to support a policy under which the drilling rigs left Australia and people fled from the place. I am being asked to support a policy under which in 1975 there was only a handful of active explorers in Australia and only 112 exploration permits were on issue. Today there are nearly 300 permits and there are literally hundreds of exploration companies actively involved. The policy speaks for itself.

—I ask a supplementary question. It is obvious that the Minister is over a barrel in this case. He is becoming emotional. I ask for a reply to the last part of my question. Will the Government abandon the ill-based policies it is currently pursuing and give greater encouragement to further research into synthetic fuels?

—The answer is that it would be foolhardy to abandon success-success acknowledged by the world. We will not abandon our policy; we will continue to pursue it. The fact that a significant number of synthetic fuel projects are being undertaken in Australia at this moment is evidence of the success of the policy.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the reports of the outstanding success of the anti-smoking campaign in Coffs Harbour and Lismore in New South Wales? Was the campaign designed to alert people to the dangers of smoking-related diseases, the most serious preventable health care problem in Australia? Is the anti-smoking campaign likely to become State-wide in New South Wales because of the 10 per cent decrease in the number of smokers in the area where the campaign was active between 1978 and 1980, despite intensive pro-smoking propaganda by the cigarette industry? Will the Minister indicate whether this important preventive health campaign might be adopted nation-wide under the auspices of the Federal Department of Health? Would the likely savings in health costs to the community as a result of such a campaign be about $150m a year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen newspaper reports this morning which refer to the campaign conducted in Lismore. I understand it was called the North Coast Healthy Lifestyle Program. I understand it had as its slogan 'Quit for Life'. It is true that it is the first campaign of its size or professionalism conducted in this country. The Commonwealth has contributed $260,000 towards assessing the effectiveness of the North Coast Healthy Lifestyle Program which was concerned not only with smoking but also with drugs, exercise, diet, stress and other factors. The results on smoking are the first to come from the campaign and they are most encouraging results. They seem to indicate that active intervention can alter smoking habits.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has already indicated its commitment to a national initiative in health promotion by allocating $500,000 last year to a pilot campaign aimed at raising general community awareness of health issues. It has committed itself to a further $500,000 for the same purpose. The Government is currently considering the way in which it might further contribute to health promotion from a national perspective. The Government certainly will be taking note of the success claimed for the North Coast anti-smoking initiative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. In view of the Minister's apparent belief that the Rundle project may proceed into the full production phase without a pilot plant, can the Minister name any other multi-billion dollar project anywhere in the world which has commenced without a pilot plant? I ask him why the Prime Minister, on 28 February and 2 March last year, said:

QUESTION.PARA: If the pilot is successful, the partners expect to expand production progressively to the desposit's full potential of 200,000 barrels per day.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —From memory, Rheinbraun, the West German brown coal company of world renown, intends to proceed in the Latrobe Valley without a pilot plant. In other words, having done laboratory tests, it intends to proceed. That is my understanding. That is one that comes immediately to hand. It may very well be that there are quite a number of others. I will seek them out. As I understand it, the pilot plant was designed primarily to test a number of different kinds of retorts for the baking of shale. There is a Lurgi type of retort. Then there is a circular grate type of retort called superior.

ANSWER.PARA: My understanding is that the pilot plant was to undertake experiments as to which was the better type of plant. I understand that for the moment the circular grate plant is in some difficulty because of legal action. That may limit it. The intention in the first place was to proceed in the belief that the pilot plant would be relatively cheap. It has now apparently been discovered that it would be expensive, and the developers are now looking to ascertain whether they can go directly commercial. I have indicated what I believe to be one significant parallel. I will seek out others and let Senator Colston know.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RETURN OF PARCELS FROM SOVIET UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs noted a newspaper item alleging that about 2,000 parcels containing clothing and other personal belongings from the estates of Russians who died in Australia have been banned from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and returned to Australia at considerable cost to the senders? Is the Minister aware of any explanation for this action? If not, will the Minister ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs to obtain from the USSR Embassy an explanation of the reasons for the return of these parcels and, if necessary, issue a statement warning prospective senders of similar parcels to the USSR to save them unnecessary expense?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have any information about parcels that have been returned in the manner outlined by Senator Lajovic. As he requested, I will refer the matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to ascertain what information is available and whether any statement would be appropriate. If there is further information on this matter I will see that the honourable senator is advised of it.

—Did the Minister for National Development and Energy say last night that he was confident that moderate new supplies of oil would be found in Bass Strait and elsewhere? Does he recall saying a week before the last Federal election that domestic oil production was unlikely to be offset by any new finds? How does he reconcile those two statements?

—I have never said that domestic oil supply was unlikely to be offset by new finds. I have said that the advice from geologists in Australia is that it is unlikely that finds of the size of those in Bass Strait will occur again in Australia but that there is an 80 per cent chance of making moderate finds of oil in Australia. I am happy to say that, whereas the advice some months ago was that self-sufficiency of oil supplies from Bass Strait, Barrow Island and Moonie might decline from 67 per cent to, say, 50 per cent in five years time, 45 per cent or 40 per cent in 10 years time and 20 per cent by the turn of the century, the companies are now advising that there is a likelihood that that decline will flatten out appreciably and that, taking into account that the pipeline from the Cooper Basin to Whyalla will be in position in about three years time, there is some encouragement that moderate additional supplies of oil will be available for the rest of this decade. Indeed, the pressure of our import parity pricing policy is such that we are now achieving what we aimed to achieve-we are finding more small deposits of oil. Of course, every extra deposit of oil helps Australia's future.

—Is the Minister representing both the Minister for Industry and Commerce and the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that Professor Milton Friedman has indicated that it is his belief that there is a direct relationship in Australia between falling immigration in the 1970s and rising unemployment, pointing out that unemployment increased enormously after-I repeat 'after'-the Labor Government deliberately reduced immigration? Does the Minister agree with Professor Friedman that immigration provided some fluidity to the Australian labour market, which lacks mobility because of its highly centralised wage fixation process, and that that lack of mobility is helping to keep up unemployment numbers? In his capacity as the representative of the Minister for Industrial Relations, can the Minister say whether the Government is giving any consideration to unfixing this centralised wage fixing process which is so hindering labour mobility in Australia? In his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, can he say whether the Government is giving consideration to increasing the number of immigrants to Australia in order to restore some fluidity to the Australian labour market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has asked a series of questions which, in my view, are exceedingly complex. As a matter of fact, I think it is true that if one looks at the post-war history of Australia, during the period of high migration which commenced--
—Who started immigration, Senator?

—I was about to refer to the period of high migration which commenced under the Labor Government and was continued with great enthusiasm by the Menzies Government and following governments. During the whole of that period of a high level of immigration, it is true that there were very low rates of unemployment in this country. It is also true that world wide among the Western economies general levels of unemployment were lower than they are today, as were the levels of inflation. So I would be reluctant to draw too close a link between the high level of immigration and the low level of unemployment, although it seems a clear historical fact that post-war migrants played a very large part in Australian development during that period. They played their part, indeed more than their part, in manning some of the more difficult areas of Australian industry and some of the more difficult parts of Australia. I think all Australians would acknowledge that.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the particular questions raised by the honourable senator, with regard to the intention of the Minister for Industrial Relations to do something to unfix the central wage fixing system, I think it is well known to all honourable senators that, quite unlike other countries, Australia has a very long tradition of the arbitration authorities playing a major role in wage fixing. I think it is unlikely that that role will be removed, but I will refer the matter to the Minister for a more authoritative reply than I am able to give without notice.

With regard to our future immigration policy, no doubt that will have to take into account a number of matters-certainly Australia's own requirements and certainly factors of family reunion. However, I do not represent the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in this place and I will therefore refer that part of the honourable senator's question to the Minister for reply. I should like to say that, as far as I am concerned, one of the interesting facets of being a representative politician in this country is the large number of people coming to my office who are temporary visitors in the country and who wish to stay permanently. One of the points they make is what great opportunities there are for people in Australia compared with opportunities in their countries of origin. I do not know whether honourable senators opposite have that experience. I have to say that it has been my regular experience over these recent years of difficult employment in this country to meet people who wish to stay because they see this as a country of great opportunity. I share that optimistic view of this country, and the very large number of people from overseas who apply annually to come here is an indication of what a very good place Australia is to live in. I think that we in this place ought to be prepared to acknowledge that and be thankful for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Did his Department advise him of the technical problems which have now been revealed by Esso regarding the utilisation of the Rundle shale oil deposits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Department and I have been closely in touch with the developments. I visited Gladstone on 18 February this year to look at the overall position of a resource boom town, including its smelters and coal ports. I took the opportunity to look at Rundle and to ask for an updated briefing. In the course of that updated briefing I was told that there was in progress a significant reappraisal because of certain engineering and cost difficulties.

ANSWER.PARA: I reported this to the Government and the Government communicated with Esso and the other partners, indicating to them that as soon as they had their appraisal completed they should notify it to the Australian people. We have made a number of contacts with them in the course of the last six weeks, the aim being that-they had to be in touch, of course, with their American co-partners and their technical people-just as soon as they reached an appraisal based on technical knowledge that was to be announced. The first time I was aware that there was likely to be a major reappraisal was 18 February and I reported that to the Government then. It has been our aim since then to urge the companies concerned to reach their reappraisal as fast as possible so that the public would know. I am happy to say that that has been achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. There is increasing concern in the Northern Territory community that Telecom Australia is not delivering the goods. It is felt that the reason for this is the fact that Telecom, while still being administered by the South Australian section, is not progressing to align its administration with developments in the Northern Territory, particularly since the inauguration of responsible self-government. Will the Minister undertake to review Telecom's management of the Northern Territory with a view to placing Northern Territory administration in direct contact with Telecom's central administrative offices to ensure an efficient and productive operation in the Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Territory presents particular difficulties in the provision of telecommunication services. I understand that, although the total area of the Northern Territory is large and as a consequence there are management problems, there are at the present time approximately 22,500 subscribers, of whom 15,000 are actually located in Darwin. I understand that applications for services involving new plant this year will number about 5,500. In recognition of the problems facing the Territory, as set out in the honourable senator's question, and particularly of the problems in serving the outback areas of the Territory, Telecom Australia recently commissioned an independent study of the telecommunication needs of the Territory and of the telecommunication needs of remote and sparsely populated areas of other parts of Australia. As a result of this study Telecom now has a detailed picture of the needs of these areas.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that 44,000 Australians in remote areas do not have access to modern telecommunications. I am reminded that Senator Ryan drew this matter to my attention late last year in relation to some other matters which she raised in this place. Planning for the extension of services to very remote areas is being undertaken. It emerges that conventional wire services in most cases are precluded, and Telecom is therefore evaluating a couple of systems, one of which will involve the use of satellites when a national satellite system is available. Comparative cost evaluations will be made to determine which among those is the most appropriate means for providing services.

I am also advised that Telecom currently has a district telecommunications manager in Darwin who is responsible for the whole of the Territory. This is something which concerns the honourable senator who asked the question and who represents the Northern Territory. This district telecommunications manager is supported by a strong engineering group headed by a supervising engineer. The district manager reports to the State manager in South Australia. Telecom has looked into the need for establishing a separate administration in the Northern Territory. At this stage of the Territory's economic and social development, Telecom feels that the additional administrative overheads in setting up a full State-like administration could not be justified. The honourable senator can rest assured, however, that Telecom is fully aware of the very high growth rates in the Northern Territory, of the developments which are occurring through both the exploitation of the Territory's mineral resources and tourism, and that these will continue to put pressure on the telecommunications system. Telecom will continue to review frequently the appropriateness of the Telecom central planning and administrative functions for the Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, follows the answer which he gave to Senator Button earlier this afternoon. Will the Minister confer with the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade and Resources? In particular, will he ask the Prime Minister whether he still believes his statement of 2 March last year in which he said that Rundle could become one of Australia's greatest industries and that it had become possible only because of the Government's oil pricing policies? In view of the Minister's answer today to Senator Button in which the Minister said he advised caution on the Rundle project, is he not saying that it is the Prime Minister who has misled Australia on this project? Further, will he ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether he still believes, as he said in February last year, that Australia has enough shale oil to last 12,000 years? Does the Minister not see some contradiction in the Prime Minister's statement and his own statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see no contradiction at all. The fact of the matter is that oil shale has been developed, and developed commercially, throughout the world. In fact, in some parts of the world, including Germany, some 40 years ago it was developed and developed commercially. The fact that it can be developed and can produce oil is known scientifically. Equally, it is known that in Australia there are very large potential supplies of shale. My notes of caution and cautious optimism were directed to the fact that in the course of the development of any mining venture there are necessarily reappraisals, reassessments of the nature of the venture. I have always indicated the strong hope, and indeed, belief that oil shale undertakings in Australia will succeed, that they will be massive in size and that they will contribute very significantly as from the last decade of this century towards meeting our hydrocarbon needs. Basically that remains absolutely unchanged. The Prime Minister was expressing a belief, a well-based belief, that an oil shale industry would be a large industry, that its investment as such would be of massive size and indeed that the kind of investment contemplated would be larger than that in the North West Shelf. Therefore, the Prime Minister was stating factual figures.

ANSWER.PARA: I have replied in this Senate to the question regarding the Deputy Prime Minister. He was in fact referring not to what are known as the economic proven reserves but to the known reserves of shale. It is true that Australia is blessed with huge reserves of shale. What is necessary is to prove up the economic proven reserves; that is, those that may be used now. For instance, Australia has massive supplies of coal. The important thing to know is where is the coal that economically can be won now. So his figures were figures related to reserves as such and not to proven or economic reserves. I find no contradiction.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory. Is the construction of the National Gallery on time and within budget?
—I have no information on that matter. I will have to refer it to the Minister for the Capital Territory to obtain a reply.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Will the Minister comment on the information contained in sections 24 and 25 of the 1980 annual report of the Aboriginal Land Commisioner, Mr Justice Toohey? Why did the Minister exclude from the grant of land to the Aboriginal Land Trust five square miles at Mudbura whilst the Commissioner's report recommended the exclusion of only one square mile? Did the Minister make his decision on material or submissions that were not available to the Commissioner at the time of his hearing this land rights claim? If so, what other material or submissions were available and who made them available? As the Commissioner's recommendation for exclusion was based on material produced by the Northern Territory Department of Primary Production that one square mile was sufficient exclusion to provide a general stock reserve or for quarantine purposes, is the exclusion by the Minister of a greater area to provide land for other than stock reserves or quarantine purposes?

—I think I should indicate to the Senate that the process which follows a report by the Land Commissioner is a fairly long one. The Land Commissioner makes a report after he has heard a land claim, after which the report is sent to the Northern Territory Government for its comments. The Minister then makes a determination and appropriate action is then put--
—Who decides? The Commissioner or the Northern Territory Government?

—Mr President, if the honourable senator will let me continue-appropriate action is then put in train for the Governor-General to make a grant of title, and so it goes. The action to which the honourable senator has referred was taken before I became Minister. It was taken by a previous Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I will need to examine the particular matters to which the honourable senator has referred. They did not occur during my period as Minister. I will undertake to try to get him the answers which he has sought.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 31 March Senator Sim asked about reports of the use of chemical weapons in Indo-China. The Government has noted with concern reports of the use of chemical weapons in the conflict in Indo-China. We have taken a close interest in the consideration of this subject in disarmament forums such as the United Nations General Assembly and the Committee on Disarmament. At last year's Thirty-fifth Session of the United Nations General Assembly Australia co-sponsored the resolution referred to by the honourable senator, proposing an impartial investigation to ascertain the facts pertaining to allegations of the use of chemical weapons. It is expected that the group of experts appointed under the terms of that resolution will commence its work shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia supports current international efforts to reach agreement on a convention banning the development, stockpiling and use of chemical weapons and incorporating effective verification measures to ensure compliance with its provisions. Australian representatives at international conferences have been working actively to achieve this aim.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March Senator Colston asked a question without notice about delays in processing applications for invalid pensions in Queensland. He raised the matter again last week. I undertook to expedite a reply. The position which he has raised is not very satisfactory. I am advised that over 700 invalid pension claims have been awaiting medical examination in Queensland for over two months. I have been advised by the Minister for Health that the total time lapse between the initial lodgment of an application with my Department and the vetting of that application by a senior medical officer in the Brisbane office of his Department and its return to my Department for final decision is about three months. This time factor is made up as follows: Time to secure an appointment for examination of the applicant by a Commonwealth Medical Officer varies from a few days to up to three weeks. Due to arrears of work, about nine weeks are required by the Department of Health to process a case from the time it is received from a regional office of my Department to the time it is returned to that office for determination. This time can be affected on occasions by the need to refer the application form back to the examining Commonwealth Medical Officer for completion so that an informed opinion can be reached. If a specialist opinion is needed an additional period of up to four weeks may be required to secure an appointment and for the specialist's report to reach the senior medical officer of my Department.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister has advised me that the many calls made on the services of medical officers in the Department of Health and by various departments and Commonwealth authorities necessitate priorities to be accorded from time to time. Nevertheless, the Director of Health, Brisbane, has advised that he has already taken action to overcome the present backlog of invalid pension applications waiting to be processed. Depending upon the availability of extra staff this will ensure that future delays in dealing with these cases are kept to a minimum. It should be noted, of course, that people awaiting a decision on whether they are eligible for invalid pension are almost certainly in receipt of some other benefit-usually sickness benefit-and that no-one should be experiencing hardship as a result of the delays. If Senator Colston is aware of any people experiencing hardship because of the delay he should refer them to me or my Department to see what assistance can be given. That is consistent with the view which I took in respect of the delays in appeals which have also been raised in this chamber. A direction was given to the Department that no-one was to suffer by reason of the delay.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MEDICAL BENEFITS SCHEDULE: COSMETIC SURGERY EXCLUSION

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 Senator Chipp asked a question regarding the restrictions on medical benefits for cosmetic surgery. The Minister for Health has advised me as follows: It is appreciated that any decisions to restrict medical benefits will provide some difficulties to patients contemplating treatment to which the restrictions apply. As regards the restrictions on certain cosmetic surgery items, the Minister for Health foreshadowed in his address to the Sixth Australian Medical Congress in Launceston on 12 February 1981 that the Government was considering the matter. He further stated that he would announce shortly a decision on medical benefits for cosmetic surgery. This statement was given considerable publicity in the Press.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator mentioned the purchase by patients of surgical implants, that is prostheses, prior to 1 April. Such expenses are, of course, not covered by items in the medical benefits schedule and the restricting of benefits for cosmetic surgery from 1 April 1981 has no effect in relation to those items.

The cosmetic surgery items have been removed from only the medical benefits schedule and therefore hospital benefits continue to be applicable to these services. The question of restriction of hospital benefits for these services has not been considered. In the examples quoted by the honourable senator, that is, the removal of a disfiguring facial birthmark or certain hair transplants-other than punch grafts-medical benefits will continue to be attracted. The restrictions apply only to breast augmentations for cosmetic purposes, facelifts, eyelid reductions and punch grafts of hair. The decision to restrict payment of benefit for them is in line with the general philosophy that medical benefits shall apply only to medical services reasonably required for medical treatment. It is considered the operations mentioned are carried out primarily for purely cosmetic purposes.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government's energy strategy, as illustrated by the shelving of the Rundle project.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government's energy strategy, as illustrated by the shelving of the Rundle project.

On 9 October last year the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) described the Rundle project as 'a classic example' of the success of the Government's energy policies. That was in an address to the National Press Club. Since February 1981 he, as Minister for National Development and Energy, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) and other Ministers in the present Government have consistently talked up two speculative stocks associated with the Rundle project, namely Central Pacific Minerals NL and Southern Pacific Petroleum NL. During Question Time today Senator Carrick, sensitive about that allegation, pointed to his answer on 15 May last year, which he said indicated that he was not concerned to talk up the viability of the Rundle project in the interests of those two companies. I refer him to another passage of the answer he gave on 15 May 1980. He talked about the two companies and Esso Australia Ltd. He stated:

On a moment's reflection one would reach the conclusion that co-partners do not go into a venture and commit billions of dollars in capital unless they are convinced of commercial viability. With a little reflection one would reach that conclusion on this situation.
Senator Carrick went on to talk about Exxon's involvement and concluded with this statement:

Dr David, the technical and research vice-president of Exxon, yesterday assured me that the most conservative judgment amongst all his technical advisers is that Rundle is commercially viable through to refining.

That statement was made in May last year. Numerous other statements were made by Government Ministers about the Rundle project and the whole effect of them has been to make Rundle the linchpin of the Government's energy strategy, and, judging from the way Ministers have talked about it almost the linchpin of the Government's employment strategy. Rundle has been the flagship of all these projects which will employ so many thousands of Australians. Figures have been cited for the number of people it has been estimated will be employed at Rundle.

Of course what the Government is now concerned to do is to miss deliberately the point of what has been said by Ministers over a period of 12 to 18 months. What has been said by Ministers over that period of 12 to 18 months is that in approximately 10 years time the energy balance, as it is called in Australia, will be upset; that Bass Strait oil production, as the Prime Minister has said continually, will be running down and Rundle it is said will step into the breach, will come on stream, as that process in relation to Bass Strait oil happens. I have a bundle of documents here but I will not refer to them all. These are some of the headlines relating to statements made by Ministers about the Rundle project: 'Bonanza in shale oil-Enough to last 12,000 years, Anthony says'; 'Carrick gives guarantees'; 'We need four Rundles'; and so on. Such statements appear not only in Press statements but also in media releases on a number of occasions by the Prime Minister estimating the number which will be employed, the effect of the program and so on by the mid-1980s. I quote from a Press release, for example, by the Prime Minister in February last year in which he said:
Production from Rundle could be particularly important to Australia as current projections show that output from Bass Strait will decline progressively from the mid 1980s.

Time and time again Ministers in this Government have been talking about the decline of Bass Strait oil and about Rundle being the solution to all these problems. Of course that is a typically desperate sort of debating point adopted by this Government time and time again. It is a classic sort of situation. Unemployment will go away under a Fraser Government, we were told in 1975 and 1977. But when it does not look like going away we are told: 'Aha! The resources boom has arrived; that will get rid of unemployment in Australia'. Fuel energy resources in Bass Strait are running down we are told, and in the same way we are told, as they run down: 'Aha! What do we have here-Rundle. Rundle will solve our problems in relation to energy policy'. The dreadful thing about this is that it is indicative not only of no real policy and no real alternatives but also of a chronic capacity to try to mislead people about the nature of the Government's activities. The result of the talking up of speculative stocks in relation to Rundle is that investors in Australia yesterday lost $57m as a result of shares bought, with encouragement from Ministers in the Fraser Government. They lost $57m. Many of them were the poor little people whom this Government pretends to be so concerned about and in respect of whom it says: 'Look, market forces will look after these people. They are the things which operate in the best interests of people in this community'. Last week $16.4m was earned by a company in a share raid-tax free, we understand. Is that the sort of society which we feel is a just one? What did anybody in this country do to earn $16.4m in one day? Was he a very clever man, of enormous ability, that he was able to do that sort of thing? What about the people who bought shares in the Rundle partners as a result of the encouragement of this Government? The fact is that the fuel and energy policies of the Government are in ruins as a result of a decision made elsewhere in the last few days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, Senator!

—We will hear from Senator Young, with his usual wisdom, in time. The fact is that due to the absence of alternatives and options, the fuel and energy policies of this Government are in ruins because Rundle was made, by excessively vociferous and excessively talkative Ministers, the linchpin of the Government's energy policy. The results are, as I have said, that thousands of small investors have lost money. The confidence of overseas and local investors is shattered by the connivance of the Government with the companies in question. The question which has been posed to Government Ministers is: 'Where are our fuel resources coming from after 1980? How will we correct the imbalance of energy supply which will arise?' The answer has always been Rundle. On 11 February 1980 Mr Anthony referred to the enormous resources of shale oil in Australia. On 3 March 1980 the Prime Minister said of the Esso company's participation with the two companies Southern Pacific Petroleum and Central Pacific Minerals:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . signals the start of what may well become one of Australia's greatest industries. Of particular interest is the role played by the Government's oil pricing policies in making the Rundle development possible.

This is true enough. On 8 October 1980 Senator Carrick said that declining domestic oil production was unlikely to be offset by any major new finds. Last night he said, of course, that he was confident that moderate supplies of oil would now be found in Bass Strait and elsewhere. He went on to say:

If Australia is to meet its energy balance within the decade we would need to have functioning by the end of the decade three or four enterprises about the size of the Rundle shale oil project. I have no doubt that in the next 12 months in Australia some coal liquefaction projects will be under construction.

The matter was regarded as so important that the Prime Minister even took it upon himself to announce that Esso was to join the Rundle partners. The Prime Minister talked incessantly, as did the Minister for National Development and Energy, before and during the last election campaign of Rundle in the most glowing terms. Of course, it is said here today by implication at Question Time that the Labor Party is a pack of Jonahs, that it is not concerned about the development of Australia and that it does not want any of these things. If the Labor Party said nothing about the Minister's failures and about the failures of this Government in respect of its energy policy we would be accused by the Government-properly so-of neglecting our duty as an Opposition. The Opposition simply is saying that in this field of energy policy as in almost every field of major government endeavour the Government has misled the people of this country by talking up projects-all sorts of pie in the sky dreams which the Government has-which are no real solution to the problems which this country faces. We say that unless the Government is able to talk in terms of reality about the issues and to offer alternatives to Rundle, in terms of energy policy, it has failed. That is the charge we make.

What is the real situation in regard to synthetic oil about which Senator Carrick suddenly started to talk with new enthusiasm today? One can look at brown coal conversion. A circus is being offered the people of Australia; it is a bread and circus job. Give them bread and circuses. The costs of brown coal conversion and the amounts of money involved are just enormous having regard to present technology. It would require about 160 million tonnes of coal to produce from brown coal oil equivalent to that of Bass Strait; it would be necessary to mine 260 million tonnes of material a year. This is roughly 10 times the size of the mining operation at Yallourn in Victoria or eight times the size of the mining operation at Mount Tom Price in Western Australia. It is about five times the existing total production of the State Electricity Commission of Victoria.

These are the sorts of figures which have to be considered. It is no good saying when Rundle seems to be going bad, 'We will look at brown coal conversion; that is the next panacea for the problems of our energy policy', without talking about those sorts of problems which are enormous. The mining of enormous tonnages of material each year would be required at Rundle to produce 200,000 barrels of oil. This is mining on a scale which has not been seen almost anywhere in the Western world up to this point. It has been said in relation to the announcement by the Rundle partners that they will go straight into production and not proceed with a pilot plant as they had announced. That is all very interesting but there are certain problems about that. The Esso-Central Pacific partners have already said that the cost of phase two of the project has escalated by a factor of three. By calling for a re-examination of the project they have all but said that in their view it is finished for the time being. Senator Carrick might debate that view and no doubt we will have an opportunity in a few months' time to debate it again. But bear in mind that we will remember what is said in this place today on this matter.

The Rundle partners are, in fact, again starting an investigation only. There is no intention of going ahead to develop Rundle at this stage. Of course, one of the reasons is that those partners have been pressing this Government for a very long time for very susbtantial contributions in terms of policies for the future and underwriting of the project which they would need before they would even consider going ahead with the project. It is an act of great irresponsibility, we believe, for the Government to hold out any hope that Rundle will go ahead in even the medium term. So what happens to the equation, the balance, of Australia's energy needs in the next ten years as stated by the Minister over and over again with the Rundle project being a key factor in that balance?

By identifying this Government so closely with Rundle-with the risks which it involves for shareholders, with the anticipations it has encouraged in others-and by pinning all future hopes on the Rundle project, the Minister has failed this country sadly. We have no coherent national fuel and energy policy. The failure of Rundle means that the Government has no oil policy. It is no good Senator Carrick telling us how many wells were drilled in 1975 or 1980 when answering questions about his own inadequacies in 1981. It is an interesting historical exercise which might give Senator Carrick a great sense of moral self-justification; it does nothing for the country in terms of knowing what our oil policy is. This Government has no coal policy and no natural gas policy. It has no liquefied petroleum gas policy. All those policies have been victims of the ad hoc attitudes of this Government. That applies to all the Government's thinking. In this instance, the Government again went for a simple, easy solution-one big project on which it could focus as a symbol, a flagship, of a lot of false dreams to fool the people as it did before last year's election.

I will make one or two points about what should be done in a constructive way at this stage. I argue that the production of synthetic fuels is premature at this stage. Of course, research and development are important in a pilot study. It might be feasible to get part of our fuel supply from synthetics produced from shale and coal by, say, 1995 and not 1985 as Government Ministers have said. At present at least eight synthetic oil projects are being studied. If they went ahead as planned they would cost enormous amounts, probably between $40 billion and $100 billion. It would cause economic chaos, massive environmental dislocation and enormous oversupply of oil if all those projects were, in fact, to go ahead. But the costs would be prohibitive. The fact that they could, in theory, go ahead is a stark illustration of the so-called energy policy of this so-called national Government. The State governments which exist at present could create this ridiculous situation.

So we say that there should be further encouragement of conventional oil exploration. As Senator Carrick virtually said last night, one new, major, oil field would be worth half a dozen Rundles to this country at present and within the next decade, which is the period we have been talking about. Conventional oil exploration could be encouraged, of course, by a continuation of import parity pricing which would provide more encouragement for new discoveries. It could be encouraged in a sensible way by the imposition of a profit-related secondary tax using some of this tax revenue to form a government hydrocarbons corporation to boost the search for oil. In that context we believe that if these things were done, we could afford to wait before going into synthetics.

But more important than anything else we need national co-ordination of oil policies. We should maximise utilisation of fuels already available in Australia which are underutilised such as natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas, coal and electricity. Australia is a gas-rich continent. We should substantially increase our known gas reserves. Although 80 per cent of the LPG we produce is now being exported it would help very much if it were used as transport fuel. In discussing this matter of public importance we are concerned with drawing attention to the knee-jerk responses of this approach of adopting a sort of linchpin program without adequate care as the centre of the Government's policy. The failure of that enterprise, as we see it, has led to the rug being pulled from under the Government's energy policies as a whole. We have a government which is always tempted to go for simplistic solutions. It has been sold a pup once again.
