The best thing we can do, of course, is to find another oil field because that is where our energy policies ought to be directed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter before this chamber seeks to indicate that because of some setbacks in Rundle there is a failure of the Government's overall energy strategy. I reject that entirely and will direct my attention to both the overall energy strategy and Rundle. It comes rather unhappily from an opposition leader who talks quite wrongly about governments talking up stocks to say that yesterday's statement means the shelving of the project. In other words, today we have seen a classic case of an Opposition leader setting out deliberately to denigrate a project upon whose success--
—It is dead.
—Did someone say: 'It is dead'?
—Yes.

—That is someone who is really trying to kill the stocks. Let Senator Button's argument die on his breath. Senator Button has set out-his front bencher, Senator Walsh, has indicated that they want this-to demolish the value of the stocks on the market. Be that on their heads. There was no such message in that notification by the companies yesterday. There was a reappraisal of whether they would by-pass a pilot plant and go on to a commercial plant. I cannot understand the un-Australian attitude of Australian Labor Party senators who want to kill a project just for their own mean-minded reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Australian energy policy. We live in a world which is consuming oil at twice the rate at which it is finding it. Australia gets most of its oil from Bass Strait. It is 67 per cent self-sufficient. It is falling away from that level and we must find substitutes and alternatives. This Government has put into place a total energy policy based on four premises. I invite the public and the Senate to examine them. We have a policy to provide energy self-sufficiency in the years and decades ahead based upon: Firstly, the conservation of all our fuels but specifically the petroleum fuels, the saving of fuels and the using of them more economically; secondly, the conversion away from oil to alternatives such as gas, electricity, coal and, overseas, uranium; thirdly, exploration in a massive way to find more oil and gas; and, fourthly, using synthetics, synthetic crudes, ethanol and other forms of power, be it solar or wind power, to fill the gap.

The test is: How is this succeeding? Let us examine this because here we have a red herring. The suggestion is that because Rundle has some difficulties, the program itself does not stand. The program has achieved, in conservation, a movement from an increase in oil stocks of 2 per cent to 3 per cent in 1978 to a decrease of 5 per cent in the current period-a fall of between 7 per cent and 8 per cent in the use of petroleum; in fact, till last year, a drop from some 662,000 barrels a day to below 630,000 barrels a day. Conservation is working, and working strongly. Talking of conservation, we have an arrangement with the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries to produce more fuel efficient vehicles. In two years those more fuel efficient vehicles will be saving 5 per cent of fuel. By 1987 they will be saving 12 per cent of fuel. Let everyone take note that by that policy alone by 1987 we will be saving 14 million barrels of gasoline fuel a day. This is part of the whole program.

We are building pipelines to facilitate a switch away from oil and liquefied petroleum gas. Let me recite some of these success stories. The Newcastle pipeline has a potential saving estimated to be three million barrels of oil a year after a five-year lead time; Canberra, 800,000 barrels a year after a five-year lead time; and Wagga, 136,000 barrels a year after a five-year lead time. All these pipelines are in the process of being built and getting into position. Since we are talking about the success of energy policies, let me say that the proposed pipeline from the North West Shelf to Perth, which will be in position in four years, will displace 28 million barrels of oil after year five. That is a 13 per cent or 14 per cent overall saving of total oil in Australia. We are being told that we do not have an energy policy. Here is a success story on its own, and it is the very start. Alongside the North West Shelf another great field has been found, near Barrow Island. Quite clearly there will be huge finds. To save oil we are also looking at pipelines in the Goulburn Valley.

We can move throughout Australia and we will find that step by step we are building pipelines which will provide for Australia a complete displacement of oil. By January 1983 the Cooper Basin pipeline will be from Cooper Basin to Whyalla. That pipeline will carry something like 35,000 barrels of liquids a day. Let me put it another way. It will carry nine million barrels a year of oil and LPG-of liquids-at the start. It has a capacity for 24 million barrels. Here is a story which is ignored. It is a story of displacement, a story of bringing more oil, gas, and liquids on stream. It is a story of very great achievement.

The Australian Labor Party wants to direct itself only to Rundle. I will come to Rundle in due course because I want to put into position the orchestration of the conservation policy which is working and which the International Energy Agency has acknowledged as being first class. Yesterday the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association conference, with a record attendance of delegates, acknowledged the huge success of the Government's energy policies in Australia. It paid tribute to the prime mover, the import parity pricing, and acknowledged the tremendous growth in exploration and the excitement that is happening in Australia. One would never guess this, from the Jeremiahs opposite. We have conservation. We have the conversion to smaller vehicles. The four-cylinder vehicles are coming in. We have the projected huge saving of 12 per cent of gasoline energy in seven years' time. We have the steady conversion towards LPG. This is not happening as fast as we would want, but we are urging more. There is evidence that there is movement now in automotive LPG. These are policies which give a price differential and which lead us to hope that in five years' time we will absorb not only what we export now but also the production from the Cooper Basin and the North West Shelf and that we will displace in automotive LPG some 14 per cent of gasoline used.

In Brisbane in very recent times the taxi industry has moved to 40 per cent LPG. The figure for Canberra is 90 per cent, and for Melbourne it is 80 per cent. This story is not told at all. The commercial use of LPG will move fast as more outlets are determined in the metropolitan areas, and as we produce more. Whether it is conservation by saving or whether it is conversion to other fuels, we are moving foward. I have given dramatic figures in relation to the saving of oil and how our policies are in place. Year by year we have that balance of self-sufficiency.

The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) was very sensitive when he came to exploration. Incidentally, it is important to remember what he said in his speech. He said that liquefaction of brown coal was no good, that it was too costly and could not happen. I think it is very important to keep in mind that the Labor Party has no policy on this matter. He said later that he thought synthetics were somewhat premature but they were on the way. His famous statement was that there must be further encouragement to seek oil. At Question Time today I had to remind the Senate of the Labor Party's policies in regard to seeking oil and how, when it came to office in 1972, there were 22 rigs in Australia and how, at the end of its three years in office, there was nothing working in Australia, and how exploration had fled Australia. This is the Opposition which is suggesting that its one solution is to encourage the finding of more oil.

I reminded the Senate at Question Time today that only 25 exploration wells were drilled in 1975 by a Labor government. Eighty wells were drilled last year and 137 this year under a Fraser Liberal government. I reminded the Senate that in 1975 a total expenditure of $145m was made on exploration and development. That figure had risen to $780m last year and to $1400m this year. Yet the Labor Party has the effrontery to suggest that it would could manage exploration. If ever there were a total failure, that was it. When I turn to the number of active explorers in Australia in 1975, I could count them on one hand. At that time only 112 applications were on issue. Today there are 300 permits on issue and hundreds of exploration companies in Australia. This year will be a record year. It will be an exciting period of exploration. The exploration industry acknowledges that this is happening because of the import parity pricing policies of this Government. It is happening here in this situation.

We are also putting large sums of money into solar energy research. We are working with overseas corporations in the development of solar energy. Our program is that by the turn of the century, in twenty years time, eight per cent of energy in Australia will be achieved by solar energy. We are developing wind power. We have many projects running on ethanol. We are looking towards the conversion of natural gas into methanol and thence into gasoline. All these things are running. I ask members of the Labor Party to look at the compendium of our research and development programs, which is some three inches high. They will see the vigour with which we are undertaking these programs and the direction the programs are taking. This compendium was commended by overseas countries as a first class undertaking. Now we come to the alternative situation, the need to have in the decades ahead alternative sources of oil-oil from coal and oil from shale. I ask honourable senators to bear in mind that Senator Button talked about three great principles. First of all, he talked about the shelving of the Rundle project. I will come to that later. That was a complete misstatement. Secondly, he said: 'You cannot liquefy brown coal. It is too dear and, in any case, synthetics are too premature'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that at all and you know it.

—If Senator Button asks me about the matter tomorrow at Question Time I will read the Hansard record. He saw the encouragement of oil exploration as the only course. Senator Button said that I had said, and I had said it, that if we were to have an energy balance for the long term future, by the turn of the decade we ought to have functioning in Australia three or four enterprises of the size of the Rundle project. I did say that. Indeed, Senator Button then proceeded to ignore the other projects in existence. He cannot but know, although he probably does not take much interest in the State from which he comes, that Rheinbraun signed an agreement with the Victorian Government on 25 November 1980 for a plant in Victoria for the development of oil from brown coal. Three stages were included in the signed agreement. The third stage involves the development and operation of a brown coal open cut mine requiring the dedication of some 1,200m tonnes of coal. It provides also for the planning, construction and operation of a plant which will provide three million tonnes per annum of liquid fuels from brown coal-an enterprise of the magnitude of the Rundle project. The agreement was signed and the stages spelt out. The Opposition believes it is an aberration. Perhaps the Opposition dismissed it because it believes brown coal is too dear. Rheinbraun, which perhaps leads the world in its knowledge and technology of coal, would be greatly invigorated to know that Senator Button, with his high technology, has a better knowledge than that company of handling coal liquefaction from brown coal. Perhaps Senator Button knows that West Germany has been doing this for 40 or 50 years. Of course, he conveniently ignored it.

SPEECH.PARA: Since we are talking about other companies, Senator Button ought to know of the Nippon Brown Coal Liquefaction Co., which signed an agreement with the Victorian Government on 8 December last year for co-operation in a pilot plant for the production of liquid fuels from Victorian brown coal in the Latrobe Valley. Time does not permit me to elaborate further. I move on to remind the Senate that Mitsui-CSR has set out-Senator Button acknowledges this-to undertake an SRC, or solvent refined coal, form of extraction. Senator Button made no mention of Gelliondale or Millmerran or any other enterprises or shale oil projects around Australia.

Now we have a situation in which the energy policy of Australia is queried. I have shown that by conservation, conversion, exploration and the potential putting in place of synthetics we have an orchestration. I have talked of the pipelines, the use of liquid petroleum gas and the whole thrust and parry of the situation. Senator Button did not mention any of these matters even though he said that, of course, the Rundle situation threatens the Government's energy policy. Of course it does not. Today I have talked about the fact that there is now more optimism that we will find moderate supplies of more oil. That is not sudden optimism by me. The producers themselves are displaying this optimism. Senator Button must be aware of the exciting discoveries of oil and gas around Australia. So many things are happening. I turn now to Rundle. Rundle, the frontrunner in synthetic fuels, ought to be encouraged by decent Australians and not destroyed. It will not be destroyed because it will beat the Jeremiahs of the Labor Party who want to see the project fail. What an extraordinary situation. Here in Australia we are hungry for oil but members of the Labor Party want to see this project fail. Surely, with the knowledge that the Exxon Corporation has great scientific ability and great integrity, honourable senators opposite must know that it will bring its scientific prowess to bear to make a success of the project, if success can be achieved. I would have thought that the Opposition would have been urging it on instead of attempting to destroy it. Of course, the fact is that we have in place now in Australia a capacity to produce and to maintain energy self-sufficiency well beyond this decade. We can in fact juggle the use of our various commodities such as our coal, electricity, gas and oil. We can put them together to get an energy balance. What a pity that the Jeremiahs are attempting to tear down and not build up. That is exactly what honourable senators opposite did in government. They are doing it in Opposition again with an equal degree of failure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick), like a Monty Python character, always looks on the bright side. For nearly two years he has been telling us that the solution to Australia's impending energy shortage, or energy balance as he insists on calling it, is in the Rundle project and similar projects. Now that the Rundle project has collapsed, for the foreseeable future anyway, Senator Carrick speaks as though the Government's oil conservation policy, as he likes to call it, has been so successful that Australia did not really need Rundle anyway. If he was not saying that I do not know what he was trying to say. Like the despots of old who used to behead runners who brought bad news, Senator Carrick holds the Australian Labor Party responsible for the failure of the Rundle project. According to Senator Carrick, the Labor Party is responsible for the failure of the Rundle project because it has pointed out the fact that the project has failed.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth, of course, as the matter of public importance states, is that the Government has no energy policy and never has had an energy policy. It has a fuel taxing policy which is one facet of its deficit dogma. The fuel taxing policy is supplemented by shameless beat-ups from Senator Carrick, Mr Lynch and Mr Fraser about the exciting prospects for energy replacement projects such as Rundle. This is reflected also, of course, in such august journals as the Stock Exchange Journal of Australia, which only three months ago was also beating up the prospects of the Rundle project. Senator Carrick has the audacity now to try to deny that he has in fact been beating up Rundle's prospects over the last couple of years. Like Senator Button, I have so much material in front of me that I can use only a fraction of it, but I will give a sample. In answer to a question about the economic viability of Rundle from Senator Wriedt on 14 May last year, Senator Carrick said:

If I may be allowed to answer, the whole question in this matter is whether Rundle will be commercially viable, that is, whether it will be commercially viable in producing oil or whether it will be commercially viable in producing oil refined stocks. That, of course, will depend entirely upon the pursuit in this community of import parity pricing.
The only reservation Senator Carrick had about the commercial viability of Rundle was the continuation of import parity pricing. He said that less than a year ago. He continued:
The basis of the partners' advice to the community of Australia was that the one basis of their viability in producing oil stocks for Australia would be the sustaining of import parity pricing.

On 14 May last year Senator Carrick said that the only thing that could stop the Rundle project, the only thing that could destroy its commercial viability or place it in jeopardy, was the discontinuation of import parity pricing. We have still got import parity pricing. We have not got Rundle. The Minister has the audacity to claim that he is not responsible for beating it up in the first place. Just in case it is thought that that was an isolated incident, the very next day, in response to a question from Senator Wriedt, Senator Carrick said something similar to what he said today. He said:

I am sorry that in what I think is one of the most exciting potential developments in Australia, there appears to be a tendency to denigrate this project on the part of the Opposition. The fact is that the future of Australia and the future of Australian jobs and the vocations for Australians depend very directly on our ability to produce petroleum energy. One of the main projects is Rundle.
At the end of the same answer he said:

Of course, any venture encounters risks along the journey. Dr David, the technical and research vice-president of Exxon, yesterday assured me that the most conservative judgment amongst all his technical advisers is that Rundle is commercially viable through to refining.

On 14 May Senator Carrick said, without any reservations, that the only thing that could stop Rundle going ahead was the discontinuance of import parity pricing; nothing was then said about the Opposition's destroying it after it was already dead. The next day he quoted an Exxon vice-president as saying that in his judgment there was no barrier to commercial viability. On 2 March last year the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said:

Esso's participation with Southern Pacific Petroleum and Central Pacific Minerals to develop Rundle's massive reserves of shale oil signals the start of what may well become one of Australia's greatest industries . . . If we had not adopted a realistic pricing policy for crude oil and instead allowed oil to be sold at an artificially low price, the plans for the development of the Rundle oil shale deposits could not have proceeded as they have . . . The Government has given a very high priority to the development of indigenous sources of liquid fuels and it is pleasing to note the success of these policies in this particular area.

On 6 July 1980 Senator Carrick, not to be outdone, issued a Press statement. It was probably issued by Laurie Power, like most of his Press statements, especially his highly political Press statements. The statement said, in part:

The Minister said that this was a most important forward step in what promised to be a great development project. Given current and expected future uncertainties about world oil supplies and the prospective run down in Bass Strait production towards the end of the decade, the development of alternative sources of liquid fuels is of immense importance . . . the companies' announcement was a further vindication of the Government's import parity pricing policy.

Not surprisingly, in response to that barrage of bullish pronouncements, newspaper headlines such as these were produced: 'Government endorses Rundle shale project'-the Australian Financial Review; 'Federal aid for Rundle project announced'-the Canberra Times; 'Fraser promises assistance'-the Australian Financial Review; 'PM backs shale oil extraction'-the Age; 'Rundle set for huge fuel boost'-the Brisbane Courier-Mail; 'Rundle a $2bn goer'-the Australian Financial Review; and 'Queensland's big oil boom'-the Australian. So they go on. It is not at all surprising that the bullish statements by Senator Carrick and the Prime Minister produced such a Press reaction.

Rundle was described on the radio this morning as the Poseidon of the 1980s, and well it might be with Senator Carrick and Mr Fraser playing the roles of Shierlaw and Hynam. What we do not know yet is who are the Burrills, the Joneses and the Crichton-Brownes. But it may be significant that questions asked by former Senator Wriedt on 21 May and 23 May last year were ducked by the Prime Minister. Senator Wriedt asked Senator Carrick whether he or any other Ministers had shares directly or indirectly in either of the Rundle partners. Senator Carrick said that he would refer the matter to the Prime Minister and then, to his very great credit, he answered:

But since, basically, I am the Minister for National Development and Energy and the one who relates directly to mines and energy, I simply say that I hold no shares at all, neither does my wife or family.

I am quite willing to accept Senator Carrick's assurance on that. But two days later nothing had been said about the other Ministers. Senator Wriedt asked Senator Carrick, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, another question on this matter. Senator Carrick gave a similar answer to that which he had given two days before-he said he would refer it to the Prime Minister. On that day, 23 May, there was inserted into the Hansard at page 2936 what purports to be the Prime Minister's answer. It is typical of the sorts of non-answers we get from the Prime Minister. It is typical of the arrogant disdain with which he treats this Parliament. The Prime Minister, through Senator Carrick, said:

All Ministers have made declarations of pecuniary interests in accordance with the arrangements referred to by the Deputy Prime Minister in his statement of 22 November 1979 on the Report of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest.

That may well be so; perhaps they have all made declarations. But what is disturbing about this Government, and what has been disturbing about it for many years, is that the public finds out about Ministers' conflicts of financial interests-the Government does not tell anybody about them and the Prime Minister does not do anything about them-only when they have been blown in the media. Did the Prime Minister know about Mr Lynch's Stumpy Gully land speculation activities? If he did, did he approve of them? The public was told nothing until the Age blew the story. We still have not been told by the Prime Minister whether he approved of them or whether he knew of them in advance. Incidentally, the public still has not been made privy to the report on the matter, contrary to the promises given by both Mr Fraser and Mr Lynch prior to the 1977 election. What we do know is that the procedures which this Prime Minister claims to have applied regarding ministerial conflict of interest or potential conflict of interest have not been satisfactory. The Prime Minister has been asked whether he knew about a former Minister's dividend stripping operations. He has ducked that question too. He has been asked whether he approves of the use of money which, on the Minister's own admission, was appropriated by his father as working capital for private businesses. He has dodged that question too; and he continues to dodge this one.

If no Ministers have interests directly or indirectly or through their families in either of the Rundle partners, why does the Prime Minister not say so? I have no evidence that they have such interests. I just note for the record, and I complain on behalf of the Opposition, that this Parliament, especially given the way in which these shares have been shamelessly beaten up over the last 18 months to two years by several Ministers in this Government, is entitled to know whether any Ministers have direct or indirect pecuniary interests in those companies. The gullible shareholders of the companies yesterday lost $57m. The market capitalisation of one of those firms fell by $57m. The shareholders are entitled to be angry at having been misled by the bullish pronouncements of numerous Ministers in this Government, of executives of Exxon and, of course, of the chairman of the two Australian companies, whose name, I think, is Mr McLennan. They are entitled to be extremely annoyed at having been misled by those bullish pronouncements into purchasing shares at what, it is now clear, were excessively high prices. While all this bullish activity was proceeding Senator Carrick was getting advice from his Department that there were quite serious technical problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—If the Minister was not getting it, the only reason he was not getting it was that his permanent head was not passing it on, because it was coming from further down. I can assure him of that.
—Then you should have disclosed it here.

—It would not have been much good my disclosing it here because the Minister told us today that he found out about it on 18 February, but in answer to a question from Senator Grimes on 11 March on whether he had given assurance to Japan that part of the production would be made available to the Japanese, he said, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: the Government has indicated that it accepts in principle the idea of product sharing but that each case must be considered on its merits and, until the actual industry is so defined that we can know what its product will be both in quality and quantity, no decisions can be made on the matter. As to the specific details of Senator Grimes' question, it is quite clear that the Australian market has to be fulfilled ahead of any others. The Rundle partners know that.

What is that? Three weeks after Senator Carrick acknowledged having been told about these technical problems there was not a word from him to the Parliament about these technical problems. There were no doubts at all cast on his previous open-ended assurances that the economic viability of this project was assured. Perhaps he did not remember it that day. On 26 March, in answer to a question from Senator MacLaren about Rundle, he stated:

My understanding is that at the moment there are discussions between the partners regarding any necessity to revise their estimates as to the volume of product output and the time of such production. Such an announcement has not yet been made.

Again there was not even a hint that the project was not commercially viable. It is not as though such information were not available. The Sydney Morning Herald of 15 March-before Senator Carrick answered that question-referred to Dr Barry Hughes of Flinders University, an economist of whom the Government could take more notice. It would be much better advised to absorb the economic analysis of Barry Hughes rather than the high tory dogma and the a priori reasoning of the Secretary to the Treasury. But on that occasion Barry Hughes said that on his calculations the cost of production of oil from Rundle was between $60 and $70 a barrel. Senator Carrick at that time was still saying it was between $40 and $50--

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never put a price on it.
—If that is correct he has been misreported because he is certainly reported here as having put that price on it.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —(New South Wales) (4.42)-Misconceptions about this Rundle shale matter are in every way regrettable-even tragic would not be an overstatement-and have done a great deal of damage already and, I suspect, will do a great deal more damage in the future. They will damage the Government's energy policy too because I cannot see, after what has happened to the shares in the Rundle twins, that many investors in Australia will again take much notice of what the Government says about the prospects for any enterprise in Australia in the future. That is tragic. Many statements which the Australian Democrats have made here in the last two years on energy I think should make it plain how great our concern is that there are other means of providing substitutes for motor spirit in Australia, if possible by the time the Bass Strait crude runs down. As we all know, that time is not very far off now-possibly another decade at best. Our key energy problem in this country is motor spirit. Let us be in no doubt about that. We are more dependent on motor spirit than is any other developed country. We do not have the railway systems, canals and things of that type to do without it so we have to have it. I raised this matter of Rundle in the Senate on 14 May 1980 in these words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . The gigantic Rundle shale fraud . . . has been presented to the Australian people as promising results it can never achieve. The way in which it has been presented as something which will solve the fuel problems of this country by the time our Bass Strait fuel is running down in 1985 is one of the most cynical, unpleasant pieces of deception that I have ever seen practised by a government on the people it is supposed to represent.
At that point Senator Wriedt interjected:
It is a fraud.
My remaining comments were these:
There is no doubt about it-the development is a fraud. Virtually everything that has been said about it is a pack of lies.
Not unnaturally, that evoked a response from Esso Australia Ltd, and as a result of that I wrote to Esso on 18 June of last year. I stated:

. . . I am concerned about the nature of the publicity Rundle has had in recent months and the resulting widely-held view among the public that as Bass Strait crude runs down Rundle shale oil will be there to solve all our problems.

It would be easy to say that this view was simplistic and ill-informed. The point is that public attitudes towards the whole energy problem, and the orderly assembly of a whole range of substitutes for petrol, especially as a transport fuel, is coloured by this kind of publicity. They are falsely reassured.
I asked a number of questions of Esso at that stage. I asked:
(i) What is a likely and feasible timetable for motor spirit production from Rundle on a significant scale, at prices competitive with other possibilities . . . ?
(ii) What cost per litre is considered feasible and on what basis?
(iii) What actual yield of
(a) oil, and
(b) motor spirit fractions
are likely from each ton of shale?
(iv) What power source is contemplated for mining, crushing and heat for extraction?
(v) How does this compare with the final energy product?
(vi) What actual capital cost is likely for the project, and on what basis? Figures as varying at 2 to 8 billions have been mentioned.
That was the case at that time. I went on to ask:
(vii) What amounts are budgeted to cover environment matters, especially rehabilitation of the land after stripmining, which does, of course, come rather expensive?
(viii) What water use is contemplated and where will the water come from?
(ix) What are the costs of extracting motor spirit from Rundle crude?
I went on to state:

My concern is that the Parliament and the public sees the project realistically and that indeed it is slotted reasonably to its proper place-especially in terms of timing-in a sensible overall energy policy.

To me, this view seems only prudent. There is also this consideration: If the public are primed for undue expectations about Rundle, and these are not realised, they may not be very pleased. You might have something resembling another Poseidon on your hands.

I wrote that letter to Esso nearly a year ago. The reply I received, I must say, was a considered and a fairly responsible one. It was considered and responsible to the effect that most of the questions I raised in fact were admitted as not being amenable to answer. Esso's letter to me states:

The figures you quote of eighteen to twenty years at best for Rundle oil to be at full capacity may therefore be somewhat pessimistic, although of course, there are substantial technological and other uncertainties associated with the project which could delay development.
This letter was written on 14 July 1980. It continues:

If we are able to meet the timing estimates outlined above, we would hope to have the first stage of Phase 2 of Rundle built and providing feedstock to Australian refineries by the early 1990's, so that Rundle should be making a very significant contribution to Australia's need for petrol during the 1990's. This again is somewhat earlier than your previous advice of the year 2000.
There is another point worth quoting from the Esso letter. It states:

We expect that Australians will not have to pay more for petrol refined from Rundle synthetic crude oil as the latter is expected to be priced competitively with imported crude oil. There should be no difference in the price of petrol to the consumer.

I mentioned that paragraph because it coincides, I think, entirely with what Senator Carrick said at that time. I remember asking him a question as to whether there would be any subsidies. He answered me by saying that indeed, Rundle would have to compete with synthetics and other things on the market. Esso went on to say:
We are unable to provide you with estimates of energy consumed during the process because of uncertainties mainly involved with hydrogenation.
That, of course, is the process of elevating the product to motor spirit. The letter continues:

We have not yet carried out any significant tests on how much of the project's gas output will be required to be converted to hydrogen for upgrading the raw liquids, and how much will be available for power generation or sale.

. . . Esso has made preliminary estimates which indicate that costs may be significantly greater. However, over the next two years, in-depth studies will be conducted which will define the scope of the project and its costs. Upon completion of these studies, SPP/CPM and Esso will be in a better position to provide definitive cost estimates.

. . . I agree entirely with you that the project should be seen realistically by the Government and the public, and we will certainly be working vigorously to accomplish this, especially as our own knowledge of the project improves over the next year or so. I might mention that as a first step, we are planning to conduct several half-day Rundle informational seminars in Brisbane, Gladstone and Canberra during August for interested Government staff to ensure they are as fully informed as possible on Rundle matters and that many previously misleading perceptions are clarified in a professional and responsible manner.

Unfortunately, those matters apparently were not clarified. That was on 14 June. According to figures in the Australian Financial Review, in August-only the following month-Central Pacific Minerals NL shares went up to $66 and Southern Pacific Petroleum NL shares went up to $23. At the end of September-I remember this circumstance very well, as will all honourable senators; this was only two or three weeks before the Federal election-everywhere I went I heard continual statements coming from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), Senator Carrick and Mr Anthony about Rundle and how much of a linchpin it was. I remember how big an electioneering point it was and how much was made of it. I think there is very little doubt of that. That month Central Pacific shares went to $76 on the Brisbane market. Southern Pacific shares went to $29.50. Then we had the election. After that, something happened. By October the shares of Central Pacific had dropped to $9.80 and the shares of Southern Pacific had dropped to $3.70. Obviously something happened at about that time, whatever it was, to affect the confidence of the market.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they split it up and formed shares six to one or something like that.

—That could make that extraordinary difference. Thank you very much for making that point. Nevertheless, Central Pacific shares are down to $3.50 and Southern Pacific shares are down to $1.35. The point is not so much what happened to the value of the shares subsequently, but the rise over that period. In January the shares were $4.50. They went up pretty slowly. By June they were $6.20 or $6.60. Then they went to $47 and then to $76. There was a remarkable increase in the price of those shares which coincided with the time that Rundle was being extolled by the Government for whatever reasons. Obviously, the development of Rundle was used in the election campaign because it was seen at least partially as being a central part of government energy policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats think that in view of the circumstances the Minister would be most unwise now to try to paint the prospects for Rundle in brighter colours than is justified. With all respect I suggest to the Minister that perhaps he feels he has a responsibility to the Australian public not to do that. Enough damage has already been done over this matter. Surely it is better not to have the situation dragged out and drawn on in some way in which the Australian public will feel that Rundle will still meet earlier expectations. This is not to say that it will not eventually be of value to this country. Of course it may be of value to this country. I would be the first to hope that it would be. It is essential, if there is to be any confidence at all by the public in the Government's energy policy and in investment in private enterprise, that people know over a period what they can invest in safely. I think perhaps it devolves on the Minister to get the facts as soon as he can and make a fully considered statement on how he sees the future of the Rundle project.

It seems to me from what I have read so far of the Esso statements which are reported in the Australian Financial Review of today in a fair degree of detail that the project, if it is going to be practicable at all, will not realise anything like the expectations that were predicted nor is it likely in any case to do so at an early date. That has been said pretty plainly by Esso and I do not think there is any reason for the Minister to say anything other than that. I do not think it is the time for reassurance to the public that Rundle is fine and has no problems. I do not think that is the case at all.

What we suggest is an urgent reappraisal of our energy program so that proven, known technology can be used to provide petroleum substitutes in Australia. The Minister and others in the Government are talking much these days about oil from coal projects. I suggest, on the information I have, if they go on doing so, that they may well be riding for another fall similar to the one they have had-and quite a tumble it has been-over the Rundle shale project. My advice is that there are grave problems about the conversion of very many Australian coals to oil, that these problems often cannot be predicted in advance and that indeed virtually a different process may be necessary in the conversion process for coal coming from different seams and areas in the same mine because of the peculiar qualities. There again we have to look with caution. Please do not let us have another Rundle shale debacle over oil from coal. I do not agree with the Labor Party that we can rely on finding another oil field. It would be great if we could, but as far as one can see and the best opinions one can derive show that we are not likely to be able to find another major oil field in this country. I wish we could, but we cannot depend on it in a country where we need motor spirit so much.

There is an area of great promise and I have raised it time and again in this Senate over the last three years and that is the conversion of methanol from natural gas, of which we have a great deal in Australia, along the lines that are being pursued by the New Zealand Government in the Maui field. The Minister has responded to questions that I have asked him from time to time by saying: 'We are looking at it'. How well are we looking at it? We have natural gas. It is a known technology. It can be costed. It can also be demonstrated to be very favourably priced in terms of the present imported cost of Middle East crude. Why are we not going ahead? Why do we not insist that the North West Shelf consortium and possibly our other gas people go ahead with the production of methanol along the lines of this technology so that at least we can get a 10 per cent additive to our fuel and we are covered to that extent? I would dearly like to know-perhaps Senator Young can tell me-why production of this sort which is being pushed all over the world, is being ignored in Australia and why we are dragging the chain when we know that time is against us so much in this matter.

I reiterate that it would be no wonder after the performance of the shares of the Rundle twins and the whole of the history of the project so far if Australian investors shied clear of energy developments in future. If the shares on Rundle were talked up it will be darn hard to talk up shares again on anything else, I think that is for sure. Then our Government will cry: 'We cannot get local investment. Local people will not invest in these sorts of things. We will have to go over to some foreign corporation'. What we need now is a respectable well-thought out energy program which takes into account all the areas of possible assistance to this country. None of these things alone-methanol, ethanol and oil from coal-can support us, but all of them put together may well provide us with a policy which will give us the means of providing ourselves with a reasonable quantity of motor spirit if some problem emerges. We could get a problem in the Middle East at any time, as we know. It could drop on us within a matter of months, weeks or days. I think we should be ready for it. We are not ready for it now. The Minister talks about conservation. I draw his attention to a report in today's Australian under the heading 'A waste of energy' in the 'Executive Suite' section. The article reads:
Is size important?
For company cars it apparently is.
Well-known motoring consultatnt, Peter Wherrett, put the latest dispute into gear at a dinner function--
Recently-
with . . . remarks about the staggering cost of motor vehicle fleet operating costs to the 50,000-odd Australian companies that operate them.
'Fleet buyers buy for all the wrong reasons', he said. 'Striking a deal seems more important than fuel economy; status is more important than efficiency'.
Only 5 per cent of fleet owners took effective cost efficiency action; 65 per cent had no cost control at all; 80 per cent were running inefficient and costly vehicle fleets; . . .
I commend that article to the Minister for his consideration and suggest that it is time we had a look at that and did something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —During this debate Senator Carrick, the Minister for National Development and Energy and the Leader of the Government in this place, has been accused by the Opposition of doing an oversell of Rundle. Certain quotes have been given in this chamber of answers or statements by the Minister. It is unfortunate that they have been very selective quotes. To counter the situation I will be selective by quoting some of the Minister's responses to questions asked in this place in regard to the Rundle oil shale project. On 4 March 1980-I repeat the date, 4 March 1980, which is quite some time ago-in answer to a question from Senator McIntosh from the Australian Labor Party the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the fact of the matter is that shale may well be there in those kinds of quantities but it becomes a viable resource only when it is known that in the capacity of technology and within the cost structure that is viable to us--
I emphasise the words 'it is known that in the capacity of technology and within the cost structure that is viable to us'-
It can be a usable resource.
Where in that statement is this oversell? The Minister went on:
At this moment oil shale in Australia has yet to be proved to be a usable resource . . . .
That was the Minister's statement on 4 March 1980. Let me move on to May 1980. Again, from the Minister, I quote:

'Australia is in a strong position to strengthen its domestic supply by developing the synthetic and crude oil resources. The initial emphasis we believe will be placed on shale oil which is close to being cost competitive at today's price for imported crude at $24.77 per barrel.

That is a quote from the report of Esso Australia. I emphasise that was the Esso report that the Minister was quoting; those words were not the Minister's. If those honourable senators opposite wish to challenge the Minister for doing an oversell or anybody else I suggest they should go out and challenge Esso. Let me refer to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 26 August 1980. He said, in his statement on energy policy and resource development:
Rundle is only one of several rich oil shale deposits. If it proves to be viable it will almost certainly lead the way in its technology--
I emphasise the words 'lead the way in its technology'; in other words, it would open up a new field in Australia-
in the development of a great new industry for Australia.

We hear only ifs. Having said that, let us look at the statements of the Labor Party that Rundle is a dead issue. The Labor Party has proposed this matter of public importance today in the following terms:
The failure of the Government's energy strategy, as illustrated by the shelving of the Rundle project.

In the Oxford Dictionary the definition of 'shelve' is 'To lay aside or defer consideration of'. Where in the statements by the Rundle consortium is it said that this project has been shelved or laid aside? It has not been deferred, nor has it been laid aside. It was stated in this morning's Press that the Rundle twin companies and Esso:

. . . wish to proceed with further work and plan to discuss a revised joint venture agreement that would permit such work to determine whether or not a project on a commercial scale is technically and economically viable and in what time frame.

Senator Mason picked up the point about the time frame. Nowhere in that statement did it say that the project had been deferred or put aside. The statement spelled out clearly that the consortium is doing a revision of the whole situation. The economics of the whole project will be dependent upon the results of the feasibility study-and the time slot-in other words the price of crude oil throughout the world at the time.

Why has the consortium come to this situation? Esso has already spent $30m in an inquiry into Rundle and as a result of that inquiry it has recommended a completely new plan of attack which will take in a lot more study of the physical problems encountered in the study. It has also said that in all probability, if feasible, it will by-pass a demonstration plant, which plant could have cost a terrific amount of money. Why has it made these statements? I would have thought that the Opposition would pick up these things in this morning's Press. They were spelled out clearly in this morning's Press. It dealt with the problems and the reasons why the consortium made yesterday's statement. It dealt with the geological problems, stating that a portion of the resource will be very difficult to extract. We have been given certain estimates of tonnages or barrels equivalent of oil, but now the companies have had to reduce that estimate in real terms because, after further inquiry, they now see a problem with regard to the mining of this resource.

I turn to the retort pilot tests. The companies have already indicated that the yields will be lower than those estimated in May 1980. They have also noted that they will have to upgrade the quality of the shale oil itself. That in itself means added problems, added costs. They have also said that the estimates for electricity and water costs have increased and that manpower requirements have also increased. Because of all these other cost considerations that have come to light as a result of the $30m feasibility study, it has been estimated that the cost of the total project could be tripled. So the capital costs could be as high as $10 billion. Of course, these costs have to be recouped, so they have to be related back to a price per barrel. I come back to the point made by Senator Mason. He said, not in the image of a Doomsday prophet-unlike members of the Labor Party-that he hopes that Rundle will be a viable proposition one day but that that will depend upon the price of crude oil at the time. We find that the estimates given in this morning's Press vary between $44 and $57 a barrel and no doubt we will see even higher estimates tomorrow. But we know that the estimate is already way above the current crude oil price based on the price of Saudi crude oil, which price applies under our import parity policy.

I wish to refer to the import parity policy. I wish to quote comments that were made early in the piece with regard to the Rundle project. Mr Schaefer of the Esso company was asked whether the project could have gone ahead without import or world parity oil pricing. When asked whether it was a Government pricing victory for a Government pricing policy, he said:
It's a victory if you like, but certainly it is true. Without todays and the projected prices for crude oil, the Rundle development would not be viable.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not viable now.

—I have just dealt with the projected prices for crude oil. The thing that has amazed me today is that the Opposition has seen fit virtually to slander the Minister, and to accuse the Government of an oversell. Opposition members have carried on with crocodile tears about the Rundle project. But would there ever have been a Rundle project in this country or would any company have been prepared to have spent some $30m in research if the Labor Party policies had been in operation or if we as a Government had listened to the Labor Party? Under Labor there would never have been an import parity pricing policy in this country. One can turn to so many other areas in which, had it not been for import parity pricing today we would not-I repeat 'not'-have had the alternative fuels that have been discussed in this place, be it ethanol, methanol, fuel from coal liquefaction or anything else. None of these things would be economically viable without import parity pricing. This is the crux of the whole situation in Australia today. We on this side are accused of not having an energy policy. Without import parity pricing, no policy that would lead to future development and expansion of resources in this country would be operative. I was interested to hear Senator Button, as I understood him, in answer to an interjection from Senator Carrick, say that it is no good talking about the number of wells drilled in 1975, as it is now 1981. He said that the best thing we could do would be to find another oil field and that that is where an energy policy should be directed.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the basis for encouragement for oil companies to explore for oil at present? There is only one basis-import parity pricing. I was at the Australian Petroleum Export Association conference in Adelaide yesterday. Over 1,000 delegates from Australia and overseas attended. When members of the Opposition talk about multi- national corporations, perhaps I should remind them that over three-quarters of the members of the executive of the APEA group are Australians. That is not a bad track record for an oil industry. Time and time again speakers at yesterday's conference made it perfectly clear that one of the greatest things that has happened this country to revive the enthusiasm that is evident in Australia is this Government's policy with regard to import parity pricing.

I hope that honourable senators will read the verbatim report of a speech given by one of the leading oil men in the United States of America from one of that country's biggest companies. I refer to a man by the name of Mr Grivetti. He was one of the lead speakers at yesterday's conference. Whilst he dealt principally with financing, he dealt with many other aspects also. He dealt with the probabilities and possibilities of finding more oil and gas, throughout the world and in Australia in particular. The one thing that he emphasised was that overseas companies have the expertise, the capacity, to explore. There are many countries to which they will not go today, even though they know that prospects for oil discovery are good. The risks involved are too great. He went on to say that, even though we may not find any more big deposits such as that at Bass Strait, even though we may never find in Australia deposits of oil as large as those in the North Sea, and even though we may not have major finds as large as some of those in Alberta or the Middle East, a lot more oil and gas will be found in this continent of Australia both on-shore and off-shore.

Mr Grivetti also said: 'Many companies will come here to help you find that oil and gas because Australia is a favoured country, because your Government is stable and because your policies are sensible. While governments give incentives to companies to come here and risk their money, companies will be prepared to take that risk, but while governments screw companies down, companies will not come here; they will go elsewhere because they must get a return on their risk and investment capital.' That was a very important statement for him to make. Other delegates at that conference, in particular two delegates from Canada, made it perfectly clear that they will look to Australia rather than to Canada to invest capital because the Canadian Government has become too tight with regard to the oil industry in that country. I think the bringing forward by the Opposition of this matter of public importance today was ill-timed. Not one basic argument has been propounded in this place. I support the Minister and all the statements he made today and the Government's policy. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
