DEBATE.TITLE: ANTARCTIC MARINE LIVING RESOURCES CONSERVATION BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Antarctic Marine Living Resources Conservation Bill 1981. If honourable senators are profoundly interested in this subject, I suggest that they read the Hansard of the House of Representatives where the subject was extensively dealt with by a number of speakers. In the course of my brief remarks I will make one or two points about the legislation. I wish, firstly, to say why we welcome it and, secondly, to point to one or two factors which ought to be considered in the future. For some time Australia has made a claim to a very significant portion of the Antarctic. Three-sevenths of the total area of the Antarctic is claimed by Australia. That represents an area equivalent to 6 million square kilometres. For some time Opposition spokesmen and indeed Government members have urged that in order to justify the extent of that claim to the Antarctic Australia should show a little more tangible interest in it than has been the case in the past. We should do a little more about asserting our interests. In that context it is not sufficient, in our view, to spend $55m as is now happening on the upgrading of the Antarctic bases, but it does require a somewhat greater presence and more particularly a greater research and development effort in the Antarctic than has been embarked upon to date.

SPEECH.PARA: Our claim to such a substantial area imposes on us obligations of a foreign policy kind. The resources of the Antarctic are probably potentially enormous in terms of food and a variety of resources which as yet we probably do not know enough about; we ought to know more. We, as a relatively rich and developed country-I emphasise the word 'relatively'-have I think a moral obligation in relation to the Antarctic. If the Law of the Sea Convention is ultimately passed we will have definite moral obligations in respect of other underdeveloped countries in South East Asia and their sharing in the resources of the Antarctic. It is important that from time to time we consider the importance of the Antarctic as a responsibility which we have in part assumed and that we do so in terms somewhat similar to the terms and spirit in which this treaty or convention is embraced in the context of this legislation. I refer the Senate to the principal point which the contracting parties undertook in connection with this Bill. The convention appears as a Schedule to the Bill and its primary aim is the conservation of Antarctic marine living resources. The Schedule refers to the undertakings of the contracting parties. It states:
Recognising the importance of safeguarding the environment and protecting the integrity of the ecosystem of the seas surrounding Antarctica;
Considering that it is essential to increase knowledge of the Antarctic marine ecosystem and its components so as to be able to base decisions on harvesting on sound scientific information;

The Schedule then sets out the terms of the convention. In the convention there is a lot of use of the expression 'rational use', an expression which is not defined. Perhaps that does not matter if policies are developed which display rational use of the living resources-that is, fish, birds, seals crustaceans, other animals-and the marine ecosystem. Many of the discussions which have taken place about this legislation have been devoted to the krill resources of the Antarctic area, their potential as a source of food in the future and the need for both research and development in relation to that matter as well as a number of other matters.

We welcome the Bill because it legislates for Australia to become an official member of the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources. I think that if we are not first, we are high in the pecking order in our acknowledgment of this convention. It is doubly welcome to Australia in the sense that the Commission's headquarters is to be established at Hobart. The most important point the Opposition would like to make about that is that the establishment of the headquarters at Hobart really imposes on Australia further ongoing obligations in relation to the degree of effort we make as a nation in Antarctica, a degree of effort not only in terms of the specific subject matter of this Bill, namely, marine living resources, but also in terms of research generally in Antarctica and the need to upgrade our research effort.

For those reasons, we believe that the step taken by this legislation is an important one, and it is welcome. It points us in the right direction, as it were, and more importantly, it points up the need for greater effort in this area if we are to honour both our foreign policy obligations and the moral obligations we take on by making such a large claim to Antarctic territory. Having said that, I wish this Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Antarctic Marine Living Resources Conservation Bill gives the Senate an opportunity to debate some of Australia's international responsibilities concerning the Antarctic. Debates on Antarctic matters tend to be extremely truncated in this place. The last debate we had on conservation of Antarctic resources occurred just before the Senate rose last May. A very important piece of legislation went through the Senate in a matter of a few minutes and did not give any opportunity for an exploration of the responsibilities Australia has taken on with regard to the Antarctic. In an historical sense, Australia's relationship with the Antarctic has been a particularly long one. The continent was first described by Captain Cook in an account of his voyages between 1772 and 1775, and at a later date Australian explorers were among the first in the Antarctic. It is interesting to note that on one of Sir Douglas Mawson's early expeditions to the Antarctic the first record was made of the fact that there were mineral deposits worth exploiting in the Antarctic, and that is a matter to which I shall return later.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1933 this Parliament passed the Australian Antarctic Territory Acceptance Act, which in section 2 states:

That part of the territory in the Antarctic seas which comprises all the islands and territories, other than Adelie Land, situated south of the 60th degree south latitude and lying between the 160th degree east longitude and the 45th degree east longitude, is hereby declared to be accepted by the Commonwealth as a Territory under the authority of the Commonwealth, by the name of the Australian Antarctic Territory.

That means that the responsibilities of the Commonwealth Government towards the Antarctic are precisely the same as its responsibilities towards any of its other external territories, or the Australian Capital Territory for that matter. By the passage of the Antarctic Treaty Act in 1960 Australia accepted certain international obligations, and the Schedule to that Act, the Antarctic Treaty, contains a number of very important provisions. For the purposes of this Bill, the most important of those provisions is to be found in Article IX, which indicates the principles and objectives of the treaty, including matters relating to the use of Antarctica for peaceful purposes only, the facilitation of scientific research in Antarctica, the facilitation of international scientific co-operation in Antarctica, the facilitation of the exercise of the rights of inspections provided for in Article VII of the treaty, questions relating to the exercise of jurisdiction in Antarctica, and the preservation and conservation of living resources in Antarctica. It is to sub-paragraph 1 (f) of Article IX, 'preservation and conservation of living resources in Antarctica', that this piece of legislation is directed. We have always asserted our territorial claims over that part of Antarctica described in the original acceptance treaty. During the second reading debate on the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Bill on 23 April 1980 the then Minister for Science and the Environment (Mr Thomson) spoke in the following terms:

The Antarctic Treaty is a cornerstone of international and Australian policies for Antarctica. Maintenance of Australia's sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic Territory is, of course, the other major consideration in our policy.
We have continued to reassert our sovereign claims. In an article on Antarctica, appearing in the Australian Foreign Affairs Review January 1981, under the sub-heading 'Sovereignty' it is stated:

Australia's claim rests upon discovery and formal taking of possession by the United Kingdom, and then a continuous display of Australian occupation and administration after passage of the Australian Antarctic Acceptance Act of 1933.

The Harries Committee on Australia's Relations with the Third World, which reported in September 1979, spent some time in its report 'Australia and the Third World' dealing with the question of the Antarctic. In relation to Australia's policy interests, it stated:
Our policy interests are:
(a) to maintain Antarctica as an area free from strategic and/or political confrontation;
(b) to provide adequate protection for the Antarctic environment, having regard both to its unique qualities and its possible effect on our own region;
(c) to take advantage of the unique opportunities the region offers for scientific research;
(d) to be informed and consulted about development in a region geographically proximate to Australia; and
(e) to derive, if possible, economic benefit from the living and non-living resources of the Australian Antarctic Territory.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard paragraphs 199 to 210 of the Harries report, which deal with the question of Antarctic policy.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
K: ANTARCTICA

199. Australian policy towards Antarctica is based on the premise that the region is an important one in which we have a history of involvement. As a consequence Australia has sought to maintain an adequate level of activity there and, as one of the twelve original signatories of the Antarctic Treaty of 1959, to have its position respected and its voice heard in international forums concerned with Antarctic affairs. Our policy interests are:
(a) to maintain Antarctica as an area free from strategic and/or political confrontation;
(b) to provide adequate protection for the Antarctic environment, having regard both to its unique qualities and its possible effect on our own region;
(c) to take advantage of the unique opportunities the region offers for scientific research;
(d) to be informed and consulted about development in a region geographically proximate to Australia; and
(e) to derive, if possible, economic benefit from the living and non-living resources of the Australian Antarctic Territory.
Australia has sought to protect these interests through policies directed towards:
(a) the maintenance of sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic Territory (AAT);
(b) the preservation of the Antarctic Treaty and the use of its consultative framework; and
(c) the maintenance of an Australian presence and the carrying out of a program of scientific research and exploration activity in the AAT.

International Interest in Antarctic Resources 200. The Antarctic Treaty contains no provisions specifically governing the exploitation of the resources of Antarctica. A significant recent development has been a growing international perception that the resources of Antarctica may be both accessible and rich, and a corresponding growth of interest in the possibility of their exploitation. Interest in Antarctic resources has been shown by United Nations bodies, particularly the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO).

201. The concern of some Third World countries that the Antarctic Treaty Parties may act soon to exploit the resources for their own benefit could precipitate proposals to internationalise Antarctica. The recognition of the 'common heritage' concept in relation to the deep sea-bed in the Law of the Sea Conference is likely to stimulate moves for application of a similar concept to Antarctica. There has already been evidence of such moves in both United Nations bodies and in the Non-Aligned Movement. These developments raise the basic questions of the longer term tenability of Australian sovereignty over the AAT; of the extent to which the maintenance of sovereignty over the AAT might jeopardise the continuance of the Antarctic Treaty, including its demilitarisation, peaceful uses and non-nuclearisation provisions; and of what arrangements in the Antarctic would best serve Australia's wider foreign policy interests, including our concern about our relations with the other Treaty Parties and the Third World.

202. Third World interest in the living resources of the Southern Ocean has been mentioned at recent meetings of the FAO Committee on Fisheries (COFI). Moves have been made in COFI, supported by Third World countries, to give COFI an active role in the management of the living resources of the Southern Ocean. These have been opposed by the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties on the grounds that, while FAO and COFI have an undeniably legitimate interest in the living marine resources of the Southern Ocean, their proper role is one of information-gathering and evaluation. Moreover, the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties have a demonstrable role in the management of Antarctica and are currently engaged in the preparation of a regime for the conservation (and therefore the responsible management) of Antarctica's marine living resources. In response to this, COFI has been prepared to modify its ambitions with regard to management. However, there is continuing pressure among the Third World countries in COFI and any failure or undue delay on the part of the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties to conclude a responsible regime for the living resources of the Southern Ocean will undoubtedly result in further moves to have COFI more involved in the management of the living marine resources of the Southern Ocean. To date, the Antarctic Treaty partners have also been successful in heading off other Third World initiatives, including those by Sri Lanka aimed at persuading the United Nations General Assembly to adopt a resolution for the internationalisation of Antarctica and that country's efforts in October 1976 to have included in the Declaration of the Non-Aligned Conference words to the effect that Antarctica was the common heritage of mankind. But it would seem likely that unless the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties can demonstrate a capacity to develop satisfactory resource regimes the dangers of Third World pressure building up will increase.

203. Australian policy must take account of the foregoing developments. However, other factors, which are difficult to assess, must also be taken into account. These include the outcome of the Law of the Sea Conference, the attitudes of the other Antarctic Treaty partners, the economic/technological feasibility of exploiting Antarctic resources, and whether international pressures will strengthen among Third World countries in such a way as to require any change in our policy. Nevertheless, three possible policy approaches can be identified. They are:

(a) Strict Adherence to Sovereignty 204. Australia has so far adopted the position in discussions among Treaty partners that nothing should be done in relation to the resources question which is not basically compatible with our sovereignty. This has been possible in the past because there has been little substantial discussion of resources in the Treaty context; such a position becomes harder to sustain as interest in resources grows.

205. The obvious advantage of a policy of strict adherence to sovereignty is that, if it were sustainable in political and enforcement terms, it would allow Australia to determine all aspects of the development of the AAT and its off-shore areas. We would be able to regulate exploitation, in the same way that we now regulate the mining industry in Australia. Such a policy would also meet our environmental interests by enabling us to impose our own standards and controls. However, in view of the very limited international recognition of our claim, there must be doubt as to whether it would be sustainable as it becomes feasible to exploit the resources in the region. At the least we would need to allow access on generous terms. If the sovereignty issue became contentious, we would have to consider whether the price, in terms of our international standing and broader political and economic interests and relations, would make a policy of strict adherence to sovereignty worthwhile. Such a policy would be seen by many developing countries as running counter to their ambitions; it could also run counter to the interests of the United States, the Soviet Union, Japan and other non-claimant Treaty Parties.

(b) Internationalisation 206. Another approach would be to accept the internationalisation of Antarctica if it is proposed, or, indeed, to promote it. The premises of this approach would be that Australia cannot hope successfully to assert exclusive control of the resources of the AAT and its off-shore area, that increasing Third World pressure is inevitable, that the Treaty itself, based as it is on a privileged position for twelve (now thirteen1) countries, will not provide a long-term solution, and that a new and comprehensive international regime for Antarctica can be established. Australia might therefore anticipate this situation through a bold and generous initiative to propose the internationalisation of Antarctica and the preservation of Antarctic resources for all mankind. Australia's acceptance or sponsorship of internationalisation, and our geographical position, might enable us to retain a measure of political influence and a share of economic benefits (including possible use of Australian bases or entrepot facilities) under any eventual international regime for Antarctic resource exploitation. But this is essentially conjectural and any international 'appreciation' might be shortlived. However, to the extent that internationalisation could prevent Antarctica from becoming a scene of international discord, our defence interests would be served. It might also be conjecture that such a policy would enhance Australia's international standing, particularly among the Third World, with consequent advantates in other areas of foreign interest.

207. Such an initiative, if successful, would, however, mean the end of Australian sovereignty over the AAT, and domestic political repercussions could be expected. It would be highly desirable-some might say a prerequisite-for there to be full consultation with out our Antarctic Treaty partners with the object of obtaining their agreement. We should, however, have no illusions that the other Treaty Powers would be likely to support such an approach; and we would incur the displeasure, and indeed the anger, of at least some of them, for advancing it. It would also mean giving up to the international community most of any economic benefits and the exclusive environmental controls which sovereignty, in theory, gives us. Whether the 'spin-off' Australia might derive from participating in an international regime for Antarctica would compensate, and whether international environmental controls would meet our requirements, could not be forecast at this stage.

(c) To Build on the Antarctic Treaty 208. Another course-and the course in fact followed in current policy-is to seek to work within the Antarctic Treaty framework to develop new regimes to handle resource questions, together with the related questions of conservation and protection of the environment. In pursuing this course our basic objective is to derive as many as possible of the benefits of sovereignty rights over resources, including the living marine resources within Australia's future 200 mile off-shore zone, without sacrificing our other policy objectives. In the context of the Treaty it is necessary to negotiate on the basis of sovereignty; but, in the recognition that the full exercise of sovereignty is unlikely to be sustainable, we have accepted that some flexibility is necessary in order to encourage others to participate with Australia in promoting mutually beneficial regimes for the exploitation of living resources and, at a later date, non-living resources.

209. The draft regime for Antarctic marine living resources, which is currently being negotiated by the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties, aims at the long-term conservation of these resources, thus ensuring their preservation as a future world food source. The establishment of such a regime by the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties can be presented as a responsible action taken in the broader interests of the international community.

210. The Committee has felt obliged to address itself to Australia's interest and policies in relation to Antarctica because they clearly have Third World dimensions which could become more important with time. However, it does not feel called upon to make any recommendation in terms of the options canvassed.
1 The thirteen Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties are Argentina, Australia, Chile, France, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, South Africa, the USSR, the United Kingdom and the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —The important thing to note is that the report indicated that one of Australia's policy interests should be to derive, if possible, economic benefits from the living and non-living resources of the Australian Antarctic Territory. It is important to understand that the peace and co-operation which so far have existed in Antarctica could well be set at risk if there is to be a major scramble at any future stage for the exploration and exploitation of mineral and especially hydrocarbon resources which may or may not be available in Antarctia, which may or may not be recoverable in Antarctica.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said something about the assertion of Australia's territorial sovereignty in the Antarctic, but I would not want it to be thought that this has gone without challenge. In an article by D. W. Greig entitled 'Territory Sovereignty and the Status of Antarctica' in Australian Outlook of August 1978, a considerable amount of space is devoted to a discussion of whether our territorial claims are proper and legitimate, and whether, as Senator Button indicated, our occasional seeming lack of presence and activity in Antarctica has pre-judiced those claims and laid them open to challenge by other treaty parties and by non-treaty parties. Greig in his article concludes I think very correctly when he says:

Extravagant claims to sovereignty are a source of discord. They exacerbate existing jealousies and rivalries. The moderation of claims needs not to be regarded as 'giving way' if it can be explained by the standard of what can rationally be demonstrated as reasonable. Even in the narrow perspective of the Parties to the Antarctic Treaty, the concept of more limited territorial rights within areas claimed could advance the cause of corporate action. Certainly Australia, a country which is scarcely in a position to assert unilaterally its claims to sovereignty, has much to gain from initiating adjustments that could promote stability and avoid confrontation. At the right time and in an appropritate context, recognition of the fact that Australia's (and the other claimants') rights are something less than sovereign could serve both those objectives.

Indeed, Mr Alan Renouf, former head of the Department of Foreign Affairs, in his recent book made a considerable plea for Australia to renounce its territorial claims in the Antarctic, something I certainly reject. In August 1979 I put a question to Senator Carrick, representing the Foreign Minister, about the Government's response to Mr Renouf's book. In a reply given to me by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister stated:

It remains the Government's policy to maintain sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic Territory. Under Australian law, the AAT has the constitutional status of an Australian territory similar to that of any other federal territory. The Government has no intention of undoing what has been accomplished over the years by its legislation on the AAT.
Finally, in the second reading speech to the Antarctic Marine Living Resources Conservation Bill 1981, as recorded on page 1008 of the House of Representatives Hansard, the Minister stated:
Australian sovereignty in the Australian Antarctic territory is in no way prejudiced by the Convention.

That is, the Convention essentially entered into at this stage. The Antarctic Treaty, I regret to say, has been plagued by a number of difficulties arising in the international environment. A backgrounder of the Department of Foreign Affairs published only last month indicates some expansion of membership of the consultative parties to the Antarctic Treaty and indicates that at the thirteenth Antarctic Treaty consultative parties meeting held in Buenos Aires in February and March this year the Federal Republic of Germany was added to the list of treaty parties. Poland, of course, had previously been added to the original signatories to the Convention.

It is unfortunate although I have said that international politics has nevertheless intruded, it is of some significance that the Soviet Union particularly has sought to exclude certain parties from participation in Antarctic Treaty matters. The Netherlands, although having acceded to the Treaty, and South Korea, which is actively interested in the question of fishing resources, have been excluded from full participation by the Soviets on the basis that it requires the unanimous consent of all parties to add further parties to the Treaty and to negotiations. It is certainly true that China has now indicated an interest in the Antarctic and the possibility of seeking to join the international regime. Perhaps the most disappointing of all these events was that during the discussions held in May 1980 in Canberra to bring about agreement on the international regime the Soviet Union was very anxious to exclude the European communities from participation in that Treaty. Senator Sibraa who, like myself, was one of the alternative parliamentary delegates who attended part of that meeting, will know the enormous amount of time wasted by the attempts of the European communities and others to play some meaningful role in the development of an international regime and the frustration they were accorded by the activities of some of the existing parties.

I wish to make a final two points on that subject. I indicated that the People's Republic of China appears to be gaining some interest in Antarctica. A recent Chinese Government delegation, in fact, visited the Antarctic and was accorded some hospitality in the Australian section of the Antarctic. The most disturbing thing I find, however, as far as the international regime is concerned is the possibility of the area being used for nuclear testing by the French. In a publication put out at the Conference on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources a question was asked as to the attitude of the French government and in particular in reference to statements made by Monsieur Bourge, the French Minister for Defence, who refused to confirm or deny that there are plans to move the French nuclear test site from Muroroa to Kerguelen Island which is one of the islands adjacent to the Antarctic. At the international treaty meeting held in Canberra in May last year specific exclusions were made for Kerguelen Island for some of the other operations of the international regime.

As I said, this treaty has been a long time in coming. It was first started at the eighth meeting of the consultative parties held in Oslo in 1975. It then worked its way through to the ninth treaty meeting in London in 1977 and the tenth treaty meeting in Washington in 1979. It eventually saw the light of day at the meeting held in Canberra. I want to say a couple of things about that. The first is to offer my congratulations to the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs for the way in which the international convention meeting was managed and for the chairmanship of Mr Ryan, a Deputy Secretary, I think, of the Department who, as chairman of the international meeting, handled some very difficult situations with great ability. I also mention Mr Brennan, the chief Australian delegate to that meeting, who made an enormous contribution to the deliberations and to the final outcome.

I was glad to see that the Australian Parliament decided that it should be represented at this meeting. Delegates and alternative delegates from both Houses were appointed. It gave me a great deal of pleasure that when the final treaty was actually drawn up and opened for signature, apart from its being signed by ambassador Brennan and one of the other Foreign Affairs officers present, an invitation was extended to me on behalf of Government delegates, and to Mr Jacobi, on behalf of Opposition delegates, actually to sign that treaty on behalf of the Australian delegation. The other point that I think was important to note about that meeting was that for just about the first time, with the possible exception of the meetings of the International Whaling Commission, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Peacock, made arrangements for non-government organisations to be represented, to have observers present and to be included in the deliberations of the Australian delegation. A Friends of the Earth representative, Michael Kennedy, the individual concerned, wrote to the Minister on 28 April 1980 indicating that Friends of the Earth would like to record its thanks to the Government and to the Parliament for its inclusion in that delegation.

That convention led fairly promptly to the passage of the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Bill 1980. That has now led to the legislation currently being considered which seeks ratification of the final instrument agreed to at the Canberra meeting. As I said, this Bill implements the Convention's conservation regime. It is important to understand that the regime itself breaks new ground. It is the first occasion on which a convention has been based upon a conservation standard which embodies an ecosystem approach to conservation. It seeks to protect not only harvested species but also the entire ecosystem including species dependent on the harvested species. In this way it differs from traditional fisheries arrangements which seek to protect only the target resource. This is the third international agreement touching on the Antarctic to which Australia has become party. The first was in 1972 with Australian accession to the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic seals.

I make a plea to the Minister to indicate, in responding to this debate this afternoon, why it is that Australia although having agreed to become a party to that international convention in 1972 has not yet seen fit to give formal ratification to that treaty. The second international agreement, of course, included those 1980 agreed measures which, as I said, found their expression in the previous piece of legislation, the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980. Clause 8 of the legislation currently being considered contains a series of very broad prohibitions. They are prohibitions which provide that a person should not do any harvesting or research in the Antarctic with respect to prohibited marine organisms unless it is done in accordance with a permit granted by the Minister. An elaborate permit system is established under clause 9 and subsequent clauses allow for the suspension, cancellation and variation of the permit. The clauses allow for the appointment of inspectors and for arrest without warrant which, apparently, is necessary since the difficulty of obtaining a warrant in the Antarctic to arrest an offender poses some difficulties, I suppose. They also provide for review of those variations, suspensions and alterations in the permit system to be appealable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

As Senator Button said, the headquarters of this new organisation which arises as a result of the Bill is to be located in Hobart. That is to the credit of a large number of people who pressed for its establishment in Hobart. It is to the credit of not only the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, who is the member for the area but also, I think one should say, former Senator Wriedt, who was a very strong advocate of the establishment of the Convention headquarters in Hobart. Steps have now been taken to get the headquarters established and functioning.

I turn now to the research issues which have to be undertaken if we are to demonstrate that our presence in the Antarctic is viable and not simply a matter of bolstering our purely territorial claims. In November 1979 the Antarctic Research Policy Advisory Committee reported to the Government with a whole series of recommendations about what it thought ought to be done in terms of research in the Antarctic and the priorities which ought to be established. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the summary of recommendations of that Antarctic Research Policy Advisory Committee which were directed to the Government at that stage.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDATIONS
Recommendation 1 That Australia have a high quality research program in Antarctica directed towards:
the living and mineral resources of the Antarctic and the environmental effects of their exploitation;
the effect of the Antarctic climate, weather and ocean circulations in the Southern Ocean area, particularly as these relate to Australia; and
taking advantage of the special opportunities afforded by the uniqueness of the Antarctic.

Recommendation 2That proposals for research consistent with the detailed guidelines prepared by the Committee should be called for and assessed in accordance with the mechanisms described in Chapter 6. All proposals, independent of their origin, should compete for a place in the research program.

Recommendation 3That universities and other organisations responsible for research under contract develop specific proposals which should compete on an equal basis with all other projects for inclusion in the research program.

Recommendation 4That medical officers employed for service in the field, in appropriate cases be offered appointments on three-year period contracts associated with a medical research body for the purpose of planning and doing research and, where appropriate, working towards a higher degree. Specific proposals for medical research by workers other than medical officers will be considered on their merits for inclusion in the overall program.
Recommendation 5That the Chairman of ANCAR be invited to attend meetings of ARPAC as an observer.

Recommendation 6That individuals of standing in scientific disciplines be appointed to act on ARPAC's behalf to encourage and coordinate responses to ARPAC's invitation to submit proposals for Antarctic research and to initiate the process of assessment of the scientific merit of these responses.

Recommendation 7That a Planning Committee be established, under the Chairmanship of the Director, Antarctic Division and comprising coordinators in specific disciplines appointed by ARPAC. The Planning Committee will make recommendations to ARPAC annually on the content of an Antarctic research program.

Recommendation 8That the level of support for Antarctic research be set no later than August each year for the program in Antarctica to begin in October of the following year. Once the total program for that year is formulated, the collaborating organisations must be assured that the required funds will be forthcoming.
Recommendation 9That the Antarctic Division continue to provide and co-ordinate the logistic support for the Australian Antarctic program.

Recommendation 10That the Antarctic Division continue to have a scientific research role and accept responsibility for such interdisciplinary coordination, storage of data and expertise as may be required.

Recommendation 11That the Antarctic Division be developed with a view to becoming a centre of excellence in Southern Ocean marine biology as the major thrust of its research program and develop a small professional group to:
undertake oceanographic research in the Southern Ocean; and
provide a supporting role in the maintenance of equipment and data storage and retrieval in order to foster oceanographic research by other appropriate agencies.
Recommendation 12That the Antarctic Division continue to conduct research in terrestrial biology at about the present level.
Recommendation 13That the Antarctic Division develop a repository of knowledge and expertise in engineering and polar technology.

Recommendation 14That the Government review the staffing structure of the Antarctic Division's research branch as a matter of urgency with a view to introducing the Research Scientist classifications as used in CSIRO.

Recommendation 15That staff levels and resources available to the Antarctic Division not be reduced from present levels. Vacancies created by letting contracts for glaciology, upper atmosphere physics and cosmic ray physics should be retained for programs in marine and terrestrial biology, oceanography and supporting studies in engineering and polar technology.

Recommendation 16That Antarctic research be identified as a national commitment. Coherence in, and continuity of funds for long-term programs should be guaranteed by the ear-marking of funds within the appropriations of the Government organisations involved.

Recommendation 17That a supplementary fund of $500,000 p.a. be created, to be administered by the Department of Science and the Environment to support high quality research proposals which are likely to contribute significantly to the aims of Antarctic research and which do not qualify for support from other sources.

Recommendation 18That the replacement of existing station buildings continue and that additional shipping capacity be provided to allow that program to proceed without reducing the logistic support for the scientific program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government responded to that report in an official statement made by the then Minister for Science and the Environment, Mr David Thomson, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's main recommendations have been accepted by the Government.

Certainly that program of research is now starting to show some evidence of being undertaken in the Antarctic. Clause 9 (1) (b) of the Bill very specifically deals with the carrying out of research. It states that one of the things which a permit system may permit is to:
carry out research with respect to marine organisms of a specified kind or kinds.

As honourable senators will know, there has been some acceptance by the Opposition of the thrust of that report, as was illustrated when Senator Button spoke in this place on 25 March 1980 on the tabling of that report. He indicated the Opposition's broad support for the proposals which were being put forward. On 22 August 1979 the then Minister for Science and the Environment, Senator Webster, announced the major rebuilding program at Australian Antarctic stations. I think Senator Melzer, as a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works, may well have seen the proposals which have been put before the Government and the Parliament on that matter. Moves are afoot to obtain a research vessel for use in the Antarctic.

The first of the three matters of scientific research that perhaps need to be brought to attention concerns the weather. It is of significance to Australia. Australia derives a great deal of its weather impact from events in Antarctica. There appeared in the authoritative journal Nature of 26 January 1978 an article written by Professor Mercer of the Institute of Polar Studies entitled 'West Antarctic ice sheet and CO2 greenhouse effect: a threat of disaster'. In that article Professor Mercer indicated:

If the global consumption of fossil fuels continues to grow at its present rate, atmospheric CO2 content will double in about 50 years. Climatic models suggest that the resultant greenhouse-warming effect will be greatly magnified in high latitudes. The computed temperature rise at lat 80*S could start rapid deglaciation of West Antarctica, leading to a 5m rise in sea level.

A five metre rise in sea level would effectively wipe out a large proportion of my constituency and I am sure of the constituencies of most honourable senators. It is quite clear that the behaviour of the Antarctic ice sheets will need to be carefully monitored by Australian meteorological authorities. The second point which appears to be of interest for research in the Antarctic is, in fact, the very matter of the origins of life on which I am sure my friend and colleague, Senator Martyr, will have some opinions. In an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald in December 1980 under the heading 'Antarctic ice could be hiding the key to life' one of the researchers as reported as saying:

'Probably the most significant thing that has been proven with the Antarctic meteorites is that amino acids do exist in outer space', says John Annexstad of NASA a member of Cassidy's team and leader of the current expedition.

In fact, there are some grounds for believing the presence of meteorites and the material frozen within the Antarctic continent may have enormous implications for the esoteric studies of things such as the origins of life and of biological molecular formations. The final major scientific area in the Antarctic which will need to be watched, as Senator Button has indicated, is the exploitation of the krill which abound in Antarctic waters. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in a publication produced in August 1979 reported:
Fisheries biologists generally regard annual catch levels of 50-60 million tonnes--
Of krill-
as feasible-about the same order of size as the entire world fish catch at present.

In fact, there exists within the Antarctic the capability of taking, in terms of protein for possible human consumption, about the same amount of value of protein as is currently derived from all the world's fisheries. That will undoubtedly have major implications for feeding people throughout the world and, indeed, will raise the question of who should properly have the right to exploit and profit from such undertakings.

I want to raise another matter because it seems to me that it is a matter on which no international agreement is likely to be provided. It is the matter of mineral resources in the Antarctic. Jon Tinker, writing in the New Scientist of September 1979, indicated that international peace, good will and harmony would probably melt as quickly-I think his phrase was-as an iceberg in the Red Sea the moment we come to talking about the exploitation of resources which actually have real commercial viability. This tends to be very largely, therefore, a debate about what mineral resources are potentially available in Antarctica. A report in the Washington Post of September 1979 stated:

Antarctic treaty nations warned yesterday that if a legal and political system to regulate oil drilling is not developed soon, the ecology of the earth's last unspoiled continent could be seriously damaged.
Major oil companies are pressuring the 13 nations to open Antarctica to off-shore exploration.

The question very much is not only whether there is material in Antarctic worth exploiting but also whether it could be exploited at a reasonable cost. A paper which was prepared by the foreign affairs group of the Legislative Research Service of the Parliamentary Library in May 1980 was headed 'A Background Brief on the Antarctic and Marine Living Resources'. It indicated that by and large the resources likely to be exploitable in the mineral sense are limited. It said:

However, while mineral occurrences have been detected in many parts of the continent most of them are of a quality and quantity such that they would not warrant further consideration if found elsewhere.

In other articles different points of view have been put forward. Barbara Mitchell who has written extensively on the politics and the environment of Antarctica in an article appearing in the Environment issue of January-February 1980 made it quite clear that in her view there are considerable mineral deposits in Antarctica and that they are capable of being exploited. One of the points she raised which I thought interesting was in the following terms:
The non-claimant--
That is, those nations without territorial claims in the Antarctic-

position is countered most strongly by the Latin claimant states and Australia. One claimant state has even insisted that its sovereignty must be recognised before the Antarctic Treaty can be extended to cover mineral resources.

In other words, before further exploration the Treaty must recognise what it currently does not recognise; that is, the actual legal authority of one of the parties over part of the continent. The article goes on:
Speaking at a press briefing seminar in Washington in September 1979, Ambassador Keith Brennan of Australia made it clear that oil found off the Australian sector was Australian.

If that is the case I suggest that that is somewhat of a departure from the international regime that has currently appertained. The Australian Financial Review of June 1980 headed one of its articles 'Antarctic marine life accord clears way for mining talks'. The article stated:
The convention, signed in Australia last week, clears the way for a more difficult task: finding a way to deal with the mineral resources of the continent.

That indeed will be of very considerable importance. Informed discussions were held in Washington last December to try to develop a framework for the handling of mineral resources within the Antarctic Treaty and within the regime that currently exists. Many people such as the Friends of the Earth are bitterly opposed to this. Dr K. D. Suter in his publication 'World Law and the Last Wilderness' is very anxious when he indicates that the kind of rocks that have been found both in South Africa and the Transantarctic Mountains include formations which are otherwise rich in deposits of platinum, nickel, copper, chromium, lead, zinc, iron and cobalt. It is to be hoped that the idea that these resources could be exploited simply by one of the Treaty parties to the disadvantage of either the international community or other Treaty parties will be resisted.

The other thing that is to be substantially resisted is the fact that there are now a number of Australian defence and foreign policy writers who are producing articles entitled, for example, 'A Limited Antarctic Warfare Capability for Australia'. There is an article in the Pacific Defence Reporter of February 1979 which indicates how Australia should be moving to acquire facilities and to acquire some sort of ability to undertake limited Antarctic warfare. There is an article by Lieutenant Colonel Teague 'Scope for Defence aid in Antarctica' which indicates the sort of resources that Australia's armed forces would need to mount and support some sort of military involvement in Antarctica. These articles need to be carefully examined.

This Bill puts into effect a treaty which has a number of weaknesses such as the failure to adjust to the mineral regime; the failure of the Treaty parties to come to grips with the continuing politics; particularly the Soviet Union's veto of other people's participation; the question of needing unanimous consent under Article 12 of the Treaty; the question which the Department of Foreign Affairs has been unable to answer as to whether Australia's 200-mile economic zone applies in the Antarctic. A question was asked by Mr Jacobi of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Peacock) as to whether Australian authority extends within 200 miles of the Antarctic. The Minister's reply to that question was:

The questions raised by the honourable member involve complex issues of law that in many respects are unsettled. It would therefore not be appropriate for me to canvass these legal problems at this stage.

We do not even have the benefit of knowing what the Australian Government's legal view is of its relationship to the Antarctic. There are territorial claims still unsettled. There are the legitimate claims of the Third World to share in the benefits that might possibly be derived in the Antarctic. There is the question of the effect of the law of the sea regime. There is the continuing battle between the conservation nations and nations such as the Soviet Union, Japan and Poland which seek to exploit the resources of Antarctica. There is a lack of biological data about krill, Antarctic fish, seals, and a number of other matters. In this Bill, I regret to say, there is a substantial division of jurisdiction.

It amazes me that the Minister responsible for this legislation should be the Minister for Science and Technology and not the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, who otherwise has the carriage of matters dealing with the conservation of living natural resources, certainly in all the other territories of Australia. It is ridiculous that one Minister will be responsible for control of whaling legislation in the Antarctic and another Minister will be responsible for the control of the exploitation of krill in the Antarctic. It seems to me very stupid that the Government should have allowed this divided jurisdiction between two of its own Ministers to persist in this legislation.

The international regime, however, is to be welcomed. It is to be hoped that the matters which have been raised, both at the international meeting which was held in Canberra and at subsequent meetings, can be dealt with effectively by the parties in the future, and that some method will be found of adjusting international disputes over other resources in the Antarctic without the breakdown of the international regime of peace and co-operation which has served the Antarctic well, and which has served the world in general very well. I hope that these other matters can be settled as satisfactorily as this one has, and that in time all of those weaknesses which I have identified can be taken up and effectively dealt with. I commend this Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not speak with the expertise of Senator Puplick. It was with great pleasure that I listened to his speech and to his treatise on the problems and the history of Antarctica. I was fortunate enough to visit the Antarctic earlier this year. While I was there it became very apparent to me that there were two or three problems that I think the Government and the people of Australia should be aware of. I must say that I had always had a deep interest in the Antarctic, but it was not until I found that I was to go there with a committee that I did more extensive reading on the area than I had before. I became aware of the fragile nature of the environment in the Antarctic, and I became conscious of the fact that Australia should play a part in preserving that continent and preventing it from being damaged or destroyed by modern man.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in this place last week, when we went to McMurdo we found that the Americans had established a nuclear reactor there. At the time they established it, I suspect they thought that it was an easy way to provide energy in the Antarctic. Energy that produces heat is essential to any human being living in the Antarctic. I suspect that the Americans thought at that time that nuclear power was a renewable, easy to manage source of energy in an area where it is not easy to get stores or get great bulks of energy delivered. But after the reactor had been in existence and in action for some few years they found the same problems existed with that reactor as exist with every other reactor. These problems arise everywhere there are nuclear reactors. They at least had enough conscience to decide that they could not endanger the area by keeping the reactor going. They could not endanger the area by awaiting the inevitable accident. They closed down their reactor and took it and the contaminated earth away. But knowing what we know now about nuclear reactors, we cannot be sure that that episode has not affected the Antarctic in some way.

By going there, and from my reading about the area, I found that 90 per cent of the world's fresh water is locked up in the Antarctic. If that fresh water were contaminated, it must have an effect on life on earth. I also realised, of course, that if that over two-mile thick cap of ice that sits on the rock that makes Antarctica started to melt in any part, life in many parts of the world would be made quite untenable, and that life for many people may become extinct in some parts of the world. It was only by delving a little into the history of the Antarctic that I discovered that that reactor had been there. We cannot but wonder what else might have gone on in the Antarctic which the rest of the world has not been made aware of and which might very well affect our lives in the future.

When I listened to Senator Puplick talk about the possible French proposal to take its weapons testing program to the Antarctic I could not help being concerned that a nation could show so little concern that it would even tolerate the idea for a moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was explaining that my interest in the Antarctic had been reawakened by the fact that I had to visit the Antarctic with the Public Works Committee. Some of the experiences I had there awakened my real concern that Australia should show some leadership in relation to the Antarctic. I explained that during my visit to the Antarctic I found out that at one stage there had been a nuclear reactor at McMurdo Sound. I was concerned that countries could be so unaware of the delicacy of the situation in the Antarctic that they would put in the Antarctic region the sort of material that could cause disaster. I said earlier that Senator Puplick had given me the information that the French were considering moving their nuclear arms tests from the Pacific to the Antarctic. I think that is appalling. The French are showing very little consideration for the effect that such action might have on the environment in the Antarctic.

SPEECH.PARA: While I was visiting the Antarctic I also heard people talking about krill. Before I went to the Antarctic and since I have returned I have heard people talking about the fact that millions of tonnes of krill can be taken from the Antarctic. It is said that krill is an extraordinary source of protein. The more questions I asked and the more I listened, the more I realised that in this area, as in so many other areas of the environment-the flora and fauna with which we are concerned-nobody really knows the answer and nobody has a base upon which to form his opinions. For instance, when we were being briefed in relation to the Antarctic it was put to me that the reason there may well be millions of tonnes of krill available for harvesting at the moment is that certain nations have fished out the whale population and that there are not as many whales in the southern seas as there once were. Whales, of course, eat extraordinary amounts of krill.

It was put to me that we might at the moment have an extraordinary population of krill in the Antarctic because, to be basic, whales were no longer eating it. It was put to me that once the krill population had caught up with the fact that there were not so many whales in the Antarctic the amount would level out to a point where there might not be millions and millions of tonnes and that in fact by allowing nations to fish for millions of tonnes of krill we might very well be exterminating the krill in much the same way as we have exterminated some varieties of whales. What impressed and frightened me was that when one asked what effect that will have on the fish population of the world and what effect that, in turn, will have on the world, the answer was the answer so often given, that is: 'We do not know'. If Australia is really concerned about the Antarctic and intends to go ahead with its commitment to the Antarctic I would like to see it take a proper view. Australia should make sure that research is carried out immediately so that we know where we stand in relation to that particular resource.

Another matter raised while we were talking to people who were in the Antarctic or who were concerned with it involved the penguin population. For years poultry farmers in Australia have been terrified of Newcastle disease. It has been put to us in various references that if Newcastle disease ever got a hold in Australia it would wipe out the poultry industry and would wipe out a good deal of the bird population. During my visit to the Antarctic it was put to me that Newcastle disease had been introduced to the penguin colonies in the Antarctic. I suppose that the penguin colonies in themselves are not of any commercial viability. I am glad to say that we do not eat, sell or wear penguins but we do not know what part penguins play in the whole chain of life in the Antarctic or in areas closer to Australian shores. It was said to me that Newcastle disease had been introduced into the Antarctic. If anything like the facts that have been given to me in various inquiries are true, Newcastle disease could very well wipe out the penguin colonies of the Antarctic. It does not appear to have caused any government to take any sort of precautions. Indeed, if Newcastle disease is present in the Antarctic, it appears that it is there because it has been introduced by countries that have not taken proper precautions in relation to the disposal of food or waste in the Antarctic. We do not appear to be taking any steps, for instance, to make sure that it does not proceed from the Antarctic into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —We specifically mentioned that in the environment protection legislation introduced last May. There was a specific clause which dealt with poultry, chickens and things of that nature.

—What worries me is that I was told that Newcastle disease existed in the penguin colonies in the Antarctic. I cannot see any evidence that we have accepted that Newcastle disease is present in the Antarctic. We are not taking precautions nationally or internationally to combat it, to do away with it or to stop its coming into Australia. None of the members of the party I was with took any precautions to stop the disease being introduced into Australia by us. I repeat that I do not know whether Newcastle disease is present in the Antarctic but I am saying that if Australia is fair dinkum about the Antarctic, if it has some commitment to it, I would hope that it would acknowledge that the disease could exist, or that it would take precautions or act in a responsible manner if such a threat exists.

SPEECH.PARA: From my own observations in the Antarctic I feel that the improper disposal of waste could affect the whole environment, the balance of nature. It appears that some countries with bases in the Antarctic take home their waste. It appears that some countries take home some of their waste and freeze the rest, hoping that nature will dispose of it in the southern seas. I am not sure what Australia does in this instance but it certainly appears that some countries do not give a damn and feel that the environment one way or another can cope with whatever waste is left there. If Newcastle disease exists in the Antarctic, that may be the reason for its existence. I would like to see countries which have bases in the Antarctic-this applies even to countries which cast envious eyes at the Antarctic and which feel that they too should perhaps have a share of the spoils-at least show a responsibility and take away from the Antarctic the mess made by human beings.

It seems to me that if we do not accept that responsibility the balance of life in the Antarctic may be upset. If the balance of life in the Antarctic is upset it might very well affect Australia and, being less parochial, I feel that it could affect the world. In taking the step that Australia has in acknowledging in this Bill its responsibility to the environment of the Antarctic, I hope that Australia goes on to show a greater responsibility to the Antarctic than it has shown before.

As speakers who have gone before me in this debate have said, Australia in the past, although claiming sovereignty over a very large slice of the Antarctic, has not done very much more than just claim that sovereignty. Despite the fact that we have not put our money where our mouths were, Australian scientists, from my experience, have done magnificently with what we have given them. They have carried out magnificent work under poor conditions and with poor equipment. They have achieved world renown in some areas in conditions that seem to me to be remarkable. I would like to see Australia take a responsibility for the Antarctic. I would like Australia to show a very proper concern for what I feel is a magnificent continent. I hope that in this Bill we have a commitment from the Government-it is certainly a commitment from honourable senators on this side of the chamber-that Antarctica will proceed without being endangered in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts I present the 185th, 186th and 187th reports of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of my colleagues on the Joint Parliamentary Committtee of Public Accounts I have pleasure in presenting the Committee's 185th, 186th and 187th reports. The 185th report is the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's 176th report on the Auditor-General's report for 1977-78. The Committee is satisfied with the explanations provided by the Department of Finance.

SPEECH.PARA: The 186th report concerns our inquiry into the Advance to the Minister for Finance for 1979-80. The Committee obtained explanations from departments and authorities in relation to 128 items of expenditure from the Advance. Public inquiries were held into four departments. I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that we are satisfied that in most cases the use of the Advance in 1979-80 was justified.

The 187th report relates to inquiry by the Committee into the criticisms made by the Auditor-General in his reports for 1978-79. It has been a long standing practice for this Committee to select items from these reports and inquire into some of the issues raised. In our 187th report we have made recommendations on some administrative and financial aspects of the Departments of Defence, Primary Industry and Social Security.

The inquiry into the Department of Defence arose out of comments by the Auditor-General in 1977-78 and again in 1978-79 relating to the practice within the Royal Australian Air Force of removing serviceable components from aircraft to remedy defects in other aircraft. Investigations by the Committee revealed that this practice, although in itself wasteful of limited resources, is a symptom of wider problems of the RAAF maintenance supply system. We discovered that as a result of delays in bringing an up-to-date computerised supply system into operation in the RAAF and the decision in 1973 to abolish 'buffer stocks' or 'supply margins' of aircraft spares, the RAAF supply system has become too finely tuned to provide the necessary logistics support to the RAAF within reasonable time constraints. We therefore made a number of recommendations aimed at the more timely provision of spare parts, including a 'once off' expenditure of around $20m to re-establish the spares supply margin and the development of a more accurate mechanism for assessing future spare parts requirements.

The Committee also noted related aspects of the availability of skilled manpower in the RAAF and local industry participation in aircraft maintenance. We discovered that the RAAF is experiencing considerable difficulty in retaining adequate numbers of skilled tradesmen and engineers. Accordingly, we are presenting a number of recommendations aimed at improved efficiencies in this area. These include better margins for skills, increased re-enlistment bonuses and overseas recruitment.

The inquiry into the Department of Primary Industry concerned the Auditor-General's criticisms of the procedures relating to the management and disposal of forfeited foreign fishing vessels. During this inquiry the Committee became aware that the realisable value of many of the forfeited vessels and catches was low, whereas the costs of storage and maintenance prior to disposal were high. Additionally, local harbour authorities were concerned that the prolonged storage of apprehended vessels posed considerable inconvenience and danger to harbour operations, and that the often considerable delays between apprehension and disposal led to increased costs.

In addition, we believe that there had been considerable ecological and environmental effects as a result of illegal fishing, particularly with the taking of clams. Confiscated catches of clam meat individually have amounted to several tonnes, with one particular catch being in excess of 11 tonnes which would represent the destruction of over 22,000 clams. The Committee is satisfied that the Department's new manual of procedures will overcome many of the Auditor-General's criticisms and should result in greater decision-making at the local level, considerably reducing the delays and costs associated with the disposal of these vessels. A vessel ordered to be forfeited in January this year is currently being destroyed in accordance with the new procedures. It is estimated that considerable savings have been achieved as a result.

The Committee also inquired into the deficiencies mentioned by the Auditor-General in the procedures for payment and review of pensions and benefits overseas. Since May 1973 persons leaving Australia either permanently or temporarily have been entitled to receive their Australian pensions and benefits under substantially the same conditions as if they were residing in Australia. There has been a rapid expansion in recent years in the number and value of these payments and the Committee was concerned that the deficiencies mentioned by the Auditor-General may have led to significant payments in excess of entitlement. Accordingly, the Committee examined the procedures for payment and review of pensions and other benefits, reciprocal payment arrangements with other governments, staffing of overseas offices and the internal audit procedures applying to overseas payment functions.

Whilst the Committee has noted the actions taken by the Department of Social Security to strengthen its procedures following the Auditor-General's report, it is concerned that this action was not taken earlier, as the growth in overseas payments has markedly increased the scope for improper or excess payments. The saving of $685,000 achieved by a special review conducted by the Geneva office over the 12 months to March 1980 clearly demonstrates the need for regular investigation. The Committee has made a number of recommendations aimed at achieving greater efficiency and economy in this field. We have recommended that most payments to pensioners overseas should be made by the central office of the Department of Social Security. Centralisation of control, we believe, will facilitate eligibility checks. In addition, the Committee believes that in order to minimise the number of overseas payments, pensioners on short term visits should be actively discouraged from using the overseas payment system and instead should have their payments made into bank accounts for transfer overseas using normal banking facilities.

The Committee has also recommended that the Department pursue the possibility of extending reciprocal arrangements similar to those with Britain and New Zealand under which administrative functions and controls over pension payments would be exercised by the authorities in the countries where the payments are being made. In some cases consideration should be given to posting appropriate officers to posts, especially in southern Europe, where significant numbers of pensioners reside. I commend the reports to the Senate.

I would like to elaborate on two points which were not clearly identified in the short statement. The first concerns the apprehension of foreign vessels and associated problems. One problem which the Committee found during its investigation was that there was a lack of co-ordination between the various departments responsible for the apprehension and destruction of catches and of vessels, which in many instances were considered by the local authorities in whose ports those vessels were situated to be not only a great danger to local shipping but also a health hazard. It is interesting to note the multitude of authorities involved with the apprehension of foreign vessels. They are at all levels of government-Federal, State and local. They include the Attorney-General's Department, the Bureau of Customs, the departments of Administrative Services, Foreign Affairs, Health, Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Prime Minister and Cabinet and Transport, Federal and State police forces, State fisheries and local harbour authorities. In the submissions from the various port authorities we were told of the immense delays which they experience because of the various departments having to make decisions about what to do with the vessels or with the crews of the vessels.

Another point which I would like to emphasise and which was mentioned in the statement is the ecological damage caused by clam fishing vessels. The Committee heard a lot of comment during its investigation about the effect on the Great Barrier Reef of clam fishing vessels and clam fishing. Clam meat is regarded as a great delicacy in quite a large part of South East Asia. The only meat taken from a clam is the muscle and the average clam yields approximately half a kilogram of muscle. If we consider that one catch consisted of 11 tonnes of clam meat, we can see that during the fishing for that meat about 22,000 clams were destroyed. We were told that the clams of the region have an extremely slow growth rate, with some species taking approximately 70 years to reach maximum size. When we consider that it takes up to 70 years for a clam to be fully grown and that in one catch alone 11 tonnes or more than 20,000 clams were destroyed, we can understand the damage done the Great Barrier Reef in that respect alone.

The Committee has come to the conclusion that the method used to dispose of apprehended vessels was not at all economical because of the delay involved and because of the way the whole system was treated. The fact is that some of the vessels the Committee inspected are of negligible commercial value and that the costs associated with their maintenance and disposal are generally many times their realisable value. Therefore, the Committee strongly recommends that such vessels be disposed of as quickly as possible after forfeiture, for the following reasons: Maintenance costs are both significant and unpredictable; they occupy valuable port facilities; they incur hidden costs by way of involvement by fisheries officers as well as local authorities; they are a hazard to navigation if they sink or break up at moorings.

I am glad to report that in July 1980 the Department of Primary Industry published a manual of procedures for recording and disposal of fisheries forfeitures. The Committee has examined the manual and is satisfied that it will help to overcome the problems raised with the Committee during the inquiry.

The second item which I should like briefly to elaborate on is the payment of pensions and benefits overseas. This matter also was referred to in the statement. It is interesting that the number of pensions paid overseas has incresed considerably in the last six years. There are two main points from which the pensions are paid; one is Geneva and one is in London. From 1974 to 1980 the number of pensions paid from Geneva increased from 2,754 to 9,423 which is a 242 per cent increase. The number of pensions payable from London increased from 2,217 to 3,941, which is a 78 per cent increase. The total number of pensions paid overseas by all posts-not only Geneva and London-increased from 5,560 in 1974 to 15,314 in 1980, an increase of 175 per cent. The major increase occurred in southern Europe. We have been told, for instance from the Geneva office, that of the 9,423 benefits paid from the Geneva office, 3,464 were paid in Greece and 2,492 were paid in Italy. The fact is that our offices in Geneva do not have facilities or staff to be able to control or check the pensions which are paid in that area. Therefore, we recommended that an office be established in the countries which pay the largest number of pensions-for instance, one in Athens and one in Rome-because it would definitely help to police and to check the pensions which are paid at the moment. Mr President, these are two points on which I want to elaborate because I feel that they are not well elaborated on in the statement.

I contend that this practice is not a reflection on the Royal Australian Air Force but rather on the Parliament, by our placing these people in a position in which such practices are not only time consuming and costly but also are necessary in order to increase the operational availability of a very small air force. We have approximately 20 different aircraft types from seven countries, and with small numbers this presents tremendous problems of supply of spares. It is impossible to get any sort of economies of scale as a result of this practice. Our Committee is most concerned about a number of features.

SPEECH.PARA: I continue to be concerned about the inevitable amount of red tape involving communications between a central office at Russell Hill and the various bases. While our Air Force is bringing into service the latest in technical hardware and sophistication the accounting and the logistic supply systems are indeed very deficient and need updating as a matter of extreme urgency. TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a statement on domestic air fares which was originally brought down last week by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt). In fact, I think it has got the stumbles. It seems to me that the Government is experiencing a self-generating stumble. The reason I say this is that we expect the Government to run the country but it cannot even run this Senate. It cannot even run this Parliament.
