Yet tomorrow we will be asked to give consideration to guaranteeing a loan to Ansett Airlines. On 2 April the Melbourne Age carried the following report on page one:

Mr Hunt, who is believed to have strongly opposed the sale of TAA when the matter was canvassed within recent weeks, said that the Government expected to spell out within a month the details under which the airline would become a public company.

Here we have an incredible situation: The Government has announced that TAA is to become a public company but Mr Hunt, the Minister for Transport, does not know whether private enterprise is to be allowed a share of it, whether 49 per cent is to go to private enterprise, or whether the whole lot is to go to private enterprise. The Minister for Transport himself, the day after April Fools' Day, did not know what was going to happen to TAA. The Age article continued:
. . . Mr Hunt made it clear that the Government would not let the situation arise where the Ansett group could take over TAA and create a monopoly.

How in the name of fortune could he stop that if TAA becomes a public company, unless the Government owns 51 per cent or more of the shares? The Minister was careful not to say that. He was given an opportunity on 1 April, 2 April and subsequent days to categorically state: 'The Government will not sell more than 50 per cent of TAA to private enterprise'. But he did not do so. All he says is that by some magical means he will stop some intermediate predator in the community from taking control of TAA, and finally putting it into the hands of Ansett. For my part, I do not believe for one moment that either Sir Peter Abeles or Mr Rupert Murdoch has any intention of purchasing TAA. I do not believe any of this rubbish suggesting that they have ever contemplated buying TAA or Qantas Airways Ltd. But in Australian civil aviation what could be just as bad as a monopoly is a duopoly where there is a cosy arrangement between Ansett and a second party, whoever owns it. But the third statement attributed to Mr Hunt on 2 April is, to use an oft repeated word, reprehensible. The article continued:
Mr Hunt told reporters outside Parliament that while it had not finally been decided, he doubted that the situation would arise where the Government sold a controlling interest to private enterprise.
I find that statement from a responsible Minister mind boggling. I repeat that the article reads:
Mr Hunt told reporters outside Parliament that while it had not finally been decided, he doubted that the situation would arise where the Government sold a controlling interest to private enterprise.
But then, unfortunately, the situation got worse. On 3 April the Sydney Morning Herald-it is hardly a rampant, radical, left wing journal of this nation-reported:

Significantly, while the recent Holcroft report called for a more competitive environment, it did not bother to recommend that TAA be either turned into a public company, or sold off to private interests.

The Sydney Morning Herald castigated the Government for not being more explicit about how much of TAA is to be sold. But the matter did not finish there. We then came to 6 April and the announcement-I am trying to source this announcement to find out where Mr Hunt made it and what were its explicit terms-that there is to be an inquiry. The Melbourne Age of April 6 stated:

It is difficult to understand the thinking behind the Federal Government's latest series of decisions regarding domestic air services. After giving what appears to have been little serious consideration to the Holcroft committee's report . . . the Government last week approved big rises in short haul tariffs and small reductions in long distance fares. The formula certainly falls far short of the Holcroft recommendations. Then, in a statement that, perhaps deliberately, distracted critics from the shortcomings of the new fares formula . . . Mr Hunt announced that the Government was considering selling all or part of TAA to private enterprise. Apart from being a complete about-turn on previously stated policies, the vague announcement seemed aimed only at quietening those increasingly vocal sections of the Government parties which are in favour of less Government involvement in commercial enterprises.
But then the Age went on to report:
But the most mystifying announcement last week was that the Government intended establishing a new inquiry into the two-airline policy and the question of deregulating the industry.

The Age then went on to canvass deregulation as it is practised in the United States of America. I do not have a complete view on that matter. As a person who champions free enterprise, I can see virtue in competition. Yet almost every article that I read about deregulation in the United States that it has reached the stage where cost cutting is impinging on safety. Areas in out of the way places such as Queensland and Western Australia-the very areas that deregulation is supposed to help-would be disadvantaged. Under a deregulated system, a completely free enterprise system, they are the first to go. So I have a totally open mind on the subject. The mystifying thing is that apparently this inquiry will run for the next five years. The Age quite properly stated:

Thus the biggest problem with the proposed inquiry is that it could provide the Government with an excuse for doing nothing about the anachronistic two-airline policy for at least another eight years.
I hope that this is wrong. I will quote from the National Times of last weekend. Marian Wilkinson and Julie Flynn are normally two very accurate and responsible journalists, but they wrote:

Last Thursday night a group of West Australian backbenchers relented after threatening the Government with crossing the floor on a crucial bill to guarantee Ansett's loan for the $246 million purchase of its 21 new Boeing jets.
I have some admiration for Western Australian senators and members. Most of them play cricket which means that they are jolly decent chaps.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you including Senator Coleman?

—Some of the women try to play cricket. I have great admiration for Western Australian senators and members but I cannot believe that they were lined up by the Prime Minister or Mr Hunt last Thursday night, who said: 'We gave you the Holcroft inquiry. We truncated it and took no notice of it but that is by the way. We got you off the hook for the election. We got Mr Crichton-Browne into the last Senate seat. We achieved that much for you. Now you have kicked up a fuss about not taking notice of the Holcroft inquiry. We have arbitrarily introduced new air fares. You cannot test whether, because of cross-subsidisation, they are the right amounts and Western Australians and Tasmanians relatively will now pay less than those in the eastern States. You cannot test that, but we will give you an inquiry. That should shut up and satisfy you boys'. The inquiry will take five years and it may take another two or three years after that to act on the recommendations of that inquiry into deregulation. Then we may have courageous Western Australian back bench senators tugging their forelocks and saying: 'Malcolm, that is fair enough for us. We will support your two-airline policy, we will support the aircraft loan Bill when it comes in'.
—You shouldn't believe everything you read in the papers.

—That is the most reassuring statement I have heard this evening. Coming from the honourable senator, I believe every word he says. It fills me with hope that when the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill comes into this Senate tomorrow-presumably it will be voted on later this week; according to the Prime Minister it must be passed before Easter, otherwise Mr Murdoch will lose his good interest rate with Eximbank--
—Your own stance has been a bit variable on this also.

—It has not been variable at all. In fact if the honourable senator had been here a moment or two ago he would have heard me repeat that I am in a dilemma about a two-airline policy. I will admit that. That is the only point on which I vary. I have said that it should be reviewed. I have never advocated deregulation. Maybe that is the answer. In Western Australia, for example, towns such as Geraldton, Bunbury and Albany-according to my interpretation-would be the first to go with total deregulation.
—What about the towns of Cunnamulla and Charleville in Queensland?

—Absolutely. They may be the first to go. My experience is that under total deregulation they would be the first to be scrubbed off the list. What I want is an inquiry. I would like Western Australian, Tasmania and Queensland senators to contemplate-before we rise, before 30 June-whether, if we pass this Bill to guarantee a loan for Ansett Airlines involving hundreds of millions of dollars we have left ourselves any room to manoeuvre on a two-airline policy for the next 10 years. Have we left ourselves any room to manoeuvre on air fares? This statement has been brought down and airlines are already charging these air fares today. Can Senator Thomas, who knows of my regard for him, stand up and say: 'I know that the economy fare from Melbourne to Perth at $220.20 is fair and equitable to Western Australia'? If he can stand up and say 'I have proved to myself mathematically that that fare is fair and equitable' then I will believe him because he is an honest man. TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) on nuclear safeguards agreements with France, Canada and Sweden. I must admit, in the short time that I have had this statement available to me, to being appalled at its contents. There are a number of disturbing features about the agreements. Honourable senators do not have to go past page 1 where the Minister states:

SPEECH.PARA: We are continuing our active role in the Committee on Disarmament, the main international negotiating forum on disarmament questions, and we are maintaining our long-established participation in the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). We are continually working to encourage such studies as those on plutonium storage, spent fuel management and assurance of supply, and to upgrade international safeguards measures, particularly in respect of proliferation-sensitive technologies.

So the Government says that while we are continuing our active role in the Committee on Disarmament and maintaining our long-established participation in the IAEA, this Government recognises the need to upgrade international safeguards measures particularly in respect of proliferation-sensitive technologies. Yet it would appear to the lay person, as he reads these agreements, that that is exactly what it is doing. The Government is providing the resources for proliferation. I do not see anything in these agreements as sufficient assurance for the people of Australia that there are, at this stage, adequate safeguards measures nor any attempt on the part of this Government to insist on adequate safeguards measures. For instance page 2 of the agreement states:

They provide for the prohibition of explosive or military use, the application of International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards, ''fall-back'' safeguards in the event that IAEA safeguards cease to apply,--
Whatever that is supposed to mean-
Prior consent rights over reprocessing high enrichment and transfers to third countries, as well as internationally recognised levels of physical protection.

'Internationally recognised levels of physical protection'. What on earth is that supposed to mean? I notice from the speakers list that not one Government member is to speak in this very important debate. Four members of the Opposition are to speak and not one member of the Government is prepared to debate such an important issue as nuclear safeguards agreements. I would like to ask what these internationally recognised levels of physical protection are. Whom do they apply to? Is this physical protection of the people who will work with Australian uranium? Is it physical protection of the agreements being signed? If it is, how will we monitor it? Exactly what are the internationally recognised levels of physical protection? This phrase can be found on page 2, paragraph 3 of the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

The other disturbing point about that paragraph relates to the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards. The people of Australia have been told and conditioned, I suppose, to believe the safeguards that apply through the International Atomic Energy Agency are the ultimate; they are as much as we need to ensure that our uranium is going only to be used for peaceful purposes. In this one statement we are told that not only do we have IAEA safeguards but also that we have fallback safeguards. The Minister's statement refers to fallback safeguards in the event that IAEA safeguards cease to apply. There is no mention anywhere in the statement, that I can find, of the circumstances in which IAEA safeguards would not apply so that we would need to go into a fallback situation. The Minister has many answers to give on this matter. As I said, I am disturbed that we do not have speakers in this debate from the Government side. There are many things that the people of Australia need to know. We need to know who accepts the responsibility for the fallback safeguards. It could not possibly be the IAEA because its safeguards have already failed to apply at this point in time. These fallback safeguards would surely come into operation only when the IAEA safeguards cease to apply. It says so in the statement.

Who is going to enforce the fallback safeguards? As I said, the people of Australia are being duped into believing we already have adequate safeguards. I will quote for instance, from the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) as reported at page 1,701 of Hansard, in the other place on 24 May 1977, when delivering the Government's policy on nuclear safeguards. I do not intend to read the entire speech, so perhaps it might be appropriate before I quote from it to seek leave to have the speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The future course of world nuclear development and the regime of international controls which should apply to such development are currently subjects of great international interest. In the past few weeks, for example, there has been an important statement by President Carter on nuclear energy in which he emphasised the need to restrain the spread of nuclear weapons or explosive capabilities without foregoing the tangible benefits of nuclear power. Again, at their recent Summit meeting, the Heads of Government of the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, West Germany, France, Japan and Italy committed themselves to increasing nuclear energy to help meet the world's energy requirements while reducing the risks of nuclear proliferation. They launched an urgent study to determine how best to fulfil these objectives. At the conclusion of the recent Salzburg Conference, the most important international conference held in recent years on all aspects of nuclear power, the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency referred to the agreement of the meeting that nuclear power was a necessary and irreplaceable source of the future energy supply to mankind for both the short and the longer term.

It is clear that there is widespread international concern to establish a framework of control within which the benefits which many countries see in the peaceful use of nuclear energy can be safely realised. These are issues of major international importance in their own right, but they have an added significance for Australia because of our potential as a supplier of uranium. They are issues on which I have already written to President Carter and Prime Minister Trudeau and on which the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) and Australian officials have held detailed consultations with the United States, Canada and other countries. They are issues which have been under the closest and most careful consideration from the moment the Government took office. In the present period of international reappraisal of these issues the Government is determined that Australia should play an active role with other countries in the search for, and achievement of, joint solutions.

A proliferation of nuclear facilities without adequate protection against diversion of material to nuclear weapons production or nuclear explosives would pose serious threats to international stability and peace, obviously inimical to Australia's interests and to global and regional security. It was for this reason that, in his address to the United Nations General Assembly last September, the Foreign Minister (Mr Peacock) described the strengthening of measures to prevent proliferation of nuclear weapons as a central and fundamental area in which Australia looks and hopes for early progress. This will remain the case whether or not Australia is ultimately to become a major exporter of uranium. The safeguards policy which we will follow is, in our view, appropriate for any country to follow whether it be a uranium supplier or consumer. I make clear from the outset that the term 'safeguards' is used here to denote the whole range of measures used to provide assurance that nuclear material supplied for peaceful purposes is not misused for non-peaceful or explosive purposes.

The Government fully accepts that, if it were in future to permit new uranium export from Australia, this would carry with it added responsibilities. Against the background of these international responsibilities the Government accepts that uranium is a special commodity, the export of which would involve important considerations of a kind not involved in the export of other commodities. This implies a requirement for selectivity in the choice of customer countries and the closest attention to ensuring adequate safeguards should be regarded as something to be balanced against commercial considerations. We view adequate safeguards as a fundamental prerequisite of any uranium export which we would also expect responsible customer countries for Australian uranium readily to accept.

It will be recalled that, following the release of the First Report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, the Government announced in the House on 11 November 1976 that it supported the Inquiry's view on the need for the fullest and most effective safeguards on uranium exports. The Government also stated that it was carrying forward more detailed consideration of safeguards in order to develop further a national policy on this subject. The announcement of a policy at this stage, of course, in no way pre-empts a decision on the question whether any such new contracts for the export of uranium will be permitted. As the Government has repeatedly emphasised, this remains a matter for consideration following receipt of the final report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. However, as the Foreign Minister said in the Government's foreign policy statement in the Parliament on 15 March 1977, the Government would be remiss if it did not address itself to safeguards questions in the meantime.

That the Government has taken certain decisions on safeguards policy at this stage reflects its determination to make sure that an established framework of policy exists so that any new uranium exports take place under the most carefully considered and responsible conditions possible. The Government wishes to avoid a situation in which decisions may be required on new uranium marketing at some point in the future without the benefit of a clear policy on the ground rules to apply so far as safeguards are concerned.

The Government has long recognised the desirability of defining a comprehensive policy on safeguards. It would not be desirable for safeguards requirements to be left to ad hoc decision as this would not afford the strong and clear support for international efforts to strengthen controls against nuclear weapons proliferation to which the Government attaches major importance. Australia is a potentially significant supplier of uranium, but if we are to play the part which this potential gives us the opportunity to play of contributing effectively to international efforts to strengthen the non-proliferation regime, it is desirable that uranium importing countries and other nuclear supplier countries alike know where Australia stands on the matter of safeguards. In the narrow sense, safeguards are systems of containment, surveillance, accounting and inspection of nuclear materials and facilities designed to verify that diversion does not take place from peaceful to non-peaceful or explosive purposes. The major systems of international safeguards are administered by the International Atomic Energy Agency. In a broader sense, safeguards for future Australian uranium exports would comprise, as well as the application of international safeguards in this strict sense, the securing from importing countries of adequate assurances regarding the use and control of supplied nuclear material and the conclusion of binding arrangements to give effect to such assurances. In both senses, as mechanisms for verification and as controls and conditions for nuclear exports, safeguards arrangements are an evolving structure, continually being strengthened, refined and improved.
Against this background, I would like to announce the following specific components of the comprehensive safeguards policy which the Government has adopted. These cover:

The need to keep policy under review; careful selection of eligible customers for uranium; the application of effective International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards; bilateral agreements with customer countries; fallback safeguards; prior Australian Government consent in relation to re-export, enrichment and reprocessing; physical security; safeguards provisions in contracts; and international and multilateral efforts to strengthen safeguards.

First, it will be a basic feature of our approach to recognise that the process of strengthening and improving international safeguards arrangements is an ongoing one. Our policy and safeguards arrangements must be kept closely under review to take account of the future evolution of international thinking on safeguards. In this regard the Government is pleased that, as recently announced, Mr Justice Fox has agreed to become an adviser to me on policy matters relating to nuclear non-proliferation and safeguards. Second, should the Government approve further development of the Australian uranium industry it will retain the right to be selective in the countries to whom uranium export will be permitted. The following minimum criteria for eligibility to receive Australian uranium will apply. The Government emphasises that these represent minimum conditions for countries to be eligible to receive Australian uranium. The Government makes clear that wider foreign policy considerations may also be taken into account, and that it reserves the right to refrain from permitting export should this be appropriate in the light of such considerations. It does not, therefore, follow that the Government would necessarily permit export to a country meeting these minimum safeguards criteria.

In the case of non-nuclear weapon states-that is to say, all countries other than the 5 existing nuclear weapons powers recognised by the Non-Proliferation Treaty-sales will be made only to countries which are parties to the Non-Proliferation Treaty. Because of these countries' safeguards obligations under the Non-Proliferation Treaty this policy will make sure that the entire civil nuclear industry in such customer countries is subject to effective safeguards to verify that nuclear material, whether of Australian or any other origin, is not diverted from peaceful uses. The Government is aware that work has recently been under way within the International Atomic Energy Agency on a new system of equally stringent safeguards to cover the entire nuclear industry in non-nuclear weapon states which are not parties to the Non-Proliferation Treaty. It will be following progress on this matter and the implications which it may have for our policy. Regarding existing nuclear weapon states, they are not obliged under the Non-Proliferation Treaty to renounce nuclear weapons or accept international safeguards. They retain the right to use nuclear material for weapons as well as for peaceful purposes. Even so, Australia would want to have assurance that nuclear material we may supply for peaceful purposes is not diverted to military or explosive purposes. We will therefore export only to nuclear weapon states which give Australia this assurance and accept that the uranium we supply be covered by International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards. In this respect the Government's policy introduces a requirement additional to those recommended by the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry in its first report.

Third, the Government wishes to ensure that if a decision is taken to permit new uranium export, the uranium will be covered by International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards from the time it leaves Australian ownership. As matters stand, while safeguards applied under the Non-Proliferation Treaty require notification of transfers of yellowcake, the full intensity of such safeguards only commences to apply later in the fuel cycle. Accordingly, it will be the Government's policy that any future sales arrangements for exports of Australian uranium should be such that the uranium will be in a form which attracts full International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards by the time it leaves Australian ownership. Fourth, Australia will require the prior conclusion of bilateral agreements between the Australian Government and countries wishing to import Australian uranium under any future contracts. These bilateral agreements will provide a framework for direct and binding assurances by importing countries to the Australian Government in relation to the use and control of uranium supplied from its use. The fundamental undertakings the Government will wish to obtain from uranium importing countries in such bilateral agreements are that nuclear material supplied by Australia for peaceful purposes or nuclear material derived from its use will not be diverted to military or explosive purposes and that International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards will apply to verify compliance with this undertaking. Australia would seek to arrange with uranium importing countries regular expert-level consultations to satisfy ourselves of the implementation of the provisions of bilateral agreements. In line with the positions taken by the United States and Canada Australia would retain the right to cease supply of uranium to any country which breached safeguards undertakings.

Fifth, the Government takes the view that nuclear material supplied by Australia or nuclear material derived from its use should remain under safeguards for the full life of the material in question or until it is legitimately removed from safeguards. In line with this basic principle the Government has decided that bilateral agreements with non-nuclear weapon states should make provision for so-called fallback safeguards. I have already made clear that Australia would not be prepared to export uranium to such countries in the absence of International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards applied under the Non-Proliferation Treaty. However, the question arises of ensuring the continued safeguarding of material already present in an importing country should safeguards under the Non-Proliferation Treaty at some stage cease to apply in that country. There should be provision under the bilateral agreements for the contained application of international safeguards in such circumstances. Further, the bilateral agreements should provide for Australia to make alternative arrangements for the safeguarding of nuclear material supplied by us in the event of international safeguards as such ceasing to operate. Moreover, the Government feels it is reasonable to ask importing countries who will already accept International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards of comprehensive scope under the Non-Proliferation Treaty, to accept that, at the first fallback level also, international safeguards should apply to all nuclear material not just that portion supplied by Australia.

Sixth, the Government considers that it would be an unsatisfactory situation for uranium supplied by Australia to one country, or nuclear material derived from its use, to be able to be re-exported to a third country without the opportunity for Australia to satisfy itself that adequate controls would apply to the transferred material and that the ultimate destination is acceptable to us. For this reason the Government has decided that bilateral agreements with uranium importing countries should make any transfer of supplied material to a third party contingent on a prior consent of the Australian Government. This provision will give Australia the means of making sure that our safeguards requirements are met despite any onward transfers of the uranium we supply or nuclear material derived from it.

Seventh, we would require that Australian uranium supplied to other countries for peaceful uses not be enriched beyond 20 per cent uranium-235 without prior Australian consent. This provision is in line with the practice adopted by other nuclear supplier countries. The figure of 20 per cent has been chosen as representing a level of enrichment below the practical requirements for a nuclear explosive, while being above the enrichment level required for most peaceful uses, excepting, for example, some research and radioisotope production reactors, for which approval to enrich to the necessary level would need to be obtained. In respect of this requirement also, the Government's policy extends beyond the recommendations made by the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry in its first report.

Eighth, the Government is aware of the interest of some countries in the reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel to meet their anticipated future fuel requirements, and to facilitate the management of nuclear material following its use in nuclear reactors. At the present time the need for reprocessing and the details of an effective control regime for this area of the nuclear fuel cycle are the subject of close study internationally. This is an area in which there are a number of new ideas and initiatives. The United States has proposed an international nuclear fuel cycle evaluation program to consider various nuclear fuel cycles in terms of their implications for proliferation control. There are also such ideas as various schemes for multinational control of reprocessing facilities and for the management of spent fuel and plutonium. The Government welcomes these studies and consultations and will seek to contribute actively and constructively to relevant aspects of them such as fuel supply assurances and waste management.

The Government's view is that, prior to a clearer outcome emerging from this current international activity, it would be premature for Australia to adopt a unilateral position on the detailed conditions under which we might be prepared to agree to reprocessing, if any, of nuclear material supplied by Australia. In order to reserve effectively Australia's position on this matter for the time being we would wish to make provision in bilateral agreements with countries importing Australian uranium that any reprocessing of nuclear material supplied by Australia may only take place with the prior consent of the Australian Government. This requirement is additional to those recommended by the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry in its first report and reflects similar concerns to those expressed by the inquiry in relation to reprocessing.

Ninth, the Government would require in future bilateral agreements the assurance from uranium importing countries that adequate physical security will be maintained on their nuclear industries. In addition, we believe the agreements should specify compliance with standards of physical security based, at a minimum, on International Atomic Energy Agency recommendations as presently defined and as updated from time to time. They should also make provision for expert level consultations as necessary on physical security arrangements. These requirements also translate into concrete policy measures concerns expressed by the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry. The incorporation of these provisions in the Government's safeguards policy reflects our concern that total nuclear control should encompass safeguards not just to verify that nuclear material is not illicitly diverted from peaceful uses by national governments or national authorities, but also to protect nuclear material from illegal use by groups or individuals.

Tenth, the establishment of effective arrangements for safeguards is essentially a matter for governments and for inter-governmental agreements, either bilateral or multilateral. Nevertheless, it is important to make sure that the actual parties to commercial contracts, which may be private organisations, are also aware of the safeguards obligations to which their transaction is subject. For this reason, although the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry in its first report did not make a recommendation on this matter, the Government has decided that it is desirable that, as a standard practice, a clause should be included in any future contracts for the export of uranium from Australia noting that the transaction is subject to safeguards as agreed between the importing country and the Australian Government.

Finally, as an important complement to the measures I have outlined so far, the Government recognises the importance of Australia contributing to constructive multilateral efforts to strengthen safeguards. There is a need for what President Carter has described as systematic and thorough consultations in this area. We too consider that it is highly desirable that there should be the widest possible consensus amongst both nuclear supplier countries and nuclear importing countries on the controls to apply to the world nuclear industry. The wider the consensus, the more effective these controls will be as a barrier to nuclear proliferation. The more uniform the views of the countries concerned, the easier it will be to implement a properly effective regime of controls. It will be an integral part of Australia's approach to safeguards to seek to promote such a consensus.

In particular, we will seek to co-ordinate policy on safeguards with other like-minded countries. As I noted at the outset, I have already initiated an exchange of correspondence with the President of the United States and the Prime Minister of Canada expressing this wish, and extremely valuable consultations have already taken place. The policy I am now announcing incorporates the Government's consideration of these consultations and represents a very similar approach to safeguards to that adopted by the United States and Canada. More generally, nuclear supplier countries have a special role and responsibility in the ongoing development of safeguards and Australia will be prepared to participate with them in any constructive efforts to develop a co-ordinated approach. We will also continue to attach major importance to the effective application of safeguards by the International Atomic Energy Agency. We will investigate whether there are specific areas in which Australia could usefully assist the Agency's capacity to apply increasingly effective safeguards.

At the present time the Government sees a multilateral approach towards safeguards questions as being especially desirable in one specific area as well as in the international nuclear fuel cycle evaluation program already mentioned; we would wish to lend support to the development of an international convention on the physical protection of nuclear material in international transit. Also, we would wish to explore with other countries a common approach to sanctions in the event of a breach of supply conditions.

The essential ingredients of the policy I have outlined are careful selection of customer countries, the application of international safeguards to verify that material supplied for peaceful purposes is not misused, the establishment of additional safeguards through bilateral agreements, and an active involvement by Australia in international efforts to upgrade safeguards. The policy is the result of full, careful and detailed consideration of safeguards by the Government. It builds on the preliminary thinking of the Government described in testimony to the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry last year, as well as the recommendations of the First Report of the Inquiry itself. The policy has been the subject of detailed exchanges of views with other countries-both uranium importers and major nuclear exporters-and relevant international organisations including the International Atomic Energy Agency.

As a result the Government is satisfied that the policy it has decided upon represents a practical, reasonable and effective package of safeguards measures to seek from countries wishing to import uranium from Australia under any future contracts. It is fully in step with current international efforts to strengthen safeguards. The policy goes beyond a mere acceptance by Australia of our international obligations as a party to the Non-Proliferation Treaty and constitutes a policy as stringent as that adopted to date by any nuclear supplier country. I present the following paper:
Nuclear Safeguards Policy-Ministerial Statement, 24 May 1977.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech contains many questions in itself. If refers also to fallback safeguards and speaks of special conditions which will apply when we supply uranium to nuclear weapons states. In reference to existing nuclear weapons states the Prime Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding existing nuclear weapon states, they are not obliged under the Non-Proliferation Treaty to renounce nuclear weapons or accept international safeguards. They retain the right to use nuclear material for weapons as well as for peaceful purposes. Even so, Australia would want to have assurance that nuclear material we may supply for peaceful purposes is not diverted to military or explosive purposes. We will therefore export only to nuclear weapon states which give Australia this assurance and accept that the uranium we supply be covered by International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards. In this respect the Government's policy introduces a requirement additional to those recommended by the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry in its first report.
Later on the Prime Minister said:

. . . the Government considers that it would be an unsatisfactory situation for uranium supplied by Australia to one country, or nuclear material derived from its use, to be able to be re-exported to a third country without the opportunity for Australia to satisfy itself that adequate controls would apply to the transferred material and that the ultimate destination is acceptable to us. For this reason the Government has decided that bilateral agreement with uranium importing countries should make any transfer of supplied material to a third party contingent on a prior consent of the Australian Government. This provision will give Australia the means of making sure that our safeguards requirements are met despite any onward transfers of the uranium we supply or nuclear material derived from it.

That statement gives us no guarantee at all that material supplied to one country and through it to another country will comply with the safeguard standards we have established in Australia. As I have said, I do not believe the safeguards or standards are adequate; they are not. The ministerial statement gives another little gem. It is not necessary to read far into the statement to start knocking holes in the agreements. On page 2 it is stated:

The agreements provide for administrative arrangements to ensure implementation of their provisions and the tracking of Australian supplied material throughout the fuel cycles of customer countries. These detailed procedures enable us to verify that there is no diversion of Australian supplied material to non-peaceful purposes.

I would like a member on the Government bench to tell me how on earth we are going to do that. Are we saying that in some magical way uranium from Australia will be tagged so that in actual fact we can track it throughout the fuel cycles of customer countries? Are we going to propose that they make the uranium bright purple in colour so that we will recognise it if it comes back to us in the form of a nuclear weapon? It is a ridiculous statement. I am sure honourable senators will agree with that view. It is contained in what is supposed to be a responsible statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Are we going perhaps to station personnel in every country to which we sell our uranium to make sure that ours is not used for any other than peaceful purposes? How are we going to monitor the Australian material or track it, as the statement says, throughout the fuel cycles of customer countries? On page 2 it further states:

The agreements concluded with France and Sweden include settlements on reprocessing in accordance with the Government's policy of maintaining Australia's prior consent rights over reprocessing of Australian origin nuclear material, while establishing conditions under which this consent may be exercised in our bilateral agreements.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs announced in Parliament on 27 November 1980 the Government's policy on these conditions:

The Agreement with Canada keeps open the possibility of agreeing on conditions for reprocessing if the need should arise in the future. Neither Canada nor Australia at present envisages reprocessing nuclear material supplied by the other.

Now we are getting down to the guts of what the matter is all about. We are now talking about the real issue-reprocessing. We are not really just talking about nuclear agreements for domestic or energy purposes; we are talking about reprocessing. There is only one reason why governments want to reprocess; it is not for peaceful purposes. Again, the bland statement towards the end of that paragraph informs us:
Neither Canada nor Australia at present envisages reprocessing nuclear material supplied by the other.

I am not aware that Australia is purchasing nuclear material supplied by Canada. In other words, this is a one sided agreement. It does not apply. There is no point in saying that neither Canada nor Australia at present envisages reprocessing nuclear material supplied by the other because we are not purchasing it from Canada; Canada is purchasing the material from Australia. That is what this agreement is all about. It is one of those agreements people are supposed to read but not question. It talks about processing nuclear material supplied by the other but we are not receiving any from Canada; Canada is receiving our uranium. We have the agreement in front of us.

When we get into the area of reprocessing we are really talking about nuclear weapons; we are not talking about the use for peaceful purposes of uranium to provide nuclear energy. The statement really does not do a great deal because we do not even get the real truth of the matter until we reach the addendums attached to the agreements. In annexe D of the French Agreement we have one of the most extraordinary provisions I have ever seen in an agreement between Australia and another country. Annex D is headed 'Enrichment to 20 per cent or greater in the isotope U235'. It states:
Whereas Article IX.2 of the Agreement provides that NMSA shall only be enriched to 20 per cent or greater in the isotope U235 according to conditions agreed upon in writing the Parties;
The Parties to the Agreement,
Declare that they shall not at present--
I stress the words 'at present'-
enrich NMSA to 20 per cent or greater in the isotope U235; and

Agree to consult within 30 days of the receipt of a request from either Party to consider proposals for conditions to be agreed upon in writing according to which NMSA may be enriched to 20 per cent or greater of the isotope U235.
I repeat that Annex D states:
. . . Declare that they shall not at present enrich NMSA to 20 per cent or greater in the isotope U235; and
Agree to consult within 30 days of the receipt of a request from either Party to consider proposals . . .

How could we have an agreement by Australia when, in actual fact, the agreement is between France, Sweden and Canada with Australia? We are not importing uranium from any of those countries so it is one way request for consultation. The request for consultation could come from only those countries. It could not come from us. Why would we be proposing that they enrich their uranium to 20 per cent or greater? That is amazing. Yet, that suggestion is in Annex D as though it is a normal practice and as though this is one of the matters that we should be considering.

Let us suppose that we have been able to track our Australian uranium all the way through the domestic fuel cycle of a customer country and we receive a request for a consultation on the possibility of enriching uranium to 20 per cent or more. Will we have the opportunity to say no? In an interjection in the other place Mr Street said:
We have to consent to it.

But will we be able to say: 'No, you cannot do this'? How will we say no? How on earth will we stop them? We are not dealing with little children. We will not be able to smack them on the hand, call them a naughty boy or a naughty girl and say: 'You must not do that again' or 'You must not do that'. If those countries have the potential already in their countries, regardless of whether it is Australian uranium, they will tell us to get lost and we will not have a single leg to stand on. There is no way that we will be able to identify uranium from Australia being used for enrichment. No one can identify the uranium. Anybody who has been working in the nuclear energy field would confirm that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the thimble and pea trick.

—It certainly is a thimble and pea trick. One would think we were talking about peanuts or peas and thimbles instead of something that could affect the whole world. Talk about apple pie! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Lionel Bowen, raised the matter of Annex D of the French agreement in the other place on 26 March this year in the general debate on the nuclear safeguards agreements. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The only real reason that one would talk about enriching uranium to 20 per cent or more would be if one wanted to get towards what is called weapons grade. Why would one want to suggest that? France has been given this peculiar advantage in that she can put forward proposals that the parties enrich uranium above 20 per cent.
To that, as I said, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, interjected:
But we have to consent to it.

But he does not say what will happen if we do not give our consent. That is the question that I am asking. I would welcome any member on the Government side telling me what will happen if we say no. What would be the situation if France says to Australia: 'Look here, old fellow, we want to enrich your uranium to 20 per cent or perhaps more, to which we say, 'No, you cannot do it' and France says: 'Tough cheddar; we will go right ahead and do it anyway'? There is no way that we could stop France. There is not one single action we could take because the uranium is already in France and it is already capable of being enriched.

We continue to make fine speeches particularly about disarmament and enrichment of uranium. The former Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Honourable Andrew Peacock, at the inaugural session of the Committee on Disarmament held in Geneva on 24 January 1979-two years ago- said:
Arms control disarmament are the gravest problems facing the world today. Solutions are imperative.

Yet in an agreement Australia is virtually saying that France will be able to enrich to 20 per cent or more because there is no way that we can stop her. We are providing the material for the most horrific weapons that man has yet devised.
The Prime Minister has had his piece to say about disarmament too. When he announced that Australia was giving the go ahead on uranium in August 1977 he assured us:
Our aim is to minimise the risk of nuclear weapons proliferation.

How does that tie in with the agreement that has been signed on behalf of Australia? Foreign Minister Peacock spelt out the steps Australia believed should be taken to minimise the risk of nuclear weapons at the inaugural meeting of the Committee on disarmament. He said:

Australia believes that the starting point for further progress in nuclear arms control should be the establishment of an international environment which will remove the motifivation to possess nuclear wapons, deter their acquisition and provide non-nuclear weapons states with security against nuclear attack.

How on earth could we provide non-nuclear weapon states with security against a nuclear attack if we did not provide them with the where-withal to create their own nuclear weapons? That is what it will take. There is not any way that we can provide security against a nuclear weapon attack without nuclear weapons. He said:
Our efforts need to embrace:
substantial limitations and subsequent reductions in existing arsenals
the complete cessation of nuclear weapons testing in all environments.

Is that not classic? We are debating an agreement between Australia and France, which has already been signed, when we know that France is perhaps the greatest perpetrator of nuclear weapons testing. Already nuclear weapons have been tested by France at Mururoa Atoll in the Pacific. Tonight we heard Senator Puplick inform us that France is seriously considering moving its nuclear weapons testing to the Antarctic. Yet we are signing an agreement that will provide France with the necessary equipment to continue its proliferation of nuclear weapons. France is not even a signatory to the Non-Proliferation Treaty. It can do just as it likes, not that the Non-Proliferation Treaty would be any guarantee that France would not do what it likes. In 1968 France said that it was not going to sign the Treaty but it promised to behave in a similar manner to those countries which did sign it. Was that not generous?

As I have said, we have had the experience of Mururoa Atoll and the nuclear weapons testing in the Pacific. Surely to heaven we have learnt by now that France cannot be trusted and that it is perhaps the most immoral country when it comes to nuclear weapons. How can it say that it will not sign the non-proliferation treaty but will act in a responsible manner as other signatories to the treaty will be expected to act and yet go ahead with the weapons testing it has been conducting at Mururoa? What control have we had over those activities and what control would we have over any other activities if France wanted to enrich our uranium to 20 per cent or more? I have said and I repeat that there is no way that we could enforce an agreement if France decided to dishonour that agreement. We are not talking about gentlemen's agreements and a shake of the hand across the board room table. We are talking about the world. We have to be concerned about the world. Not just Australia and not just France are involved. We are talking about the whole world. Let us look at other most important matters which the Foreign Minister in 1979, Andrew Peacock, saw as being important. He said:
the prevention of the spread of nuclear weapons to countries not yet possessing them.

How on earth could we prevent that? How on earth could we prevent France, Sweden or Canada from providing countries which do not have nuclear weapons at this time with those weapons? If they wanted to sneak them in the back door, how would we know? If they wanted to use Australian uranium, how would we know? Mr Peacock went on to say:
measures to ensure that the use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes does not contribute to the proliferation of nuclear weapons
the cessation of the production of fissionable material for nuclear weapons purposes
satisfactory security assurances for non-nuclear weapon states confidence building measures which will limit the danger of nuclear war through miscalculation or the failure of communication.

The Fraser Government has been very big on talking about its commitment to nuclear arms control and disarmament. Its recent actions merely confirm that its real interest is in quick profits for big companies in an industry which is neither proven to be safe nor able to ensure an answer to the world's long term energy needs and which, by its own admission, provides the means by which more and more countries may produce nuclear weapons and heighten rather than diffuse the prospect of a nuclear holocaust.

We have heard our own Prime Minister say that it is possible that we will have a nuclear war within three years. Any decision by this Government to allow other nations to reprocess spent nuclear fuel derived from Australian supplied uranium will make it possible for customer countries to extract, amongst other things, plutonium, which is a major material used in nuclear weapons. Despite the Government's pathetic protests that it in no way seeks to encourage the production of nuclear weapons, only a fool would be convinced that, with the flimsy qualification that customer countries will be required to 'demonstrate and to comply with Australian safeguards on storage and non-proliferation of nuclear weapons', there is any real safeguard. What do we do, for instance, if one of our customer countries informs us that some of our uranium is missing? That has happened before, and it has happened in Australia. I will refer to that matter in a moment.

Let me remind the Senate of a few other instances of shipments of uranium going missing and turning up in unexpected places. On 10 April 1969 a 8,500 lb shipment of enriched uranium from Goodyear Atomic Corporation to New York turned up in Cleveland, Ohio. There was no reason for its being there; it just went in the wrong direction. In India, in May 1974, police arrested five members of the personnel of a uranium enrichment plant and discovered that they had 3.6 kilograms of uranium. Inquiries revealed that a gang which stole uranium transported it through Nepal eventually to end up in Hong Kong. Where did it go after it had been through Hong Kong?

In the United States, on 2 February 1979, the Federal Bureau of Investigation recovered 68 kilograms of uranium stolen by an employee at the General Electric plant at Wilmington in North Carolina. On 11 May 1979, in France-Senator Primmer will probably recall this incident-a man tried to kill his employer with radioactive discs which he had placed under the seat of his car. Where did he get the discs from?

TALK.START.PARA: —He put him in the hot seat.

—Yes. He did not worry about the emission of radiation. In the United States, on 9 October 1979, police found tiny glass tubes filled with radioactive tritium in a vacant lot near the American Atomic Corporation factory.
—It couldn't happen to nicer people.

—Charming! In Australia, on 31 October 1979, in a report in the West Australian-I have pointed out in this place many times that the West Australian is possibly the most conservative of all newspapers in the conservative Press in this country-the following report appeared:

SPEECH.PARA: Bushwalkers and children have access to a chemical dump at Australind where low level radioactive waste is stored.
The waste is radium 228, with a half-life of six years, and radium 226, with a half-life of 1,600 years.
The dump is on private land about 200 metres from the Collie River where bushwalkers often go.

That is charming! I want to refer to uranium and to those types of products which have gone missing in Australia. Honourable senators will recall that on 8 August last year it was found that quite a deal of uranium had been going missing from the Mary Kathleen mine, presumably over a lengthy period. People do not just cart out 2,200 kilograms of uranium overnight. It has to come from somewhere, and it is generally taken in little bits so that people do not realise that it is missing. On 16 August another man was charged with the theft of a further 220 kilograms of uranium oxide from the Mary Kathleeen uranium mine.

What do we do if we are told by some of our customer countries-these people with whom we are signing agreements and to whom we are selling our uranium-that some of our shipment is missing? I do not know.

I was hoping that some of the Government members would be able to tell me a little more clearly just what it is that these nuclear safeguard agreements are supposed to mean. At the moment they do not mean very much at all to me. As I have already pointed out, the agreements are with France, Canada and Sweden. I have no reason to trust France and I am sure that many people in Australia feel very strongly about the Australian Government entering into any sort of nuclear safeguard agreement with France after the attitudes it has portrayed in the Pacific in regard to its nuclear testing. I believe Australia does have a part to play, even if it is only secondary to and perhaps even dependent upon the actions of the super-powers.

I am disturbed that as long ago as 1978 we were told that Australia was already spending $7m a day on arms. I think there are much more useful and peaceful ways in which $7m a day could be expended in this country. As I have already said, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Peacock, on 24 January 1979 said that arms control and disarmament are the gravest problems facing the world today and that solutions are imperative. Solutions are imperative. They come closer to reality now, not necessarily because of the fact that we have these agreements, but because these agreements mean so little. It is an incredible situation to find oneself in-recognising that we have a need to assist those countries which do not have energy supplies and realising the small amounts by comparison which are going into the discovery and continuation of other worthwhile fuel energy cycles.

I was interested to hear Dr Mark Diesendorf from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation speaking on a talkback radio program in Western Australia yesterday, prior to my leaving for Canberra. Some of the things that he had to say were extremely interesting, including the fact that we cannot have just one nuclear energy station. If we are to operate on nuclear energy all the time, there must be two stations, which doubles the problem.

We are talking tonight on the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) on nuclear safeguard agreements with Canada, France and Sweden. I wonder how much governments, and the Australian Government in particular, understand about the enrichment process. I question whether in actual fact they are aware that plutonium metal will be created whether the reactor is in fact intended to make bombs or whether it is intended to have much larger quantities come from reprocessing plants built purposely to reprocess that substance. The Australian Government has stated that reprocessing cannot be undertaken without prior consent from Australia. As I have said, this is not an easy provision to enforce. In fact, short of massive interference in the internal affairs of the recipient countries, Australia could not possibly enforce that provision.

I do not believe that Australians are being fooled by a government which is attempting to conceal its utter contempt and disregard for the principles of non-proliferation behind this non-existent safeguard, because it is a non-existent safeguard. There is no way in which we can guarantee to anybody in Australia that our uranium will not be used in the proliferation of nuclear weapons. I think the Government has failed to take into consideration the catastrophic consequences that could follow from the passing of plutonium into the wrong hands. I believe it is a matter of the gravest national importance yet no concern was expressed either in the statement presented to the Parliament or in the agreements. I hope that we are not too cynical and too totally irresponsible to forget John Donne's famous and appropriate line:
No man is an Island, entire of itself;

We are not an island, we may be an island continent. But we have to be concerned for the safety and the security of the whole world. Senator Mason in a previous speech pointed to the pitifully inadequate safeguards announced by the Government. He said:

How can we be assured that governments keep their agreements. What would happen in the event of a coup d'etat such as that recently in South Korea in which a new military regime could renounce previous agreements? In this case plutonium held in storage could then be diverted readily and quickly to the production of small high fall-out type A bombs-fission weapons capable of global nuclear pollution-and could even be used to attack Australia.

The Government's policy may place Australians at greater risk of a nuclear attack. Nations such as France and Japan, which it seems are the only two nations so far which will be allowed to reprocess uranium, cannot give guarantees that every government from now to eternity will abide by the rules of the uranium game according to Malcolm Fraser. According to Malcolm Fraser, it is a game. We are playing with people's lives. We are playing with the future of children on this earth.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be from now to eternity.

—It certainly will be from now to eternity. It seems clear to me that Mr Fraser has forgotten or perhaps never meant his words of 1979 which I quoted earlier. He said that the Government's aim was to minimise the risk of nuclear weapons proliferation. Yet none of these agreements does just that. If anything, they maximise the risk of nuclear weapons proliferation. I, for one, am not prepared to accept as a fact of life, as Mr Anthony has put it, the export and reprocessing of Australian uranium and the obvious implications of greater access and stockpiling of nuclear weapons by formerly non-nuclear weapons possessing countries.

SPEECH.PARA: In this world only a handful of people will benefit either directly or indirectly from the development of nuclear power and specifically nuclear weapons. Yet that fact of life is forcibly being imposed on us. Who is going to benefit? Not many Australians will benefit. Who, I wonder, will protect them when nuclear war becomes a reality? If people want to know how ill-prepared Australia is for that eventuality they should contact their special emergency services to get hold of a document which shows what to do in case of a nuclear attack. It is a gem. It is something that every Australian should read. Some of the documents go back to 1968. They have not been updated.

In Western Australia Dr Geoff Williams has just been given a grant of $100,000 by the Western Australian Government to study something like 127 buildings in the Perth city area which are considered to have nuclear safe areas. It is incredible that $100,000 is to be spent on a survey of about 127 buildings that are considered to be safe in the event of a nuclear attack on Perth. I suppose that is all right if one happens to be in or near one of those buildings and enough warning is given to enable one to get into the basements of those buildings where one apparently will be safe.

We live in strange times. It is strange to me because it is clear that the overwhelming majority of people throughout the world want peace. The declaration of the international conference for zones of peace in the Indian and the Pacific Oceans as long ago as 1978 expressed concern that we could in actual fact assist mankind better by creating a zone of peace, by declaring the whole nation a zone of peace. What a wonderful thought that is. We know that we do not have a government committed so deeply to peace or to peaceful purposes that it will do anything about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is selling us into a zone of war.

—It is indeed. At this time, whether we like it or not, we are a zone of war. Australia is prepared to sell the potential for nuclear weapons to almost anybody, as I have said. France is the most immoral country that one could imagine so far as nuclear weapons testing is concerned, yet we are selling her our uranium. A special clause is contained in the agreement which says that in all probability Australia will give consent to enriching uranium to 20 per cent. I want to conclude my remarks by referring to two important quotations. Paragraph 47 of the Final Document of the Tenth Special Session of the General Assembly of the United Nations held on 30 June 1978 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Nuclear weapons pose the greatest danger to mankind and to the survival of civilisation. It is essential to halt and reverse the nuclear arms race in all its aspects in order to avert the danger of war involving nuclear weapons. The ultimate goal in this context is the complete elimination of nuclear weapons.

Yet here tonight we are discussing the wherewithal to manufacture those nuclear weapons. The final quotation to which I wish to refer comes from President Franklin D. Roosevelt, in his address to Congress on 6 January 1941. He said:
The fourth--
He was referring to a principle or ideal-

is freedom from fear-which, translated into world terms, means a world-wide reduction of armaments to such a point and in such a thorough fashion that no nation will be in a position to commit an act of physical aggression against any neighbour-anywhere in the world.

I totally reject these agreements. Unfortunately, they have already been signed. I am not a lone voice on this side of the chamber but there is no voice from honourable senators opposite. Not one honourable senator opposite is prepared to debate these very important agreements tonight. They are supposed to be safeguards agreements with France, Canada and Sweden on the provision of our uranium and the nuclear safeguards that will apply. It seems a great shame to me that we will not have the opportunity to hear words of wisdom from the Government benches. I think it is about time the Government recognised its priorities. Obviously, nuclear safeguards agreements is not one of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on these agreements. I appreciate the final comments of my colleague, Senator Coleman. I just said to another colleague: 'I feel I am singing an old song to a tired audience'. At times one wonders whether in this place it is worth rising to comment on these matters. It is not worthless making these comments outside because more and more Australian people understand what honourable senators on this side of the chamber are saying when they are talking about the whole nuclear industry and its proliferation into armament. It would appear that honourable senators opposite no longer want to comment. I do not believe that honourable senators opposite do not understand the very real problems that are attached to the nuclear industry and to our assistance in the proliferation of nuclear arms by mining uranium. I think they understand very well the problems. The Government has been painted into a corner by the uranium miners and the nuclear industry. It appears that there is no longer anybody on the other side of the chamber with sufficient courage or the stomach to face up to the arguments that need to be put in this particular instance.
—They are locked into their system. They cannot object to it.

—Honourable senators opposite know that nuclear war is threatened. They know that there are no safeguards so far as nuclear war is concerned and they know that Australia is providing the material from which those nuclear weapons will be made. Much is made in the statement attached to the agreements about the fact that the Government believes in and is working actively to enhance the international non-proliferation regime through action in multilateral bodies, but at the same time as it is saying that it is allowing American B52 bombers to use bases in Australia. The Government tells us that we should not be concerned because the Americans will use them only to train their pilots in navigation. It tells us that the B52s are unarmed. Of course it omits to tell us that, in military parlance, saying a bomber is unarmed does not mean that it is not carrying bombs; it just means that those bombs are not primed at that particular time. The Government hides behind such words. It knows very well that we are threatened with nuclear war and it admits that there is no safeguard. I have proof of that in a letter from the Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, in which he said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: A complete protection against the effects of the explosion of nuclear weapons is not a practicable civil defence objective for any country.
He continued:
. . . successive Australian Governments have taken the view that our primary concern should be to support the effectiveness of the US deterrent to war itself.

We know what the United States deterrent is. It includes such things as B52 bombers carrying nuclear weapons that will land on our shores and paint us into whatever deterrent action the United States of America is going to take. That is the sort of proposition we have from the Government, and no Government member has enough guts to stand up here and put up an argument for it. The statement talks about our active role in the Committee on Disarmament. What is our active role in that Committee? It is providing the wherewithal for nuclear weapons. Certainly I have not seen any statement from this Government which says: 'We believe in peace. We will fight for peace. We will be for peace in any circumstances.' Instead, we have a Government which, from the sorts of statements it has made, is hell bent on provoking anything but peace in places such as Afghanistan, El Salvador and Poland. Where is there one statement from one Government Minister which says: 'We believe in all circumstances in peace, and we will fight for peace'? There are plenty of statements about deterrents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plenty of statements about war.

—Plenty of statements about war. Our active role in the Committee on Disarmament is referred to, while we provide the very material from which nuclear weapons are made. The statement talks about our continuing work to encourage such studies as those on plutonium storage, spent fuel management and assurance of supply, all of which are geared to a continuation of the supply of the material from which nuclear weapons are made, and the upgrading of international safeguards measures, particularly in respect of proliferation-sensitive technologies. What are we doing in that respect? Nothing-no research, no statements, and no active turning of our backs on nuclear war. We are told in the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Agreements is to ensure that when Australia supplies uranium for peaceful purposes it will not be diverted to non-peaceful or explosive uses.

It does not say whether these agreements apply to the source materials, such as yellowcake, or whether they apply only after enrichment. If they apply only to the source materials such as yellowcake, that is just so many words on paper. There is no way in which we can stop yellowcake once it has been enriched from being diverted to non-peaceful or explosive uses. The statement goes on:
These safeguards and controls remain in place over all Australian origin nuclear material so long as the material remains relevant from the point of view of safeguards as determined by the IAEA;

For what sort of period are we covering this material? For how long does that sort of mealy-mouthed statement apply? We will keep the safeguards covering the material so long as it remains relevant from the point of view of safeguards as determined by the International Atomic Energy Agency. There are no safeguards determined by the IAEA at this moment, so what safeguards are we talking about? What safeguards are we putting on this material? If we are talking about the life of the material, that is, the time over which that material can be used, we are talking about a period of over 1,000 years. Are we seriously proposing that these agreements can be kept in force and will safeguard this material for that length of time? As the Opposition has said before, no era has lasted, no regime has remained in control, for anything like that period. What reason do we have to believe that any civilisation of which we are a part will be able to control material for anything like that period?

Nowhere does this document tell us how countries can retreat from this arrangement. We know that under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons countries are required to give only 90 days notice and they can then say: 'That's it. We are out of it.' Does that apply to these agreements too? If it does not apply, and if these agreements are to stay in force for 1,000 years, what will we do if a country says: 'Sorry, it does not suit us any more'? Nothing. We have supplied the material with which civilisation can be obliterated and we have absolutely no way of enforcing these mealy-mouthed safeguards. Part of the proposal talks about fallback safeguards. They can provide for the prohibition of explosive or military use, the application of the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards-fallback safeguards, in the event that IAEA safeguards cease to apply. Those IAEA safeguards do not apply now, so will somebody please tell us what the fallback safeguards are? What fallback position can we possibly have when dealing with this sort of material? This renowned document refers to:
prior consent rights over reprocessing, high enrichment and transfers to third countries, as well as internationally recognised levels of physical protection.

Will somebody please tell me what are the internationally recognised levels of physical protection? There is none, as we all know. We all know that it is impossible to impose them, so what is the point of drawing them up? It is just so much hot air. Further, the statement talks about our exporting of uranium under stringent safeguards. I should like to know what sort of stringent safeguards apply when at this very moment drums of yellowcake are being sneaked out of Darwin under all sorts of cloak and dagger conditions. They are being flown into Darwin from the mine site, sneaked on to planes and flown out to Singapore, to go where? We are told that their final destination may be Japan but they will have to be enriched before they get there. We have no way of knowing where those drums of yellowcake have gone. After a drum of yellowcake is taken into a country, to expect the people of Australia or the people of the world to believe that the exact material comes out of that country again is just hypocritical nonsense. There is no way in the world whereby, once a drum of yellowcake has been tipped into an enrichment plant, we can ever know where our yellowcake has gone, what bomb it finishes up in, which country it annihilates, how many people it kills in a thousand years time. The Minister for Foreign Affairs told us further in the statement:
. . . the Government has developed an approach to reprocessing which fully satisfies the Government's non-proliferation concerns.

If I can say so cynically, I agree that it probably has, because the Government has not got any non-proliferation concerns. So the very fact that it has developed such an approach to reprocessing is probably the truest statement in the whole document. If we accepted that an Australian government did have a concern about non-proliferation, how on earth could we believe in this nuclear world where there are no accounting processes, no monitoring procedures and no reliable procedures or processes to prevent a small but significant amount of plutonium being diverted, it could write into a document a phrase to the effect that the reprocessing procedures that have been set out fully satisfy its non-proliferation concern?

It is common knowledge that all over the world plutonium has been lost, stolen, diverted or whatever term we like to use. It has gone from being officially used for nuclear power to countries or to people who want to produce nuclear weapons. That has been proved over and over again. Small amounts perhaps are involved, but large amounts are not needed to make nuclear weapons. The situation has even reached the point, as my colleague Senator Coleman pointed out, that ordinary people are using this sort of material for their own ends to wreak revenge. In a case which came before the French courts only last month the French Government charged a man who had planted radioactive substances in a car belonging to his boss. A newspaper report of the case stated, in part:
It . . . revealed weaknesses in security at the Leastone nuclear decontamination centre.
The report stated that the man in question said that he found three tubes containing radioactive substances under the driving seat of his car, and it continued:
The tubes were thrown back into a pool at the company's headquarters.
In the pool, nuclear wastes in tubes from all over Europe are dropped for decontamination . . .
Expert witnesses said it was easy for Lecomte to fish some of the tubes out of the pool, stuff them into plastic containers to protect himself from radiation and put them under Busin's car . . .
The newspaper Le Figaro said: 'Engineers at the decontamination company admit that no adequate equipment has been invented to prevent the theft of radioactive material.
'A thief has only to know the area to avoid setting off the alarm sirens. It is all rather frightening.'

It is all rather frightening right across the spectrum because we cannot guard even small portions of material that have been discarded from the nuclear industry and are being kept for some sort of disposal. The material to which I have just referred was being kept for decontamination. It could not be guarded. We cannot guard the material that sails the high seas in ships. We cannot guard the material that is carried by road in trucks. We cannot guard the material that is carried by railroads. We cannot guard the material that is put in waste dumps. We cannot guard the material that is sent into factories to make high-grade nuclear weapons. Nobody in the world has found a way in which to guard that material and Australia is the country that supplies the raw material in those sorts of instances.
One of the agreements under discussion is with Sweden. In the statement accompanying the presentation to the Senate of the Agreement it was stated:
Sweden . . . has a firm commitment to nuclear power confirmed in a referendum last year . . .

That is a little less than the truth. Sweden has a commitment to nuclear power to the year 2000, if it cannot produce the power from any other source in that time, and a commitment to be free of nuclear power after the year 2000.
