This week the news came that Sweden is opening its own mine, against some strong opposition from the Swedes themselves who see the opening of a mine as a way to destroy their water supply and an area where their deer graze. Once Sweden has opened its mine, if it does, and once material is produced from that mine, how will we differentiate between Swedish uranium and Australian uranium? There is no way in which we will be able to do so. So we will be seen by the Swedish people as being a party to the destruction of their country as uranium destroys their water supply and their pastures. The Government could at least be honest about Sweden. It could honestly say what the position is. It could honestly say that a great number of Swedes are against the Swedish nuclear program and are working very hard to see to it that Sweden does not go nuclear or goes nuclear to the least possible extent. Instead the Government suggested in its statement that all Swedes are going all the way with nuclear power and will continue being all the way with nuclear power into the future.

My colleagues have already questioned the role that France plays in nuclear proliferation. France is an unabashed nuclear weapons country which has not signed the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. It is a country to which we have gone cap in hand begging it to buy our uranium to the point where in 1979 permission was given to the uranium miners to conclude conditional contracts with the French before any safeguards such as these were drawn up or had actually been signed-so hungry are the uranium miners for some return and so stupid does Australia appear to be. The statement talks about the IAEA and its verification activities in France. That will not be of any comfort to us because for one thing the IAEA has admitted that it has not got anything like the number of inspectors it would need to keep a close watch on activities in France and we know very well in any case that France is of no mind to let inspectors in to inspect its facilities. The statement says:
. . . no Australian supplied uranium can be transferred to any third country which Australia itself would not be prepared to supply directly.

How will we ever know? Because they say they will not do so or have not done so? What will we do once it has been transferred to a country such as Pakistan or to one of the African countries? What will we do when such a country says: 'We have supplied them with some plutonium which might very well have been produced from your uranium. What are you going to do about it'? We could do nothing about it. Will we stop supplying such a country with more uranium, or will we stop selling our wool or our wheat? Will we disallow one of the mineral contracts which we might have signed with it by then? There is no way in the world we would do that. The Government's statement is just so much rhtoric and so much hot air. Nobody can guarantee that a country which produces nuclear weapons, as France does, will not use Australian uranium to produce the material for those nuclear weapons.

Already we are caught between France and Japan. Japan sends its waste to France to be reprocessed. We are jammed in there and we would have absolutely no way of knowing what material had gone where and when it had gone there. We would have no way at all. France is tied in with Euratom, the European Atomic Energy Community. We know very well that Euratom is tied with a scheme which allows the free flow of material between European countries. How do we cope with this? I suggest, for instance, that France would treat us with derision, would ignore whatever piece of paper it had signed and would go its own way. Already, of course, we cannot guarantee that our uranium would not be used in the tests in the Pacific. Horrifically, we have no way of knowing whether our uranium would be used in tests in the Antarctic if the French go ahead with the project, and we have no reason to believe that the French will not push ahead with it. This document further states:
The conclusion of the Agreement is proof that the two Governments--
The governments of Canada and of Australia-
are willing to accept themselves the stringent controls they require of others.

That sounds to me to be a bit like that old joke about the lady who went to the dentist and the tag line is: 'But we will not hurt each other, will we?' I think that that is much the same as the feeling between Canada and Australia. How can we accept that of Canada? I remind honourable senators that it was Canada who supplied the reactor to India. India was to use it only for experimentation but India was naughty and used that reactor to produce a nuclear weapon and blew a great big hole in the ground. What could anybody do? Everybody tut-tutted. Canada said that she would not supply any more uranium. That policy lasted a short time and recently both Canada and America have decided that India has shown her regrets and has paid the price and they will again supply uranium to her.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might have something to do with Pakistan.

—It might very well have something to do with Pakistan because as soon as India blew a great hole in the ground Pakistan said: 'If it is all right for you to give it to them, it is all right for you to give it to us'. We know that at the moment President Reagan is pressuring Congress to ease the safeguards agreements so that the material can be made available to countries such as Pakistan. Once it is made available to countries such as Pakistan, who else then demands the same right? After all, why should one country be kept out of the club? Why should they all not be allowed to have a go? Why should they all not be given a reactor and some plutonium to play with? Then we all can be caught up in the hurdy-gurdy.
—Like those stupid gun laws in America. They finish up shooting the President.
—Yes. If one takes the same analogy, they will finish up blowing the world to kingdom come. This statement points out:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . while applying stringent non-proliferation safeguards to our uranium exports we are prepared to make Australian uranium available to customer countries for legitimate peaceful energy purposes.

I point out to the Senate that the whole nuclear energy program came into being because the military juntas around the world wanted to produce nuclear weapons. In producing the material for nuclear weapons, energy was produced. So the so-called peaceful nuclear energy program was a great cover to provide nuclear weapons for the world. Uranium miners are so desperate for a return on the capital which they have invested that they will push governments to anything. Already we have the international spreading of nuclear weapons. Small countries all over the world are desperate to show that they too are as good as the country next door, or are desperate to pressure the country next door, by seeking nuclear weapons. If President Reagan is successful in lifting the safeguards agreements and allowing nuclear weapons, plutonium and uranium to be exported to Pakistan, we can be held just as responsible. If our uranium is exported to America we have absolutely no way of knowing that our uranium was not part of the bomb which might very well start the next war, which will be a nuclear war.

The uranium miners, as I said, are desperate for some sort of return. They have invested $420m in a processing plant. At the moment the price for uranium is hitting $20 per lb. This means that if one wants some sort of return on the money one put in, one is desperate to sell it anywhere and at any time. That, very obviously, is the stand which the uranium miners of the world and the uranium miners represented in Australia are taking, and this Government is going along with them. Never mind about all the high-flown phrases in this statement. Never mind about the so-called safeguards. There is no safeguard once this material is used. The Government is not prepared to look at safeguards in any fashion because, as it knows, and as we know, the only real safeguard is to keep the wretched material in the ground. If the Government really cared about peace, about non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, about keeping this world free from nuclear war, it would disregard the greedy uranium miners and it would listen to the majority of the people of France, Canada and Sweden who say, as we do: 'Leave it in the ground'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time is limited because of the lateness of the hour. One of the things which amazes me in a debate of this nature, when the Government has put down a series of documents, is that it is not prepared to defend them. I am the fourth speaker tonight from my side of the chamber. Not one Government member has participated except by way of a couple of childish interjections. It is a matter which should be handled by the Minister in charge of the Department of National Energy and Development, Senator Carrick, regardless of whether the Department of Foreign Affairs or other departments are involved. He is the man who is supposed to be responsible for the production of nuclear material and, in company with other Ministers, of course, to see that safeguards are observed.

SPEECH.PARA: It is surprising that the most junior Minister, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is in charge of the House during such an important debate-a junior Minister who, incidentally, is having great difficulty handling his own portfolio, who has rubbished the people suffering from the effects of agent orange and who has said that a lot of the things they have been suffering from are psychological, or, alternatively, that they have been taking drugs or that they have venereal disease. This week or in the week after the Easter recess I will provide the Minister with some photographic proof of what is happening. It will show that even he has not a grip on the problems in his Department. I understand that Senator Carrick was otherwise engaged tonight on Nation- wide, where he behaved like a crashing bore and was an abject failure in trying to explain the scandal which has now become apparent over the last day or so involving the Rundle shale oil deposits.

The agreement between Australia and France-I think this is a prime example-is one of the most tragic things which has ever been entered into by a dictatorial country. That is what France is. France has never signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. In years to come there will still be deaths from the atomic tests carried out in the Pacific. We do not know yet the long term results of the damage which has been done to the marine environment by France's underground testing. We do not know precisely what happened in the nuclear accident there some little time ago because France has been terribly silent about it, but that accident caused injury and death. I suppose one could align France's secrecy in its atomic testing with that of Russia and China. The Non-Proliferation Treaty has not been signed by China. There has been secrecy surrounding the experimentation in regard to the testing of atomic weapons. One can apply this on a broad basis to America. I shall quote a letter dated 30 October from the Australian Embassy in Paris to the French Secretary-General who entered into the negotiations with Australia. I propose to incorporate a copy of the letter of agreement at the end of my speech. The letter was sent to M. Bruno de Leusse de Syon, Secretaire-General, Ministere des Affaires Etrangeres. The address and postcode are also shown. Let me quote a couple of paragraphs from the letter. If this is not a bootlicking episode as far as the Australian Government is concerned then I would like to know what is. In the first paragraph Mr Rowland states:
Mr dear Secretary-General,

I have the honour to refer to discussions between Australian and French officials which took place in Canberra in August 1980 which covered, inter alia, an agreement for a transitional arrangement to enable conversion and/or enrichment in France of Australian origin nuclear material supplied to Japan under a sales contract concluded prior to 2 December 1972.

Senator Doug Scott led a team to France to conduct some negotiations associated with these agreements. One of the first indications we had that something was going to go wrong was a statement made by Senator Scott. From memory it was made from Paris. We were told nothing about these secret agreements that were going on. If time permits I propose tonight to read from another document which I compiled, otherwise I will do so when I continue my speech on another day. One of the great problems has been the secrecy surrouding the negotiations for the selling of uranium whether it is in the enriched form or in ore form. Incidentally, recently a statement was made by, I think, that great leader of democracy the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, who said that the Australian Government was still planning to go ahead with an enrichment plant in this country. I will not ask the responsible Minister in this place to carry the load of responsibility by requesting him to explain all about it because I am sure he has never heard of it, and obviously he would never have read the paper anyway. I refer to page 2 of Mr Rowland's letter. This ought to go into the record. It reads:

(1) This letter applies only to 478 short tons of uranium concentrate (yellowcake) which is proposed to be shipped from Australia under the contract between Shikoku Electric Power Company and Queensland Mines Ltd concluded on 9 October 1972 as to 300 short tons in January 1981 and as to 178 short tons in April 1981.

Prior to the holding of the 1972 election, when the Labor Party was succesful in winning government, none of this information was released. It was a state secret. It was probably a classified document. But now that the agreements have been made all these little things are seeping out. This shows there has been long term planning. It further shows, as the Minister for National Development and Energy indicated in this place today over the Rundle scandal, that he is not in control of the energy policy of this country and he does not know what is going on. As one of my colleagues on this side of the House said during the debate on the matter of public importance, a whole host of small shareholders have lost something like $57m. I would say-I make this accusation in all sincerity-that before this happened the Government or the people responsible in Government had warned the big shareholders what was going to happen to Rundle. In other words, it was a fake show so that some people could rip off the cream, just as in the so-called takeover of Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd. Some $16m was ripped off Australian taxpayers by avoidance of tax to fatten the pockets of somebody who already was wealthy. Paragraph 2 of the letter from Mr Rowland states:
For the purposes of this Letter the following definitions apply:

(a) ''Australian origin nuclear material'' means uranium concentrate (natural uranium ore concentrate of the approximate chemical formulation U308) and all natural, enriched and depleted uranium products, including compounds, derived therefrom, or equivalent quantities;
(b) ''conversion'' means transformation by chemical processes of uranium concentrate to uranium hexafluoride;
(c) ''enrichment'' means increasing the ratio of the isotope uranium 235 to the total uranium isotopes above the ratio found in nature;
If I may interpolate, this shows a progression well on the way towards plutonium. The letter continues:
(d) ''appropriate governmental authority'' means, in the case of France, the Secretaire-General du Comite Interministeriel de la Securite Nucleaire--
That is, the interministerial section responsible for security nuclear weapons-

or such other authority as the French Government may designate from time to time and, in the case of Australia, the Australian Safeguards Office or such other authority as the Australian Government may designate from time to time.

(3) The Australian origin nuclear material, when in France, shall not be used for any other purpose than the conversion and/or enrichment below 20 per cent in the isotope U235 contracted for and the associated storage.

The letter goes on to deal with a couple of other so-called safeguards. That document is not worth the paper that it is written on. I do not know what is wrong with this Government but it is totally oblivious to the general feeling of people in Australia in relation to the mining of uranium. I have here the results of a poll, which I propose to read, together with the questions that were asked in this survey which was taken in the Townsville region some 12 or 18 months ago when the Premier of Queensland was most anxious to see that a uranium enrichment plant was established in that area without any regard to safeguards. There was a telephone poll and a street survey. I will give the results for both. The first question was:
Are you in favour of a uranium enrichment plant being built in the Townsville area?

The results of the telephone survey, which covered 100 people, were: Twenty-six in favour; 68 opposed; six people did not understand the question, did not want to be involved or did not care. The results of the street survey of 409 people in relation to the first question were: One hundred and eleven in favour; 276 opposed, and 22 came into the other category I mentioned. The second question was:
(a) If 'Yes' to Q1 say 'Could you please give me your reasons why?'
(b) If 'No' or any other reason given in Q1 ask 'Do you support the building of uranium enrichment plants elsewhere in Australia?'

The people surveyed were slightly less emphatic in their responses to this question. The results of the telephone survey in relation to the second question were: Twenty-two said 'yes'; 44 said 'no'. In other words, there was a 100 per cent difference. Some people did not answer this question at all and two people had other replies. The results of the street survey of 409 people in relation to the second question were: Sixty-two said 'yes'; 208 said 'no' and six were undecided. The third question was a very important one. The others were important but this was the most important. It reads:
Do you feel there is enough information on the safety, and waste disposal problems affecting the nuclear industry?

In the telephone poll 12 said 'yes'; 76 said 'no' and 12 were undecided. In the street survey, 23 said 'yes'-that is, 23 people out of 409 were convinced that nuclear safeguards were sufficient-380 gave an emphatic 'no' vote and only six were undecided. Those are the sorts of figures that ought to be generally known. They have been published but not widely. There have been no gallup polls for several years in Australia to find out what the Australian population really thinks about the mining of uranium.

I know the Government Whip was very emphatic that we ought to go ahead-I know that Senator Kilgariff will admit this-with the mining of uranium in the Northern Territory. But when Japan said it would send the nuclear waste back for burying in his country from which he wanted uranium to go he said: 'No, not under any circumstances will you bury it in the central Australian desert'. The Premier of Queensland, who is known as the great upholder of democracy in this country, got very keen on the Burdekin dam project because a lot of water was needed to establish an enrichment plant in the region. But when he found out that the National Party undertook a similar poll to that which I have referred to and came up with almost identical answers he got cold feet and said: 'We will put it in a remote area'. But he did not say that it would be built in Kingaroy. Now the proposal has gone into limbo and money for the Burdekin dam has disappeared, obviously as a result of collusion between this Government and the Queensland Government in relation to the mining of uranium.

I have the results of a local authority poll for a referendum which was taken in the Thuringowa Shire. The Minatome mine is located just inside the Dalrymple Shire. The Chairman of the Thuringowa Shire, Danny Gleeson, a political chameleon, who had been in the Labor Party-in fact he has been in everything except the bath-said he would be one of the those who would take part in a civil rights campaign. I am delighted to see Senator Carrick has entered the chamber after the massive show which he has just put on for Nationwide.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Institute of Sport-Federal Funding of Local Government

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pursue the quest that, in conjunction with Senator Button, I started last week to probe to the full extent whether the Australian Institute of Sport is fully achieving the objectives for which it was set up. Senator Button and I have not been altogether happy with the responses we have been getting. When Senator Button initially raised the subject last Tuesday night he received a response from Senator Peter Baume who in a guarded fashion said that there was some sort of demarcation dispute between the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson), who is normally the Minister who deals with sporting issues, and the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman). On the next day I pursued the matter a little further. I asked whether-this was the main thrust of my campaign-in line with the objects that were supposed to be embodied in the Australian Institute of Sport, we were going to provide special facilities for field games exponents. I had in mind particularly discus throwers and people who put the shot. On Wednesday, in a further question to Senator Peter Baume, I pointed out that it is accepted that there are many claims on the usage of the Bruce Stadium and that it appeared that there was some reluctance to let the field games people use it because of damage to the turf.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst we can argue about sports priorities, the real issue is embodied in Senator Baume's statement that the Bruce Stadium is a sort of half-way house and the Canberra College of Advanced Education is prepared to have its oval used on an interim basis. Australia is probably unfortunate in that we do not have the total state commitment that applies in eastern European and most western European countries. We do not have the numerous millionaires that the United States has. In all those countries athletics are pretty well funded and facilities are usually first class. I wish to hammer home the point that some athletes are treated as second class competitors as far as facilities are concerned.

Before reporting my remarks on Thursday morning the Canberra Times had asked the respective Ministers for a comment. In the criticism that I voice, I want it to be clearly known that nobody is questioning the dedication of the director of the Australian Institute of Sport, Don Talbot. He made his mark in the swimming world. I do not question his appointment to this top position but I believe that he is in a squeeze play between the two departments. Senator Baume expounded the idea that we have an alternative place for the field games exponents. I say that that is not good enough. Obviously, the College of Advanced Education would be responsible to some degree to a Minister other than the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I come back to my attitude in this area. I think I have had more experience than most in eastern European travel. I know that if a certain area is the responsibility of only one Minister all departmental bickering is removed. I pointed out to Senator Baume that some of Australia's top field games girls such as Gael Mulhall and Bev Francis, who I suppose epitomise the zestfulness of Australian womanhood, who train so assiduously and of whom we expect the maximum number of succeses overseas, are given second class facilities.

What burns me up is that, although Senator Button started this probe last Tuesday and I continued it on Wednesday, we have had no comment from the Minister, Ian Wilson, the Lochinvar from Adelaide-not a word. We have heard nothing from his Department and nothing from the Minister for the Capital Territory. I have checked the Canberra Times up to this morning. No comments have been reported from the Ministers. I know what is behind it. This is the month of April. I say to those people who compete in field games-I have had discussions with officials of the Victorian Women's Amateur Athletic Association-that all that I have said about the playing down of field games has been borne out by the wall of silence. I say again that it is the month of April. The Budget will be presented in August. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) spoke on record about this Institute and what it would do. We were going to recapture former glories in some sports. Frankly, it has become a victim of the gang of four. I give notice now to my colleagues in the Estimates committees which deal with the estimates for the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and the Department of the Capital Territory that we will certainly push this matter. But I am a political realist.

Senator Baume, who represents the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment in this chamber, is absent from the Senate. I took the trouble to ring his office at 10 a.m. to advise him that I would raise this matter. Senator Messner, representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, may be the one to give me good tidings; I do not know. I can assure him that as far as many people outside this chamber and I are concerned, if the Institute is to meet its full ramifications, every one and every sport must be equal as far as its operations are concerned. I say again and again that it is not a matter of having interim facilities. There is ample land in Canberra for such facilities. There is no question that a short discussion between the Minister for the Capital Territory, Michael Hodgman, and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Ian Wilson, should clear up the matter in an hour. As a matter of fact, anybody who read last Thursday's Canberra Times would have got the impression that we were on the threshold of a breakthrough.

Like most senators, I have a copy of the Australian Olympic Federation report on the 1980 Olympic Games. In the women's field games, the first place in the discus throwing competition went to East Germany, the second to Bulgaria and the third to the Soviet Union. In the shot put competition East Germany was first, the Soviet Union was second and East Germany was third. I am not a jingoistic person and I do not think any of our athletes are either, but this is the age of specialisation. The money involved would be peanuts. When some of these early Press releases came out I almost asked whether some Press officers prostituted their profession. Frankly, the style now is for a Minister to announce a new era, a vision splendid, and when six months later as a political infantryman one tries to find out what has happened there are always a lot of gaps in the story. There is no doubt that if Senator Button and I had not commenced this probe last week these girls who compete in discus and shot put events, would have been living in a dream world believing that everything was right. Well, everything is not right. I believe that we pay a pretty poor compliment to these people. We expect them to compete overseas in the future. I have before me a letter from the Australian Olympic Federation, signed by the Honourary Secretary-General. He deals with forward planning. He states:
Preparation for . . . the Summer Games . . . in Los Angeles, July 28th-August 12th-and the Winter Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia . . .

He goes on to mention future targets. Here we are arguing about the piddling amount of money needed to provide land for this Institute. As we have seen happen so often in many sports, if one is only a tenant and not the landlord, by the whim of somebody else one can be pitched out. I think we all appreciate that the rhythm of training should be maintained and that if it is suddenly broken we cannot expect success.

I wind up on this point: Those people in the field games have been excellent ambassadors for Australia in any country in which they have been competing. Even though in this particular area we certainly were not quite up to the standard of the East European countries that I mentioned there is no doubt that we were in the Pacific Games. Gael Mulhall, for example, dominated those proceedings as she did in the subsequent games held in the capital city of the State of South Australia which the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, represents. I note that the Minister acquiesces with that assertion. The fact is, as I said last week, that actions speak louder than words and I would expect the two Ministers to go public and give us the real story. What is much more important is that at the end of a season these girls are still training hard. The Melbourne Age of Monday carried a report about one of our illustrious coaches who had been unwell but who had come back to coaching under extreme difficulties. Most of our top athletes flocked to him to discuss technical problems with him. If that dedication by our athletes is to be maintained, let us give a bit of lead. Let the two Ministers concerned make a public utterance. I repeat, in this age of budgets for departments amounting to many millions, not much money is here involved. I leave the matter at that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I intend to correct misleading information given to this chamber last week by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume. Last week, Senator Walters asked a Dorothy Dix question of the Minister in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar). Senator Walters's question related to Federal Government funding for local government. She asked whether the Minister could 'inform the chamber of the amount by which the Federal Government funding to local government has increased since the Fraser Governent took office'. If the Minister had not been given advance warning of this question, he would not have had the necessary figures at hand. Last Wednesday, however, he provided to the honourable senator for Tasmania figures which purported to show how much more the Fraser Government had given to local authorities than the previous Labor Government. This exchange occurred on 1 April so perhaps the Minister was only trying to enter into the spirit of the day when he answered Senator Walters's question.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the Minister informed Senator Walters that in the last Whitlam Budget-1975-76-the sum of $80m was provided to local government; that in the first Fraser Budget-1976-77-it jumped to $140m; and that in last year's Budget, the allocation made by the allegedly generous Fraser Government to local authorities was $221m. These figures are certainly impressive. I am sure that many people who heard the question and answer on the rebroadcast of proceedings that evening would think that the Fraser Government had been extremely generous to local authorities. The only problem is that Senator Baume's assertions are not correct. The Minister has conveniently looked at only one aspect of the Federal Government's financial assistance to local authorities, namely, general purpose assistance for local government.

I refer the Minister to 1980-81 Budget Paper No. 7, a copy of which I am sure he has in his office. He will see that on page 108 there is a long list of other direct and indirect payments that are Federal Government grants to local authorities. At the base of page 108 the total amounts provided to local government by the Commonwealth Government are shown for four financial years. These amounts are: 1976-77, $192.160m; 1977-78, $201.668m; 1978-79, $212.094m; and 1979-80, $255.313m. If the Minister would consult a previous Budget Paper, he would see that the total amount, not in just one area that happened to suit the Minister's argument, provided to local government in the last Whitlam Budget in 1975-76 was $274.255m. So, not in any year since the Fraser Government took office has the total amount allocated to local government reached the level of funding provided in the last Whitlam Budget. These figures which I have quoted do not represent the level of funding in real terms. Expressed in 1975-76 dollar values, the figures would read as follows: 1976-77, $174.058m; 1977-78, $168.478m; 1978-79, $167.003m and 1979-80, $184.608m. Again, these figures do not compare at all favourably with the Whitlam Government's allocation of $274.255m in 1975-76.

I do not know whether the Minister thinks that by simply forgetting to mention all the extra payments to local government in addition to the general purpose assistance, or the tax sharing entitlement as it is now called, he will fool either the Senate or local authorities that they are better off under the Fraser Government. I suggest to the Minister that the next time he supplies an answer to a Dorothy Dixer from an honourable senator on his side of the chamber he make sure that he has a factual answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With reference to Senator Mulvihill's remarks in connection with the Australian Institute of Sport, as he has pointed out, this matter has received some attention in the media and, in particular, in the local newspapers. I know that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the Honourable Ian Wilson, is aware of the particular problem as are a number of honourable senators on this side of the chamber. I will bring the matter to his attention and ask him to bring down a reply to Senator Mulvihill as soon as possible. I might just mention that Senator Baume did know that Senator Mulvihill was going to address this problem. However, he has been caught in Cabinet and is not able to be here at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Colston sought to set the record straight, as he termed it, in regard to Senator Baume's answer to Senator Walters's question last week. I am not in any way debating the questions and the points that Senator Colston raised but I wonder whether-and I will check this by reference to the records which he quoted-the 1975 figure for grants to local government which he mentioned in fact included the Regional Employment Development Scheme grants which were, of course, of a fairly short duration, were cancelled by the former Whitlam Government, would not have applied in subsequent years and certainly were not taken up by the Fraser Government when it came to power at the end of 1975. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: How much has the Government saved since coming to office through: (a) the one-month pension rise delay announced in February 1976; (b) the suspension of twice-yearly pension indexation in 1978; (c) payment of the consumer price index (CPI) adjustment up to 30 June 1979, on 8 November 1979, rather than on 30 June 1979; (d) payment of the adjustment for the CPI rise up to 31 December 1979, from May 1980, rather than from 31 December 1979; and (e) payment of the adjustment for the CPI rise up to 30 June 1980, from November 1980, rather than from 30 June 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) If the May 1976 increases in indexed pension and benefit rates had been paid from the first payday in April 1976, additional expenditure on Social Security pensions and benefits would have been about $25m.

(b) If pension and benefit rates had been indexed in May 1979 by the increase in the consumer price index from the June to December quarters 1978, there would have been additional expenditure of about $95m on Social Security pensions and benefits in the period May to October 1979.

(c) If the November 1979 increases in indexed pension and benefit rates had been paid with effect from 1 July 1979, additional expenditure on Social Security pensions and benefits would have been about $140m.

(d) If the May 1980 increases in indexed pension and benefit rates had been paid with effect from 1 January 1980, additional expenditure on Social Security pensions and benefits would have been about $96m.

(e) If the November 1980 increases in indexed pensions and benefit rates had been paid with effect from 1 July 1980, additional expenditure on Social Security pensions and benefits would have been about $96m.

It should be noted that these cost estimates exclude expenditure on pensions paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Also, no allowance has been made for the effect on revenue of the taxation of the payments concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of complaints by fisheries officials, especially the Australian Fishing Industry Council, regarding the mesh size used by Taiwanese trawlers off Western Australia.
(2) Is it true that the Government has imposed a mesh limitation of 50 mm on the nets of these trawlers working on the North West Shelf.
(3) Has the Taiwanese put one net inside the other effectively halving the net size and the size of the fish caught so as to net small fish, a demand for which exists in Taiwan.

(4) Does the Minister agree with the Australian Fishing Industry Council's contention that the pattern of fishing by the Taiwanese on the North West Shelf made it uneconomic for an Australian boat to work that area.
(5) Is it true that the Taiwanese are allowed to operate in this region because the Australian industry have been unable to use the area.

(6) Have Australian fishermen been unable to fish this region because the Taiwanese establishment there had made it unlikely that the stock of fish would build up to the point where is could be fished by Australian vessels.
(7) Will the Minister undertake urgent action to change this situation if these matters are true.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Prior to negotiations with the Taiwanese and their Australian representative in September last year, extensive discussions were held with Australian Fishing Industry Council representatives on the terms and conditions of access for Taiwanese vessels including proposed measures to control fishing operations by the Taiwanese in north and north west waters. During the negotiations with the Taiwanese, which were attended by observers representing the Australian Fishing Industry Council, and the Western Australian and Northern Territory Governments, the Taiwanese were informed of the intended introduction of legislation to prohibit the use of cod end liners and to set a minimum mesh size of 50 mm during the period of the current agreement.
(2) Yes. A Fisheries Notice restricting the use by pair trawlers of a net with mesh which is less than 50 mm came into operation on 1 April 1981.
(3) In the past, yes. However the use of any material or device which blocks or obstructs the mesh of the cod-end was prohibited from 1 January 1981 by Fisheries Notice No. 95.

(4) The Australian Fishing Industry Council has been fully consulted on the conditions of access for Taiwanese vessels to waters of the North West Shelf. Competition from Taiwanese would affect the success of Australian operations in the area but other factors such as operating expenses and availability of suitable markets would also be major determinants of economic success. In order to assist in the assessment of the commercial viability of Australian fishing operations on the North West Shelf the Government approved several feasibility fishing ventures by Australian fishing interests involving the use of Japanese and Korean stern trawlers. These projects operated in areas fished by the Taiwanese and through the use of different mesh sizes valuable information on catch rates, species mix and size composition of fish was obtained. Information obtained from these operations is available to the Australian fishing industry.

(5) The Taiwanese have operated in waters of the North West Shelf for many years. In accordance with our responsibility to allow foreigners access to stocks not fished, or only lightly fished by Australians, within the 200 mile Australian fishing zone (AFZ), the Taiwanese have continued to fish in the area since the AFZ commenced on 1 November 1979. Under agreements negotiated with Taiwanese commercial interests their fishing effort has been considerably reduced, primarily by limitation on the allowable catch, and certain fisheries and areas of interest to Australians are now closed to the Taiwanese. The closed areas were extended following consultations with industry during the last round of negotiations for access by Taiwanese vessels. Taiwanese fishing operations have been closely monitored and controlled since the extension of Australia's fisheries jurisdiction.

(6) No Australians operated in the north west trawl fishery before the Taiwanese fishery was established in 1973. Since 1974, catch rates have been stable. As I have mentioned, areas have been closed to Taiwanese fishing in order to allow for an expansion in Australian fishing operations. Moreover, the allowable catch is well below the Taiwanese catch prior to the introduction of the 200 mile Australian fishing zone and gear restrictions have been introduced.

(7) Operations by foreign fishing vessels are kept under constant review by Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Governments in order to determine appropriate management measures to apply and restrictions if any to be introduced to protect the interests of the Australian fishing industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In what years has Australia been a member of the (a) Special Committee on the Situation with regard to the Implementation of the Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and People; and (b) Working Group of the Committee (see Question No. 29, Senate Hansard, 5 December 1980, page 500).
(2) On what occasions and with what results have the (a) Special Committee and (b) Working Group considered the French territories in the Pacific.

(3) Did the United Nations General Assembly resolve on 11 December 1980 that the Special Committee should undertake a thorough review of the list of territories which have not yet attained independence and should report thereon to the next session of the General Assembly.
(4) On what dates (a) have the (i) Special Committee and (ii) Working Group met since 11 December 1980; and (b) is each due to meet.
(5) What attitude has Australia taken on the French territories in the Pacific at meetings of the (a) Special Committee; and (b) Working Group.
(6) What attitude has Australia decided to take on the French territories in the Pacific at meetings of the (a) Special Committee and (b) Working Group this year.
(7) What other countries are members of the (a) Special Committee; and (b) Working Group.
(8) What consultations has Australia had with those countries on the French territories in the Pacific since 11 December 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Australia joined the Special Committee on the Situation with regard to the Implementation of the Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples when it was established in 1961 and has been a member ever since, except for the period from January 1969 to January 1973.

(b) The Working Group of the Special Committee is an informal group which the Chairman of the Committee can convene at his discretion to assist him in planning the work program of the Committee. Its membership has come to consist of the office bearers of the Committee and several others invited by the Chairman. Australia was invited at the beginning of 1980 to participate in the Group.

(2) (a) The Anglo-French Condominium of the New Hebrides was considered from 1961, when the Special Committee was established, until 31 July 1980 when it attained independence as the Republic of Vanuatu. No other French territory in the Pacific has been considered by the Special Committee.

(b) The Working Group did not consider the New Hebrides. The New Caledonia Independentist Front made representations in 1980 to the Chairman of the Special Committee to have New Caledonia reinstated on the United Nations list of non-self-governing territories. Such a decision can be taken only by the General Assembly of the United Nations. The Special Committee, however, is the appropriate body to make a recommendation to the General Assembly on the issue. The Chairman of the Special Committee decided, as an initial step, to convene a meeting of the Working Group in August 1980 to consider the representation. The Working Group agreed that the documentation provided by the Independentist Front should be put to study. No date has yet been set by the Chairman for reconvening the Working Group.
(3) Yes, in General Assembly Resolution 35/118.

(4) (a) and (b) The Special Committee met on 21 January 1981. No timetable of future meetings has yet been decided. The Working Group has not met since 12 August 1980. As noted under 1 (b) above, the Chairman of the Special Committee has the discretion to call meetings of the Working Group.

(5) (a) In the Special Committee Australia supported the program of self-determination for the New Hebrides and was a member of the United Nations Mission which visited the territory and observed the elections in November 1979. At meetings of the Special Committee in August 1980, Australia took a leading role in the adoption of an appropriate resolution welcoming the accession to independence of the new state of Vanuatu and at the same time expressing regret that continuing incidents on the island of Espiritu Santo, supported by foreign nationals, were not brought to an end before independence.
(b) Australia agreed with the decision of the Working Group noted in answer 2 (b) above.

(6) (a) and (b) The attitude to be taken by Australia at any meetings this year of the Special Committee and the Working Group which discuss French territories in the Pacific will be decided having regard to the matters arising at the meetings, to considerations relevant at the time of such meetings, and to the resolution adopted by the South Pacific Forum at Honiara in 1979, which read in part as follows:

'Noting the desire of Pacific Island peoples, including those in French territories, to determine their own future, the Forum re-affirmed its belief in the principle of self-determination and independence applying to all Pacific Island peoples in accordance with their freely expressed wishes. Accordingly the Forum called on the metropolitan powers concerned to work with the peoples of their Pacific Territories to this end.'
(7) (a) The Special Committee is composed of the following 25 countries:

Afghanistan, Australia, Bulgaria, Chile, China, Congo, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Ethiopia, Fiji, India, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Ivory Coast, Mali, Sierra Leone, Syria, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia, USSR, Tanzania, Venezuela, Yugoslavia.
(b) The Working Group is composed of the following ten countries:
Australia, Congo, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Iran, Ivory Coast, Sierra Leone, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia.

(8) No consultations on French Territories in the Pacific have been held within the framework of the Special Committee since adoption of General Assembly Resolution 35/118 on 11 December 1980. Naturally, Australia will be consulting at the appropriate time with members of the Special Committee and with other countries concerned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1981 (Hansard, page 79) Senator Bonner asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. The question concerned the accuracy of an article in Newsweek concerning Soviet use of Cam Ranh Bay.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Increased use by Soviet Naval Forces of the port of Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam has been noted. This port was formerly used by United States forces in Vietnam. We have no evidence however to support reports of construction at Cam Ranh Bay, or any other Vietnamese port, for the exclusive use of Soviet nuclear submarines.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Joint Tropical Trials and Research Establishment

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1981 (Hansard, page 84) Senator Keeffe asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. His question concerned the transfer of Service personnel from the Joint Tropical Trials and Research Establishment (JTTRE).

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The JTTRE conducts hot-wet and hot-dry exposure trials of defence material and materials for the United Kingdom Ministry of Defence and the Australian Department of Defence.

The Establishment was formed in 1977 by the amalgamation of the Joint Tropical Research Unit and the Tropical Trials Establishment. The latter was formerly an Army unit and twelve of its Army personnel in administrative-clerical positions were retained. These servicemen were employed at Pin Gin Hill and Cowley Beach.
Experience has shown that a new Establishment requires a review after a settling-down period, and an Establishment Review was conducted at JTTRE in September 1980.
The Review recommended that all Service positions be dis-established for the following reasons:
The level of activity involving Service personnel at JTTRE no longer justifies the retention of servicemen, particularly when higher priority requirements for them exist elsewhere.
The Review concluded that the duties undertaken by the military personnel can now be undertaken by civilian staff within current staff ceilings.
The servicemen were not fully employed and not performing worthwhile and satisfying duties.
The servicemen were performing duties that did not require service training or experience.

The last serviceman (a driver) is expected to be withdrawn from JTTRE about the end of April this year. There will be occasions when trials conducted at JTTRE will require the participation of servicemen. In such cases the necessary servicemen will be drawn from the appropriate operational unit for deployment to JTTRE for the duration of the trials.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1981 (Hansard, page 148) Senator Walters asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. The question sought clarification of the definition of 'de facto spouse' in Determination No. 26 of 1980.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The definition of 'de facto spouse' in Determination No. 26 of 1980 was included in that Determination to cover payment of Post Allowance to members in de facto relationships who otherwise qualify for the Allowance.

The definition used was one which applied to de facto relationships in the Defence Force at that time. It has since been amended after a thorough examination by the Department and the three Services. The definition in use since 13 January 1981 requires that there should be a period of twelve months cohabitation before a de facto relationship may be recognised and that there should be either a child dependent on the de facto couple, or a legal impediment to their marriage.
In a case where legal impediment to marriage is claimed, a maximum period of eighteen months is to be generally applied to Service recognition of the relationship.

Regarding the question whether the definitions of de facto spouse or de facto relationship should be uniform with those contained in other Commonwealth legislation, these definitions should be designed to meet the particular purpose of the legislation as is the case with other Commonwealth legislation.

In respect of Defence Force Salaries and Financial Regulations, the definitions govern extension of considerable financial and conditions of service benefits to those who satisfy them. This needs to be considered in the framing of the definitions.
